PART II - CODE OF ORDINANCES 
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of the City of West Miami, Florida," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1965, § 1-1) 
Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless the content clearly indicates otherwise: 
    City means the City of West Miami, Florida, and shall extend to and include its several officers, agencies and departments. 
    Computation of time. In computing any period of time prescribed or allowed by this Code, the day of the act, event or default from which the designated period of time begins to run shall not be included. The last day of the period so computed shall be included unless it is a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday in which event the period shall run until the end of the next day which is neither a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. When the period of time prescribed or allowed is less than seven (7) days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. 
    County means the County of Dade. 
    County Code. The words "County Code," or the initials M.D.C.C., shall mean the "Code of Metropolitan Dade County." 
    Gender. The masculine includes the feminine and neuter and vice versa. 
    Number. The singular includes the plural and vice versa. 
    Oath. The word "oath" includes an affirmation. 
    Officers, departments, agencies. Whenever reference is made herein to any office, officer, department or agency, unless otherwise specified, it shall mean such office, officer, department or agency of the City, and shall include the duly authorized personnel and subordinates of such office, officer, department or agency. 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" includes individuals, children, firms, associations, joint adventures, partnerships, estates, trusts, business trusts, syndicates, fiduciaries, corporations, and all other groups or combinations. 
    Personal property includes every species of property except real property. 
    Shall, may. The word "shall" is always mandatory. "May" is permissive or directory. 
    State means the State of Florida. 
    Statutory citations herein, unless otherwise specified, are to Florida Statutes, 1979, as supplemented by the 1980 Supplement, and are intended and shall be construed merely as a convenience to the user of this Code. The fact that a citation herein may be rendered no longer appropriate or correct because of subsequent enactments of the Legislature shall not invalidate or otherwise affect the meaning of the provision in which the citation appears, and such citation shall be deemed to refer to the appropriate provisions under such subsequent legislation. 
    Tense. Words used in the present or past tense include the future as well as the present and past. 
(Code 1965, § 1-2) 
State Law reference- General statutory definitions and rules of construction, F.S. § 1.01. 
Sec. 1-3. - Matters not affected by Code. 
    Neither the provisions of this Code nor the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of such Code; nor shall this Code or the ordinance adopting it affect: 
(a)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by the City or authorizing the issuance of any bonds or other evidences of indebtedness by the City; 
(b)  Any contract or obligation assumed or entered into by the City; 
(c)  Any right, franchise or license granted by the City; 
(d)  Any ordinance accepting, naming, establishing, locating or providing for the improving of any specific street or way in the City; 
(e)  Any ordinance adopting or amending a budget or making any appropriation; 
(f)  Any ordinance levying or otherwise relating to the imposition of ad valorem taxes; 
(g)  Any ordinance which by its own terms or by operation of law is effective only for a stated or limited time; 
(h)  Any ordinance relating to specific local improvements or special assessments therefor; 
(i)  Any ordinance accepting any subdivision plat or dedication in connection therewith; 
(j)  Any ordinance relating to the acquisition or conveyance of specific property by the City; 
(k)  Any ordinance or type of ordinances specifically referred to and continued in effect by such Code; 
(l)  Zoning ordinances of the City. 
Sec. 1-4. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be the titles of such sections, nor to any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or re-enacted. 
(Code 1965, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-5. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion therein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section or subsection or any portion thereof, such repealed portions may be excluded from said code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are re-adopted as a new Code by the City Commission. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section (or subsection or paragraph) number of this Code in substantially the following language: "That section (or subsection or paragraph) ____________ of the West Miami City Code, is hereby amended to read as follows:...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  In the event a new section (or subsection or paragraph) not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the West Miami City Code is hereby amended by adding a section (or subsection or paragraph) to be numbered ____________ , which said section (or subsection or paragraph) reads as follows:...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1965, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-6. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
    No suit, proceeding, right, fine, penalty or forfeiture, instituted, created, given, accrued or secured under any ordinance previous to its repeal, shall in any way be affected, released or discharged by its repeal, but may be prosecuted, enjoined or recovered as fully as if such ordinance had continued in force, unless expressly provided. 
(Code 1965, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-7. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    If any ordinance, provision, section, paragraph, sentence, clause, or phrase of this Code is for any reason found to be invalid or inoperative by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of the provisions and ordinances of this Code shall nevertheless continue in full force and effect. 
(Code 1965, § 1-6) 
Sec. 1-8. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the City to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the City of West Miami to be misrepresented thereby. Any person, firm or corporation violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-9. 
(Code 1965, § 1-7) 
State Law reference- Forging or altering public records prohibited, F.S. § 831.01. 
Sec. 1-9. - General penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this Code or any ordinance where no other penalty is prescribed, shall, upon conviction, be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or be imprisoned for not more than sixty (60) days, or shall be both fined and imprisoned, in the discretion of the court. Each day that such violation shall continue (or, in the case of shows and exhibitions illegally conducted, each performance) shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1965, § 1-8) 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, F.S. § 162.22. 
Sec. 1-10. - Offenses dependent on notice. 
    When the unlawfulness of an act or omission shall depend upon the giving of a notice by any officer of the City, the continuance of the act or omission, after such notice, shall be deemed an offense, and the offender shall be punishable for each day of such continuance as for a separate offense. 
(Code 1965, § 1-10) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Plan review board, § 5-36 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - When newly elected Councilmen inducted. 
    The first meeting of the newly elected Council for induction into office shall be held at 8:00 p.m. in the evening on the first Monday next following its election. 
(Laws of Fla. 1949, ch. 26301, art. III, § 3) 
Sec. 2-2. - Oath of office of City officers. 
    Every officer of the City shall, before entering upon the duties of his office, take and subscribe to the following oath or affirmation to be filed and kept in the office of the City Clerk: 
    "I solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support the Constitution and will obey the laws of the United States and the State of Florida; that I will in all respects observe the provisions of the charter and the ordinances of the City of West Miami and will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of ____________ ." 
(Laws of Fla. 1949, ch. 26301, art. VI, § 6) 
Sec. 2-3. - Investigatory powers of Commission. 
    The Commission, or a committee authorized by it, shall have the power to inquire into the conduct of any office, department or officer of the City and to make investigations as to City affairs; and for that purpose may subpoena witnesses, administer oaths and compel the production of books, papers and other evidence. Failure to obey such subpoena and to produce books, papers or other evidence as ordered under the provisions of this section, shall constitute a violation of this Code. 
(Laws of Fla. 1949, ch. 26301, art. VI, § 3) 
Sec. 2-4. - Commission to keep journal. 
    The Commission shall keep a journal of its proceedings and the journal shall be open to public inspection. 
(Laws of Fla. 1949, ch. 26301, art. III, § 10) 
Sec. 2-5. - Duties of City Clerk as Clerk of Commission. 
    The City Clerk shall give notice of Commission meetings, shall keep the journal of the Commission's proceedings, and shall authenticate by his signature and record in full in a book kept for the purpose all ordinances and resolutions. 
(Laws of Fla. 1949, ch. 26301, art. III, § 9) 
Sec. 2-6. - Group insurance for City officers and employees, retired employees, and new employees eligibility. 
(a)  Pursuant to Florida Statutes, the City Commission may exercise its option to provide group life, health, accident, hospitalization or annuity insurance in accordance with Section 112.08 through 112.153 of the Florida Statutes, and any amendments thereto. Members and their dependents of the City Commission, City Manager, City Attorney, and any other City officers and employees that the City Commission may designate, are eligible to enroll and participate in the benefits of any group life, health, accident, hospitalization or annuity insurance of the City of West Miami, Florida. 
(b)  All retired personnel and spouse, or survivor of them, hereinafter collectively called "retired employee," who meet the following conditions precedent, conditions, standards and guidelines, shall be entitled to the same benefits of group insurance as active employees of the City, provided: 
(1)  The retired employee must be continuously employed by the City of West Miami for a period of not less than eight (8) years including therein the following: 
a.  The period of time commencing ten (10) days prior to the first day of qualifying and ending at the time he assumed office, if elected, that the retired employee had to resign to qualify as a candidate for City office by reason of State law; and 
b.  The period of time that the retired employee has to leave City employment by reason of sickness or accident. 
However, there may be one (1) break in such continuous employment if: 
a.  The retired employee shall have been an employee for a period of one (1) year immediately prior to meeting the eight (8) year eligibility period; and if 
b.  The last one (1) year of employment shall have been continuous and without interruption for leave, leave-of-absence, sick leave or other absences with the exception that sick leave shall have been permitted for a period of five (5) days during the one (1) year period and that regular vacation periods that have been taken had not exceeded the normal vacation period based upon the years of service of the employee. 
(2)  The retired employee shall not be eligible for benefits relating to any illness contracted or accident suffered during the time the retired employee was not an active employee of the City. 
(3)  All benefits will terminate three (3) months after the retired employee becomes eligible to receive Social Security and supplementary benefits regardless of whether or not such benefits have been applied for. 
(4)  The costs to the retired employee shall be adjusted by the Commission to reflect, in the Commission's sole determination, a fair premium cost based upon the benefit and age group of all retired employees as a group. In no event shall the cost be less than that as is being paid by then active employees. 
(5)  The retired employee shall not be eligible for benefits if the retired employee is subsequently employed by an employer other than the City and either is receiving or is eligible to receive benefits from the subsequent employer. 
(6)  If an active employee becomes sick or disabled and is retired by reason of such disability and is eligible to receive Social Security benefits, the retired employee shall make good faith effort to receive such Social Security benefits, including but not limited to exhausting all administrative remedies and appeals; otherwise it shall be deemed conclusively that the retired employee is not eligible for City benefits. The retired employee shall not be eligible for City benefits. However, if the retired employee recovers and is not otherwise eligible for Social Security benefits, then the employee shall be eligible to obtain City benefits subject to other exclusions and conditions provided herein. 
(7)  The City shall extend this coverage to the active personnel, both past and future, provided they do meet the terms and conditions set forth in this section. 
(c)  New employees of the City are not eligible for insurance benefits until they have been a full time employee for a period of not less than ninety (90) days. Full time employment shall be considered as working for more than thirty (30) hours per week, except members of City Commission, City Manager, City Attorney and any other City officer designated by the City Commission who shall be eligible upon commencement of their duties. 
(Code 1965, §§ 2-21-2-27; Ord. No. 86-04, § 1, 9-3-1986; Ord. No. 87-14, § 1, 8-19-1987) 
Sec. 2-7. - Performance bonds required of certain officers and employees. 
    All officers and employees of the City among whose duties is the handling of the funds of said City, or who have custody of its property, shall furnish bond with surety in the sum prescribed by the Commission, but in no case less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), before entering upon their respective duties. Said bond to be conditioned upon the faithful performance of their respective duties in connection with the handling of City funds and custody of City property. Said surety may be the official bond of a good, solvent surety company authorized to do business in the State of Florida. The premiums of such bonds shall be paid by the City. All such bonds shall be filed with and preserved by the City Clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 2-1) 
Sec. 2-8. - Payment of judgments against City personnel. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy of the City to pay any final judgment against any official or employee of the City arising from a complaint for damages or injury suffered as a result of any act or omission of such official or employee as provided in F.S. § 111.071 and F.S. § 768.8(9), as authorized by said statutes and under the terms and conditions of said statutes. 
(Ord. No. 406, § 1, 12-17-1980) 
Sec. 2-9. - Lien for nonpayment of City service charges. 
(a)  Imposed. Whenever the City shall furnish water service, electric service, sewer service, trash collection, garbage collection, or other similar service to the owner or occupant of any real estate within the City for a service charge or fee, and the service charges or fees for such services shall not be paid within three (3) calendar months from the date of the mailing such bill or statement of service charges or fees to the owner or occupant of the real estate receiving the benefits of such services, such delinquent service charges or fees and any penalty charges imposed thereon for nonpayment shall be and thereupon become a lien upon the real estate to which such services were delivered or where such services were performed. Such liens shall become effective three (3) calendar months after mailing of bill or statement therefor to the property owner or occupant at the address of said property without further action on the part of the City and without the necessity of filing same with the Clerk of any Court. 
(b)  Priority; collection. The liens provided for in subsection (a) shall have the same priority and dignity as taxes on real property. Such liens shall be collected in the same manner as provided by law for collection of delinquent real estate taxes. 
(c)  Authorization to decline to contract directly with tenants; deposit for service. 
(1)  The City administration may, at its option: 
a.  Contract directly with owners for garbage, water and sewer services and utilities; and 
b.  Require individual contracts for garbage, water and sewer services and utilities, if any, provided by the City of West Miami be made directly with the owner of the real property; or 
c.  Request a deposit or other security from owner of real property; and 
d.  Require that the deposit for garbage services from owner of property be in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00); 
e.  Require that the deposit for water and sewer services from owner of property be in the amount of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00); 
f.  Withdraw from the security deposited collected and deposited in the City by tenant/non-owner occupant or owner for the purpose of payment, arrears of amounts due for services rendered to the tenant/non-owner occupants or owners; 
g.  Discontinue services to a tenant/non-owner occupant or owner who is in arrears of thirty (30) days or more. 
(2)  In the event that the City administration determines to contract for water, sewer, garbage or any services directly with the owner of the real property, upon nonpayment of such charges, within thirty (30) days after the overdue bills are thereafter mailed to the property owner, at the last mailing address on record for such owner, then such delinquent charges shall become a lien on that real estate or any real estate owned by the owner of the subject property without further action on the part of the City and thereafter, may be collected in the same manner as provided by law for collection of delinquent real estate taxes, such liens having the same priority and dignity as real estate taxes. 
(Code 1965, § 2-5; Ord. No. 2008-03, §§ 2, 3, 8-6-2008) 
Charter reference- Authority to impose lien for delinquent service charges, § 7.03. 
Cross reference- Fees for city garbage collection, § 8-24 et seq.; clearing of litter from open private property by city and lien therefor, § 8-66; water rates and charges, § 15-47 et seq. 
Sec. 2-10. - Collection and service fee for dishonored checks. 
    Whenever any check, draft or other order for the payment of money to the City is returned for any reason by the bank or other payor upon which the same shall have been drawn, it shall be the duty of the City Manager to collect same and to add a five dollar ($5.00) service fee to the amount due. The five dollar ($5.00) service fee shall be in addition to all other penalties imposed by law. 
    The service fees collected pursuant to this section shall be deposited in the same fund as the collected item. 
(Ord. No. 369, §§ 1, 2, 10-16-1975) 
State Law reference- Service fee authorized, F.S. § 166.251. 
Sec. 2-11. - Manner of publication when not otherwise provided. 
    Wherever "publication" is required herein or by an ordinance, and the manner of publication is not prescribed by law or ordinance, such publication may be made by posting at a conspicuous place in the City Hall for the requisite period. 
(Laws of Fla. 1949, ch. 26301, art. VI, § 8) 
Sec. 2-12. - Acting City Manager; conditions; restrictions; manner and procedure for appointment; designation. 
    The City Manager shall designate at all times, in writing, filed with the Commission, the name of a qualified City administrative officer to be acting City Manager in the event of temporary absence, disability, death, resignation or otherwise, to exercise the powers and to perform the duties of Manager, during said circumstances. Such designation shall be subjected to approval by the City Commission. The Commission may revoke such designation and approval at any time and appoint another person to serve until the City Manager shall return and be able to carry out the duties of City Manager or until a new City Manager is appointed The City Manager may from time to time change such designation subject to the approval of the Commission. The City Manager shall state publicly the person who is currently designated to be the acting City Manager. In the event that there is no valid designation of such person by the Manager, approved by the Commission, then the Commission shall designate and appoint the acting City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 86-08, § 1, 9-17-1986) 
Sec. 2-13. - Decorum at City Commission meetings. 
    Any person who makes impertinent or slanderous remarks or who become boisterous while addressing the City Commission of the City of West Miami shall be barred from said audience before the City Commission by the presiding officer (Mayor), unless permission to continue or again address the Commission be granted by a majority vote of the Commission members present. 
(Ord. No. 94-08, 12-7-1994) 
Editor's note- Nonamendatory Ord. No. 94-08, adopted Dec. 7, 1994, has been included herein as section 2-13 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 2-14-2-21. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ELECTIONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Elections generally, Art. VI. 
County Code references- Payments to candidates, including candidates for municipal office, prohibited, MDCC § 12-8; soliciting payments from candidates, including candidates for municipal office, in exchange for enforcement, § 12-9. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-22. - Adoption of State code. 
    Those chapters of the State Election Code, applicable to municipalities, being Florida Statutes Chapters 97, 98, 99, 100, 101, 102, 104, and 106 be, and the same are hereby adopted except where in conflict with the City and Dade County charters and ordinances, insofar as the same may be made to apply to municipal elections. 
(Code 1965, § 7-1; Ord. No. 377, § 1, 1-15-1978) 
Sec. 2-23. - Polling place designated. 
    The City Hall is hereby designated as the polling place for each and every municipal election held within the City. 
(Code 1965, § 7-2) 
Sec. 2-24. - Procedure for qualification of candidates. 
    All candidates for the office of City Commissioner, in regular or special elections, who otherwise meet the qualifications established by the Charter, shall pay a qualification fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). Such fee shall be paid from funds on deposit in the primary campaign depository only by means of a check drawn upon the campaign account of the candidate, payable to the City, and shall be paid to the City Clerk at the time each candidate shall qualify. Candidates for the office of Mayor and City Commissioner may qualify during a designated qualifying period commencing at noon of the 50th day and ending at noon of the 46th day prior to the City's regular municipal election. Dates for qualification of candidates in special elections shall be as provided by the Commission or the Mayor in accordance with section 3.05(c)(2) or (3) of the Charter. 
(Code 1965, § 7-3; Ord. No. 87-05, § 1, 5-6-1987; Ord. No. 97-02, §§ 1, 2, 3-5-1997) 
Charter reference- Time and manner of qualifying to be set by ordinance, § 6.02. 
Sec. 2-25. - Commission as judge of elections and qualifications. 
    The Commission shall be the judge of the election and qualifications of its members and for such purpose shall have power to subpoena witnesses and require the production of records but the decision of the Commission in any case shall be subject to review by the courts. 
(Laws of Fla. 1945, ch. 263.1, art. III, § 4) 
Sec. 2-26. - Persons allowed in polling places in City elections only. 
    As many electors may be admitted to vote in a City election only as there are booths available, and no person who is not in line to vote may come within three hundred (300) feet of any polling place from the opening to the closing of the polls, except the officially designated watchers, the inspectors, the clerks of election, and the City Clerk as Supervisor of Elections or his deputy. However, a City policeman may enter the polling place with permission from the City Clerk or a majority of the inspectors. Such restrictions shall not apply to commercial businesses or privately owned homes and property which are within three hundred (300) feet of the polling place. 
(Ord. No. 87-06, § 1, 5-6-1987) 
Sec. 2-27. - Candidates may not run for more than one (1) office of the City. 
    No candidate for public office of the City shall qualify for the office of Mayor and the office of City Commission at any one (1) election. 
(Ord. No. 88-01, § 1, 2-17-1988) 
Secs. 2-28-2-34. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ELECTION VIOLATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- State election code violations, F.S. ch. 104. 

Sec. 2-35. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division: 
    Employee of the City means any regular part-time or full-time employee of the City, including, but not limited to, policemen, firemen, clerical employees, water department employees, and others. 
    Officer of the City means any City official, including, but not limited to, the Mayor, City Commissioners, City Engineer, City Attorney, members of the Planning and Zoning Board, members of the water board, chief of police, fire chief, department heads, and others. 
    Election shall mean any State, County or municipal election, including, but not limited to, general elections, party primary elections, special elections, bond elections other than municipal bond elections of the City, Charter elections, initiative, referendum and recall elections, and other governmental elections. 
(Code 1965, § 7-4) 
Sec. 2-36. - City personnel using City equipment or employees for political purpose. 
    It shall be unlawful for any employee or officer of the City to use or make use of, directly or indirectly, any equipment, property, funds, facilities, supplies, services of City employees, or other items of value belonging to or in the custody or control of the City in any election for the furtherance of the candidacy of any political candidate, slate of candidates, political group, or proposition to be voted on in such election. 
(Code 1965, § 7-5) 
County Code reference- Political activity of county officers and employees restricted, MDCC § 2-52. 
Sec. 2-37. - City personnel permitting use of City equipment or employees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any employee or officer of the City to suffer, permit or allow, directly or indirectly, any person or group of persons to use or make use of, any equipment, property, funds, facilities, supplies, services of City employees, or other items of value belonging to or in the custody or control of the City, entrusted to or under the supervision or control of said officer or employee, in any election for the furtherance of the candidacy of any political candidate, slate of candidates, political group, or proposition to be voted on in such election. 
(Code 1965, § 7-6) 
Sec. 2-38. - Political use of City equipment or personnel by others. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person not an employee or officer of the City to use or make use of, directly or indirectly, any equipment, property, funds, facilities, supplies, services of City employees, or other items of value belonging to or in the custody or control of the City, in any election for the furtherance of the candidacy of any political candidate, slate of candidates, political group, or proposition to be voted on in such election. 
(Code 1965, § 7-7) 
Sec. 2-39. - City personnel coercing other City personnel. 
    It shall be unlawful for any employee or officer of the City to direct, require, command, threaten or coerce any other employee or officer of the City to use or make use of, directly or indirectly, any equipment, property, funds, facilities, supplies, services of City employees, or other items of value belonging to or in the custody or control of the City in any election for the furtherance of the candidacy of any political candidate, slate of candidates, political group, or proposition to be voted on in such election. 
(Code 1965, § 7-8) 
Sec. 2-40. - Posting, distributing political matter on City property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to post signs, placards, or other advertising matter or devices, in the furtherance of the candidacy of any political candidate, slate of candidates, political group, or proposition to be voted on in an election, on any real property or equipment belonging to or leased or rented by the City, including, but not limited to, the City Hall, any playgrounds or parks or parkways, or any City vehicles; and it shall be unlawful for any person to leave or deposit any handbills, literature or advertising material for the furtherance of the candidacy of any political candidate, slate of candidates, political group, or proposition to be voted on in such election, on or in any real estate, buildings or equipment belonging to or rented by the City excepting public streets and public sidewalks; provided however, that this section shall not apply to nonpartisan political rallies held on City property with permission of the City Commission in which all candidates, or persons in their behalf, are permitted to participate. 
(Code 1965, § 7-9) 
Cross reference- Littering generally, § 8-56 et seq.; posting notices on public structures, § 10-8. 
Sec. 2-41. - Expenditures for publicizing bond issues. 
    Where specifically authorized by the City Commission, reasonable sums may be expended to publicize issues involved in municipal bond elections of the City; provided however, that where requested by a dissenting Councilman, dissenting views shall be publicized in a like manner. 
(Code 1965, § 7-10) 
Secs. 2-42-2-51. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FINANCE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Finance and taxation generally, art. V. 
Cross reference- Taxation, Ch. 14. 
State Law reference- Municipal finance and taxation generally, F.S. § 166.201 et seq.; financial matters pertaining to political subdivisions, F.S. ch. 218. 

Sec. 2-52. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    Check means any written check, draft, money order or other negotiable instrument drawn upon any bank, savings and loan association, or other financial institution, including postal money orders and checks of the federal government or its agencies. 
    Depository of the City means any bank, savings and loan association or other financial institution officially designated by the City, its departments or agencies, for the deposit of funds of the City. 
    Employee means any full-time or part-time employee of the City, its agencies or departments. 
    Funds of the City means any money or checks collected for or on account of the City, its departments or agencies. 
    Officer means any elected or appointed officer, official, or department head of the City, its agencies or departments. 
(Code 1965, § 2-11) 
Sec. 2-53. - Duty to turn over City funds on receipt. 
    All officers and employees of the City who come into possession of any funds of the City by reason of the performance of their duties, or otherwise, shall as soon as practicable deliver such funds to the City Manager or department head designated by the Manager to receive such funds. 
(Code 1965, § 2-12) 
Sec. 2-54. - Funds to be deposited in City depository. 
    The City Manager or department head designated by him shall deposit all funds of the City in depositories of the City on the first banking day following collection of such funds; provided however, that this section shall not apply to reasonable petty cash funds or change funds necessary for daily operating procedures. 
(Code 1965, § 2-13) 
Sec. 2-55. - Cashing of checks prohibited; exception for City checks. 
    No official or employee shall at any time cash with cash funds of the City any check; nor shall any officer or employee accept in payment of any obligation to the City any check unless such check shall be for the exact amount of the obligation to the City; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to any check of the City properly issued and signed by duly authorized signatories and drawn upon an account of the City with a properly designated depository of the City. 
(Code 1965, § 2-14) 
Sec. 2-56. - Personal possession of City funds. 
    No official or employee of the City shall keep any funds of the City upon his person or carry same from City premises except for the purpose of delivering same to the City Manager or department head designated to receive such funds, or for the purpose of transporting such funds to a depository of the City for deposit therein. 
(Code 1965, § 2-15) 
Sec. 2-57. - Advances to officers and employees. 
    No officer or employee of the City shall borrow or obtain advances from funds of the City, including petty cash funds; provided, however, that prior to a regularly scheduled pay date, partial payments of salary or wages already earned to such date may be paid by check only upon written request of employees or officers; and provided further that vacation pay due any employee or officer shall be considered earned within the meaning of this provision at the commencement of the vacation period of such employee or officer. 
(Code 1965, § 2-16) 
Secs. 2-58-2-66. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PURCHASES AND CONTRACTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
County Code references- Joint purchases by county and municipalities exempted from competitive bid requirements, MDCC § 2-10.1; municipal sale or conveyance of real estate subject to county review and approval, § 2-11.2. 

Sec. 2-67. - County ordinance adopted. 
    County Ordinance 64-41 and 1. 9-15-84, entitled "Joint purchases by County and municipalities; exemption of municipality from competitive bid procedures," is hereby adopted. 
(Ord. No. 98-02, § 2, 6-17-1998) 
Sec. 2-68. - Procedure for purchases of $500.00 to $7,500.00. 
    Whenever the administrative department of the City desires to make a purchase of any equipment, supplies or material or to enter into any contract for services, labor and material, and the estimated purchase price or cost thereof is in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00), but does not exceed seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00), the City Manager shall request quotations of prices for such proposed purchase or contract prior to final purchase or entry into such contract from those contractors and suppliers who have requested in writing that they be allowed to bid on such contracts or purchases. 
(Code 1965, § 2-31; Ord. No. 389, § 1, 5-16-1979; Ord. No. 404, § 1, 11-5-1980; Ord. No. 98-02, § 1, 6-17-1998) 
Sec. 2-69. - Bids to be solicited for purchases in excess of $1,500.00; publication of notice. 
(a)  Whenever the administrative department of the City desires to make a purchase of any equipment, supplies or material or to enter into a contract for services, labor and material, the cost of which is estimated to be in excess of fifteen hundred dollars ($1,500.00), the Manager shall first establish or cause to be established specifications for the equipment, supplies or material or contract desired, and shall send out to a representative number of persons or firms dealing in such products, or contractors engaged in such work, as the case may be, copies of such specifications together with [a] request for sealed bids. Such request shall state the latest time that the bids will be accepted and the time and place of opening such sealed bids, and the time thereafter when the bids will be submitted to the City Commission. 
(b)  In addition to the above, the Manager shall cause to be published in the Dodge Report and in publications of the Builders Exchange, notice that the City is seeking sealed bids on the project described in the specifications. In the event the named publications are discontinued, the Manager shall cause notice, that the City is seeking sealed bids, to be published in available publications in circulation in the construction industry. 
(c)  Joint purchases by County and the City; exemption from competitive bid procedures. Notwithstanding the above, wherever by an arrangement of the provisions in the contract documents of the County for the purchases of commodities by competitive bidding procedures, it is provided that the same price for which such commodities are available to the County shall also, during the period of time provided therein, be available to the City which may desire to purchase such commodities at the County contract price; then and in such event, the purchase or purchases of such commodities under the provision of the County contract and at the County contract price shall be exempt from competitive bid requirements otherwise provided by this Code. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the above, the City Commission shall preserve the right to decide whether to require competitive bidding or avail itself of the provisions of the County, State or other approved GSA (Governmental) approved vendors/contracts for all purchases in excess of seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00). 
(Code 1965, § 2-32; Ord. No. 389, § 2, 5-16-1979; Ord. No. 404, § 2, 11-5-1980; Ord. No. 82-10, § 1, 10-6-1982; Ord. No. 98-02, § 3, 6-17-1998) 
Sec. 2-70. - Opening of bids. 
    All sealed bids shall be opened by the City Manager in the presence of the City Clerk at the City Hall during regular business hours at the time and place designated in the request for bids. The opening of bids may be attended by any bidder or agent of any bidder and by any other interested person. Bids received after the time set forth in the request for bids shall not be opened, but shall be marked by the City Clerk as having been received after the time for receiving of bids and shall be returned unopened to the bidder. Bids received on time shall be opened by the City Manager, and the City Clerk shall make a list of the bids setting forth the name and address of the bidder and the amount bid. 
(Code 1965, § 2-33) 
Sec. 2-71. - Tabulation of bids by Manager; action of Commission. 
    The City Manager shall make or cause to be made a tabulation of the bids in such form as to advise the City Commission of the pertinent details of such bids and whether or not each bid is regular and complete. As a part of such tabulation, the City Manager shall set forth the recommendations, if any, of the administration as to the acceptance of the bids or rejection thereof. Each Councilman shall be furnished a copy of the tabulation at the Commission meeting designated in the request for bids, at which meeting the Commission shall consider the bids and take such action as it deems appropriate. 
(Code 1965, § 2-34) 
Sec. 2-72. - Opening of bids other than by Manager and City Clerk. 
    The City Commission may direct that bids be opened at a Commission meeting rather than by the City Manager and City Clerk as provided above, and in such event the request for bids shall so provide. 
(Code 1965, § 2-35) 
Sec. 2-73. - Authority to reject all bids. 
    The Commission may reject any and all bids and all requests for bids should so state. 
(Code 1965, § 2-36) 
Sec. 2-74. - Waiver of requirement for bids. 
(a)  Whenever the administrative department is unable to secure three (3) competitive bids from prospective suppliers because of the peculiar nature of the equipment, supplies, material or insurance desired, or because the equipment, supplies or material are patented or manufactured by one company only, the City Commission may, by resolution setting forth the reasons, adopted at the time it receives bids, waive the requirement of three (3) competitive bids and proceed on the basis of the bid or bids received. 
(b)  In addition to the above, the City Commission, by resolution setting forth any other reasons, may by four-fifths ( 4/5 ) vote authorize the purchase by the City from prospective suppliers or contractors and waive the requirements and procedures provided in this article IV. 
(Code 1965, § 2-37; Ord. No. 94-02, § 1, 5-18-1994) 
Sec. 2-75. - Procedure for authorizing work by City forces. 
    Whenever the administration shall determine that any work or project may be done by City personnel, the requirement of bids may be waived by the Commission upon presentation of a certificate from the City Engineer that in his opinion the work may be done by City forces at a cost less than by contract; provided, however, that the requirement of sealed bids for equipment, supplies or material to be used in such project may not be waived, except as hereinabove provided. 
(Code 1965, § 2-38) 
Sec. 2-76. - Purchases in avoidance of requirements. 
    It is the intent of this article that purchases and contracts be at the lowest prices attainable considering the quality of the services contracted for and of the materials purchased, and it shall be a violation of this article to purchase materials or contract for services in quantities or units smaller or lesser than usual or smaller or lesser than proper purchasing procedures require in an effort to avoid obtaining requests for bids or quotations as required by this article. 
(Code 1965, § 2-39) 
Sec. 2-77. - Purchase order required. 
    All purchases made by the City, or any official thereof, shall have a purchase order and said order shall be signed by the City Manager or, when authorized by the City Manager, by the head of the department making the order. A copy of said purchase order shall be attached to the check vouchers before payment is made. 
(Code 1965, § 2-40) 
Sec. 2-78. - Requirements for contracts for public improvements. 
    Any contract for the construction, maintenance, repair, expansion or extension of a public improvement shall be in writing and shall be filed in the office of the City Clerk, and the said contract shall provide that the whole amount due under such contract shall not be paid until the work done thereunder shall have been inspected and accepted by the City Commission; and not less than five (5) percent, or such higher percentage as determined by the Commission, shall remain unpaid until acceptance of the work by the City Commission. 
(Laws of Fla. 1949, ch. 26301, art. I, § 22(b)) 
Sec. 2-79. - Violations. 
    Any person who shall violate any provisions of this article, or who shall solicit the violation thereof by any officer or employee, shall be guilty of a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1965, § 2-41) 
Sec. 2-80. - Time for submission of bids or proposals; time may be extended; plans. 
    In all requests by the City for bids or quotations, the proposed contractor or supplier shall submit his bid, quotations or proposal no later than thirty (30) days from the day the request is made. The City Commission may shorten such time period. The plans, specifications, and/or other details of the request for any bids shall be ready for inspection at the City Hall on the first date that requests for bids, quotations or proposals are advertised. 
(Ord. No. 86-05, § 1, 9-3-1986) 
Sec. 2-81. - Bid protest. 
(a)  Applicability; exemptions. 
(1)  This section shall govern any protest made by a participant in any competitive process utilized for selection of a person or other entity to construct any public improvement, to provide any supplies, materials or services (including professional or management services other than professional services whose acquisition procedure is governed by the Consultant's Competitive Negotiation Act, F.S. § 287.055 et seq.), or to lease any County property. 
(2)  The foregoing notwithstanding, the protest procedures contained in this section, shall not apply to contracts and purchases which the City Manager has the delegated authority to award and protests thereon shall be governed by procedures established by administrative order approved by the City Commission. 
(3)  A protest hereunder may not challenge the relative weight of the evaluation criteria or the formula specified for assigning points therefor contained in the bid, request for proposals (RFP) or request for qualifications (RFQ) specifications which have been approved by the Commission. 
(b)  Procedure. 
(1)  Responsiveness. Prior to this Commission or any committee thereof hearing any protests relating to a competitive bid, request for proposal or request for qualifications, the City Manager shall request the City Attorney to certify whether the bid or proposal in question is responsive. Upon receiving such request, the City Attorney shall, in consultation with the City Manager if necessary, determine whether the bid or proposal is responsive. This Commission and any committee thereof shall be bound by the determination of the City Attorney with regard to the issue of responsiveness. 
(2)  A written intent to protest shall be filed with the City Clerk and mailed to all participants in the competitive process and to the City Attorney within three (3) working days of the filing of the Manager's recommendation. For purposes of calculating this period, the day of filing of the City Manager's recommendation with the Clerk shall not be counted. Such written intent to protest shall state the particular grounds on which it is based and shall be accompanied by a filing fee. The protester shall then file all pertinent documents and supporting evidence with the City Clerk and mail copies to all participants in the competitive process and to the City Attorney within three (3) working days after the filing of a written intent to protest. No bid protest shall be accepted unless it complies with the requirements of this section. Notwithstanding the above, in the event that a public records request is made within the first three (3) days of the above-referenced period, a protester may utilize any public records obtained as evidence or additional grounds for protest, provided that: 
a.  The protester met all the deadlines set forth above; and 
b.  A supplementary filing is made with the City Clerk within 48 hours of receipt of the records responsive to the request. 
(3)  Protests filed in accordance herewith shall be referred to a Hearing Examiner. A Hearing Examiner shall be appointed not later than five (5) working days following the filing of a bid protest. The Hearing Examiner shall conduct a hearing in connection with the bid protest which shall be completed within ten (10) working days following his or her appointment. The Hearing Examiner shall, within five (5) working days of the hearing, file written findings and recommendations with the City Clerk and shall submit or mail a copy of same to all participants in the competitive process and to the City Attorney. The Hearing Examiner may extend the deadline for completion of the hearing upon written petition for good cause shown, but such extension shall not exceed an additional five working (5) days. The Hearing Examiner shall consider the written protest and supporting documents and evidence appended thereto, the City Manager's recommendation, and supporting documentation, and all evidence presented at the hearing. The Hearing Examiner may also require written summaries, proffers, affidavits and other documents the Hearing Examiner determines to be necessary in order to conclude the hearing and issue the report and recommendation within the time limits set forth in this section. The Hearing Examiner shall be entitled to rely on evidence of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs, whether or not such evidence would be admissible in a trial in the courts of Florida. 
(4)  The Hearing Examiner shall allow a maximum of two (2) hours for the protester's presentation of its protest and a maximum of two (2) hours for the City's response to each protest. In the event of multiple protests, the Hearing Examiner shall allocate the time as necessary to ensure that the hearing shall not exceed one (1) day. 
(5)  The City Manager shall prepare a resolution, to be approved by this Commission, amending and setting forth a fee schedule for filing of bid protests. The fee shall be in the amount necessary to defray the cost of the bid protest process established in this section. The resolution also establish the amount of compensation to be paid the Hearing Examiner, and shall provide for a prorated reduction of that compensation in the event the Hearing Examiner fails to abide by the time limitations set forth in this section. 
(6)  Hearing Examiners shall be selected from a panel of retired judges who have served ten (10) or more years as Circuit Judges in the Eleventh Judicial Circuit in and for Miami-Dade County, Florida. Hearing Examiners may be selected from alternate sources where the City Attorney recommends in writing that such action is necessary to achieve greater diversity. 
(7)  The Hearing Examiner's findings and recommendation shall be presented to the Commission together with the recommendation of the City Manager. Notice thereof shall be mailed to all participants in the competitive process at least five (5) days in advance of such presentation. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section or any prior resolution, the matter shall be heard by the Commission without prior presentation to any committee. The matter shall be resolved on the basis of the record before the Hearing Examiner and no evidence or issue which was not presented or raised at such hearing shall be considered. Presentations to the Commission by any participant in the competitive process or their representatives if authorized by subsection (b)(8) of this section shall be limited to ten (10) minutes per side. The foregoing time limitation shall be inclusive of all speakers addressing the Commission on behalf of each side. 
(8)  If the Hearing Examiner concurs in the City Manager's recommendation, a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of the Commission members present shall be required to take other than the recommended action; provided, however, a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote shall not be required to reject all bids. If the Hearing Examiner concurs in the City Manager's recommendation, the Commission shall not allow presentations by any participants in the competitive process or their representatives at the time the matter is presented to the Commission. If the Hearing Examiner does not concur in the City Manager's recommendation, the participants in the competitive process and their representatives may make presentations to the Commission and the Commission shall decide the matter by majority vote. 
(9)  The City Manager may provide different time periods for the taking of any actions required hereunder when the interest of the City so requires by including appropriate language in the specifications or addenda thereto. 
(10)  The foregoing notwithstanding, the Commission, by two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of the members present, may waive the requirements of this section and entertain a bid protest, upon written recommendation of the City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 2, 11-4-2009) 
Secs. 2-82-2-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PENSIONS AND RETIREMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-90. - Election to participate in State retirement system. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the City to conduct a referendum on the 26th day of September, 1973, among eligible officers and employees for the purpose of permitting said officers and employees to elect to participate in the Florida Retirement System as authorized by Chapter 121. Florida Statutes, and amendments thereto, whereupon all those officers and employees, except those excluded by law, electing by affirmative vote in said referendum to participate in the Florida Retirement System, shall become members of the Florida Retirement System effective on the first day of February, 1974, and shall participate thereafter during their employment, and those officers and employees who elect not to participate in the Florida Retirement System shall sign an appropriate rejection ballot which shall be attached to and become a part of the agreement with the State for providing coverage under the Florida Retirement System. Those officers and employees electing not to participate in the Florida Retirement System who were members of a local retirement system on the date of the referendum, shall be permitted to continue their membership in the local retirement system for as long as their employment continues. 
    All officers and employees hired on and after the date of the referendum shall be compulsory members of the Florida Retirement System as of the effective date of participation in the Florida Retirement System so stated herein. 
(Ord. No. 338, § 1, 9-19-1973; Ord. No. 347, § 1, 12-19-1973) 
Sec. 2-91. - Ordinances providing for local system continued for nonparticipants in State system. 
    Ordinance Number 292, providing a pension plan for City employees, as from time to time amended, shall continue in force and effect for those employees covered by it and who have elected not to participate in the Florida Retirement System; and nothing contained in this Code or in the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect such ordinance or plan. 
Sec. 2-92. - Withholdings for State system authorized. 
    Withholding from salaries, wages or other compensation of employees and officials for the purpose provided in section 2-90 hereof, are hereby authorized to be made, and shall be made in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable State laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the administrator designated by said laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Ord. No. 338, § 3, 9-19-1973) 
Sec. 2-93. - Appropriations required for State system. 
    There shall be appropriated from available funds, derived from ad valorem taxes and general revenues, such amounts and at such times as may be required to pay promptly the contributions and assessments required of the City, which shall be paid over to the lawfully designated Administrator of the Florida Retirement System at the times and in the manner provided by law and regulation. 
(Ord. No. 338, § 4, 9-19-1973) 
Sec. 2-94. - Records, reports required for State system. 
    The City shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable State laws or regulations, and shall adhere to all laws and regulations relating to the Florida Retirement System. 
(Ord. No. 338, § 5, 9-19-1973) 
Sec. 2-95. - State system adopted. 
    The City does hereby adopt the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges, and other conditions thereunto appertaining, of the Florida Retirement System, for and on behalf of all officers and employees of its departments and agencies to be covered under the agreement. 
(Ord. No. 338, § 6, 9-19-1973) 
Sec. 2-96. - Custodian, withholding and reporting agent for State system. 
    The City Manager is hereby designated the custodian of all sums withheld from the compensation of officers and employees as authorized herein and of the appropriate funds for the employer's contributions as provided in section 2-93 hereof. Also, the City Manager is hereby designated the withholding and reporting agent and charged with the duty of maintaining records for the purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 338, § 7, 9-19-1973) 
Secs. 2-97-2-106. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SOCIAL SECURITY 

Sec. 2-107. - Extended to City employees and officials. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the City to extend, effective as of January 1, 1953, to the employees and officials thereof, not excluding by law, and whether employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function, the benefits of the system of Old Age and Survivor's Insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto, including Public Law 734 of 81st Congress, and by Chapter 650, Florida Statutes; and to cover by such plan all services which constitute employment as defined in Section 650.02, Florida Statutes, performed in the employ of the City by employees thereof. In pursuance of said policy, and for that purpose, the City shall take such action as may be required by applicable State or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1965, § 17-1) 
Sec. 2-108. - Agreement with State authorized. 
    The Mayor, or other chief executive officer of the City, was authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the Chairman of the Florida Industrial Commission as the State Agency for the State of Florida, or his authorized representative, for the purpose of extending the benefits provided by said system of Old Age and Survivor's Insurance to the employees and officials of this City as provided in section 2-107, which agreement shall provide for such methods of administration of the plan by said City as are found by the State agency to be necessary for the proper and efficient administration thereof, and shall be effective with respect to services in employment covered by such agreement performed after the first day of January, 1953. 
(Code 1965, § 17-2) 
Editor's note- The Division of Retirement of the State Department of Administration is the successor to the State Industrial Commission as state agency under F.S. § 650.02(4). 
Sec. 2-109. - Withholdings authorized. 
    Withholding from salaries, wages, or other compensation of employees and officials for the purpose provided in section 2-107 are hereby authorized to be made, and shall be made, in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable State or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the State agency designated by said laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Code 1965, § 17-3) 
Sec. 2-110. - Appropriations for City contributions. 
    There shall be appropriated from available funds, derived from the general funds of the City such amounts, at such times, as may be required to pay promptly the contributions required of the City as employer by applicable State or federal laws or regulations, which shall be paid over to the lawfully designated State agency at the times and in the manner provided by law and regulation. 
(Code 1965, § 17-4) 
Sec. 2-111. - Records, reports required. 
    The City shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable State or federal laws or regulations, and shall adhere to the rules and regulations of the State agency for the enforcement of said laws and regulations. 
(Code 1965, § 17-5) 
Sec. 2-112. - Federal law adopted. 
    The City does hereby adopt the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges, and other conditions thereunto appertaining, of Title II of the Social Security Act as amended by Public Law No. 734, 81st Congress, and thereafter, for and on behalf of all the officers and employees thereof and of its departments and agencies, excepting any official or employee who occupies any position, office, or employment not authorized to be covered by applicable State or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1965, § 17-6) 
Secs. 2-113-2-122. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - RESERVED[6] 

Footnotes:
