(Code 1965, § 6-20) 
Sec. 5-5. - Schedules of permit fees. 
(a)  Permits issued by County. The Building Official shall charge and collect for building, electrical, gas, mechanical, plumbing, demolition, building moving and other permits for work performed in the City of West Miami the same rate charged by Miami Dade Building Department for work performed in the incorporated area of Miami Dade County. 
(b)  Permits issued by the City. Fees for issuance of the following City permits shall be as follows: 
Painting less than $1,000.00 $20.00 Painting by owner or a commercial company and valued more than $1,000.00 $50.00 or 1% of total value of work, whichever is greater Concrete slab $100.00 Concrete driveway (ribbons or single car) $50.00 Driveway-Circular (concrete or paved) $100.00 Driveway-Straight (concrete or paved) $30.00 Utility shed (requires inspection) $90.00 Sign permit (requiring building permit) $75.00  Temporary sign or banner $35.00 Fence permit $50.00 Roof repair-Less than 200 square feet (2 squares) $100.00 Roof permit-Additions, less than 200 square feet (2 squares) $150.00 Miscellaneous home improvements, interior $20.00 Miscellaneous home improvements, exterior $50.00 Sidewalk repair $50.00 COPIES OF DEPARTMENTAL RECORDS: Plan reproductions from microfilm - per sheet $6.25 Reproduced records - per page $0.19 Double sided copies - per page $0.25 Certified copies - per page $1.25 Notary public service - per page $1.25 Research and ordering plans per address or permit number $18.75 Open permit search per address or folio (additionally a fee of $1.25 per page will be charged for certification or records). $43.75  
(Code 1965, § 6-20; Ord. No. 378, § 1, 3-1-1978; Ord. No. 89-09, § 1, 11-1-1989; Ord. No. 2010-03, § 1, 7-7-2010; Ord. No. 2016-04 , § 2, 11-16-2016) 
Sec. 5-6. - Additional service charge for starting work without permit. 
    In the event that any work for which a permit is required by this Code is started or proceeded with prior to the obtaining of said permit by the duly authorized person, there shall be imposed, charged and collected a service charge of three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) for permits charged under County rates provided in section 5-5(a) of this chapter or a service charge of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for permits charged under City rates provided under section 5-5(b) of this chapter. Payment of such additional service charge shall not relieve any person from paying the regular permit fee provided in section 5-5 of this chapter, nor from fully complying with the requirements of the applicable code in the execution of the work nor from any penalty prescribed therein. 
(Code 1965, § 6-21; Ord. No. 378, § 2, 3-1-1978; Ord. No. 87-02, § 2, 3-4-1987; Ord. No. 89-09, § 2, 11-1-1989) 
Sec. 5-7. - Cash bond to guarantee completion of work and repair or replacement of sidewalks, curbs, drains, trees, parkways, grass and other public property. 
(a)  Required. Whenever any person shall apply for a building permit, roofing permit, mechanical permit, gas permit, electrical permit, and any other applicable permit required for construction, alterations, replacements, repairs, additions or any other work requiring a permit by this chapter or the South Florida Building Code, such person shall be required to pay the City, in addition to the applicable permit fee, the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) as a bond to guarantee completion and final inspection of the work described in the building permit, cleaning of the construction and surrounding public area and the repair and/or replacement of all sidewalks, curbs, drains, parkways, grass, trees and other public property damaged during the construction period either by contractor, owner, or other person. 
(b)  Refund or additional permit fee. Upon completion of the work and proof to the City Manager of the final inspection of the work described in the applicable building permit and upon completion of all cleaning of the construction and surrounding public areas, and upon the completion of the repair or replacement of all sidewalks, curbs, drains, parkways, grass, trees and other public property damaged during the construction, then and in these events, the bond shall be refunded to the applicant. In the event the applicant shall not furnish to the City Manager proof of final inspection within nine (9) months from the date the permit was issued, or in the event that the applicant has not cleaned or has not kept clean at all times the construction and surrounding public areas, or in the event applicant has not repaired or replaced any and all damaged public property or has not maintained same in good and safe condition, then and in these events, the bond shall become the property of the City and shall be paid over to the general fund as an additional permit fee. For good cause shown, the City Manager may extend the time for completion of the work described in the applicable permit for a period within twelve (12) months from the date the permit was issued. 
(c)  Other remedies, administration costs and reasonable Attorney fees. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the City from exercising all of its rights and remedies provided by law or equity to recover all its damages or otherwise enforce this section, including but not limited to administration costs and reasonable Attorney fees. 
(Ord. No. 374, §§ 1, 2, 8-3-1977; Ord. No. 386, § 1, 1- -1979; Ord. No. 87-11, § 1, 8-5-1987) 
Sec. 5-8. - Alarm system permits; renewal; fees. 
(a)  Initial requirements. Whenever any person desires to install an alarm system or to maintain an existing alarm system on any premises, an application for permit shall be submitted to the City together with an application and permit fee in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00). Installation of a new alarm system or the continuation of an existing alarm system shall be prohibited until the issuance by the City of an alarm system permit to the applicant. 
(b)  Annual renewal permit; term; fees. All alarm system permits issued pursuant to subsection (a) hereof shall expire on September 30. Thereafter, an annual renewal permit shall be obtained on October 1 of each year. An annual permit fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) shall be paid at the time of renewal. 
(c)  False alarm fees. All alarm systems are required to be inspected and tested once a year or after a false alarm occurrence within seventy-two (72) hours to determine the cause of the false alarm. A third false alarm shall require a thirty-five-dollar ($35.00) fee for service. 
(Ord. No. 89-09, § 3, 11-1-1989; Ord. No. 2010-03, § 2, 7-7-2010) 
Secs. 5-9-5-17. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 5-18. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    Indoor swimming pool means a swimming pool which is enclosed within a dwelling house and shall include swimming pools which are partially enclosed in a dwelling house and screened on the top and remaining sides. 
    Nonclimbable fence means a wire fence having mesh or openings not exceeding two (2) inches, or wooden picket fences with openings between pickets not exceeding four (4) inches, or brick, block or masonry walls without openings therein except for gates. 
    Outdoor swimming pools means a swimming pool not meeting the definition of an indoor swimming pool. 
    Raised swimming pool means any pool which is completely above the level of the ground and whose sides are vertical and at right angles to the ground level and not terraced. 
    Self-closing gates means gates or doors equipped with a spring device which automatically close same when not in use. 
    Self-locking gates means gates or doors which are equipped with latches or locks which latch or lock close automatically when such door or gate is closed. 
    Shielded latches means latches or locks which are equipped with shields to prevent accidental opening of same. 
    Swimming pool or pool means any container of water used for play or swimming purposes having a depth of more than twenty-four (24) inches and a water surface area of more than one hundred (100) square feet. The term shall include pools set upon the surface of the ground or partially or entirely below the ground level and shall include pools constructed or made of concrete, cement, plastic materials, or any other materials, and shall include immovable, movable or portable pools. 
(Code 1965, § 21-1) 
Sec. 5-19. - Protection of outdoor pools from entry. 
    Every outdoor swimming pool shall be completely surrounded by a nonclimbable fence not less than four (4) feet in height; provided, however, that a dwelling house or accessory building may constitute a part of such enclosure. All gates or doors less than four (4) feet in width opening through such enclosure shall be self-closing and self-locking gates equipped with shielded latches. All gates more than four (4) feet wide, including driveway gates, shall be kept locked with a padlock or key-type lock when not in actual use. 
(Code 1965, § 21-2) 
Sec. 5-20. - Protection of indoor pools from entry. 
    Every doorway, passageway or opening in the walls or screened portion of an indoor pool shall have a door or gate as provided herein. Doors or gates to indoor swimming pools through which the swimming pool is visible to persons outside thereof, shall be self-locking and self-closing and shall have all handles installed at least five (5) feet above the floor level. 
(Code 1965, § 21-3) 
Sec. 5-21. - Protection of raised pools from entry. 
    Raised swimming pools shall be enclosed so as to meet the requirements of outdoor swimming pools or indoor swimming pools depending on the location of such raised swimming pool; provided, however, that in the case of raised swimming pools with vertical sides of at least thirty (30) inches above the ground at all points on the sides thereof, no fence, wall or other enclosure shall be required, provided that the only access to the pool is by means of a portable removable ladder, in which event such ladder must be removed and taken from such pool when such pool is not in use and such ladder must be stored under lock and key when not in use. No such pool shall be left unattended with ladder attached or in such position to provide access thereto. 
(Code 1965, § 21-4) 
Sec. 5-22. - Responsibility for compliance. 
    No person in possession of land within the City, either as owner, purchaser, lessee, tenant, or licensee, upon which is situated a swimming pool as herein defined shall fail to provide and maintain such fence, wall or enclosure, and gates and doors as herein provided. 
(Code 1965, § 21-5) 
Secs. 5-23-5-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RESERVED[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-08, § 2, adopted Sept. 2, 2015, repealed Art. III, §§ 5-36-5-38, which pertained to the Plans Review Board and derived from Ord. No. 83-02, §§ 1-3, adopted April 6, 1983. 

Secs. 5-36-5-54. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MAINTENANCE OF COMMERCIAL PROPERTY[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 83-05, § 1, adopted June 15, 1983, amended the Code by addition of provisions designated by the city as a new Chapter 5B; for purposes of classification, the editor has redesignated said provisions as Art. IV, §§ 5-55, 5-56, at his discretion. Subsequently, Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, adopted May 4, 1988, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as §§ 5-57-5-63, dealing with requirements for outdoor lighting of public and private parking lots. In the further interests of classification, said sections have been designated as Div. 2 of Art. IV, with §§ 5-55 and 5-56 being redesignated as Div. 1 of Art. IV, at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Municipal code enforcement, § 2-136 et seq.; fire prevention and safety code, § 7-1; garbage and trash, Ch. 8; duty to keep sidewalk in front of premises free of litter, § 8-60; buildings in deteriorated state declared a public nuisance, remedy, §§ 10-21(c), 10-22 et seq.; planning and development, Ch. 12; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 13. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-55. - Prevention of deterioration or blight. 
(a)  The exterior of all commercial property shall be maintained so as to prevent deterioration or blight from inadequate maintenance. 
(b)  [The following minimum standards shall be observed in the maintenance of commercial property:] 
(1)  All exterior building surfaces shall be free of chipping, pitting, cracking, discoloration, peeling or fading; 
(2)  All exterior signs shall be in good repair and free of chipping, pitting, cracking, peeling, fading or discoloration. Lighted signs shall have all lights working; 
(3)  Doors and windows shall be free of cracked or discolored glass or corroded frames; 
(4)  All awnings shall be without tears or holes and be free of dirt, discoloration, fading or cracking. Any lettering or painted surface on awnings shall conform to subsection (b)(2) above. All hardware, supports and poles shall be straight, free of rust, and in good condition; 
(5)  If any property is vacant for more than fifteen (15) days, all glass surfaces visible to the public shall be clean and screened from the inside with a clean, neat-appearing opaque material and shall be kept in such condition until the property is occupied; 
(6)  All sidewalk overhangs attached to commercial buildings shall be structurally sound and free of rust, discoloration, peeling, chipping, cracking, fading, sagging or dirt. All lettering or signage on overhangs shall conform to the requirements provided in subsection (b)(2) above; 
(7)  Henceforth, no air conditioner or heating or cooling device shall be installed so as to be visible from the street, or so as to discharge condensation onto the sidewalk or street. 
(Ord. No. 83-05, § 1(A), 6-15-1983) 
Sec. 5-56. - Compliance; penalty for violation. 
(a)  The City Manager is empowered and authorized to require compliance with this article within thirty (30) days of written notice to violators. Failure to comply shall be punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and/or sixty (60) days in jail. Each day of noncompliance shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  In the alternative, violators may be cited to the City Code Enforcement Board as provided in chapter 2 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 83-05, § 1(B), (C), 6-15-1983) 
DIVISION 2. - OUTDOOR LIGHTING OF PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PARKING LOTS 

Sec. 5-57. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this division, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section: 
    Footcandle (fc), is the unit of illumination when the foot is the unit of length; the illumination on a surface one (1) square foot in area on which there is a uniformly distributed flux of one (1) lumen. It equals one (1) lumen per square foot. 
    Levels of lighting is where levels of lighting are specified in terms of footcandles; this shall mean that upon completion of the lighting installation, the initial reading of the lighting level on the parking area taken during nighttime hours shall conform to the specified footcandle level. 
    Motor vehicle is every vehicle which is self-propelled, which shall include motorcycles having a seat or saddle for the user or the rider and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. A motor vehicle shall also include a motor scooter with a motor which produces not to exceed five (5) brake horsepower, including every bicycle with motor attached. 
    Parking garage is a building or structure designed and maintained for the parking of motor vehicles. 
    Private parking lot is an area or space used for the parking of motor vehicles when no fee is charged. 
    Public parking lot is any area or space used for the parking of motor vehicles when a fee is charged for such service. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 5-4-1988) 
Sec. 5-58. - Applicability of article. 
    The provisions of this division shall apply to both private and public parking lots for all nonresidential properties and for those residential properties containing three (3) or more dwelling or living units. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 5-4-1988) 
Sec. 5-59. - Compliance with article requirements. 
    All public and private parking lots presently in existence and those to be developed in the future shall be equipped with lighting installed in accordance with the standards contained in this division. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 5-4-1988) 
Sec. 5-60. - Date for compliance by existing parking lots. 
    Existing parking lots, both public and private, shall conform with the provisions of this division within one hundred twenty (120) days from effective date hereof. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 5-4-1988) 
Sec. 5-61. - Design standards. 
(a)  The current edition of the IES Lighting Handbook, published by the Illuminating Engineers Society, 345 East 47th Street, New York, New York, 10017, is hereby adopted by reference. This standard shall be used as a guide for the design and testing of parking lot lighting, and the standards contained therein shall apply unless standards developed and adopted by this division, or subsequent amendments, are more severe, in which case the more restrictive standards shall apply. 
(b)  Public and private parking lots to which this division is applicable located in all zoning districts shall be provided with adequate light fixtures so that an average level of illumination of one (1) footcandle of light will be provided and that at no point in the parking area shall there be less than one-half (1/2) footcandle of light. 
(c)  Overspill of lighting onto adjacent properties or structures shall not exceed one-third ( 1/3 ) footcandle (vertical) and one-third ( 1/3 ) footcandle (horizontal) illumination. 
(d)  Prior to the time a parking lot lighting system is approved, an appropriate test report shall be submitted to the City Manager or his designee, showing that the lot is in conformance with this division or, in lieu of a test report, notification shall be supplied to the City Manager or his designee by the owner, occupant or agent of the subject premises, indicating the type and number of luminaries, height of fixtures, location, wattage and aiming angle of existing light sources. 
(e)  All parking garages shall be provided within lighting fixtures which will provide an average level of illumination of two (2) footcandles of lighting in the parking areas but at no point shall there be less than one (1) footcandle of light. 
(f)  All private or public parking lot lighting shall be controlled by automatic timing devices or by light-sensitive switches which will ensure that the lighting turns on at dusk and off at dawn. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 5-4-1988) 
Sec. 5-62. - Conditions. 
(a)  Detailed plans and specifications shall be submitted to the City showing the design, location, height, type and strength of lights, intensity of illumination of area, shades, deflectors, beam directions and any other necessary information relating thereto requested by the City. 
(b)  The proposed lighting shall be so located, oriented, adjusted and shielded that the lighting will be deflected, shaded and focused away from adjacent residential neighborhood and residential use property and will not create a traffic hazard on adjacent streets by reason of glare or the like. 
(c)  The City Manager or his designee shall review the said detail plans and specifications and shall determine whether the lighting or lighting system meets the criteria. 
(d)  After approval of said plans and specifications by the City Manager or his designee, the applicant for [a] building permit shall obtain the permit and shall have construction completed according to the approved plans and specifications within thirty (30) days or show good cause to the City Manager or his designee, why the work was not completed within such time. Upon such showing of good cause, the City Manager or his designee may extend the time for completion. 
(e)  In the event that the lighting system when completed and illuminated at night does not conform to the provision of this division, the City Manager or his designee shall require that the lights or lighting system be corrected or modified to conform hereto. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 5-4-1988) 
Sec. 5-63. - Penalties for violations. 
    For violation of this division, the private or public parking lot owner or operator, whether person, corporation or association, shall be fined or imprisoned in accordance with section 1-9 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 88-03, § 1, 5-4-1988) 
Secs. 5-64-5-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - EXCAVATIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 85-05, § 1, adopted July 17, 1985, amended the Code by the addition of §§ 5-8-5-17, which provisions have been redesignated and included herein as Art. V, §§ 5-71-5-81 at the discretion of the editor for purposes of classification and reference. 
Cross reference- Schedule of building permit fees, § 5-5; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 13; sidewalk construction and repair, § 13-14 et seq. 

Sec. 5-71. - Permit for excavations generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to do work on or cut into, dig up, or excavate for the purpose of laying sewers, water mains, underground wires, or gas pipes, or for setting poles, or any other purpose whatsoever, any of the streets, parks, parkways, sidewalks, alleys, or easements in the City of West Miami, Florida, without first securing from the director of public works a permit to make said excavations and do said work. 
(Ord. No. 85-05, § 1, 7-17-1986) 
Sec. 5-72. - Authority to issue permit. 
    The director of public works shall be authorized upon proper application being made to issue to any individual, firm, or corporation, a permit to cut into, dig, or make excavations in any of the streets, parks, parkways, sidewalks, alleys or easements in the City of West Miami for the purpose of laying sewers, water mains, underground wires, gas pipes, or setting poles, or for any other purpose, providing that the applicant complies with the following regulations: 
(a)  At the time of issuance of permit an applicant shall submit an accurate site plan showing by two (2) dimensional drawing, the actual size and location of any existing structures, pipes conduits, wires, cables, poles, lines and any other utility facilities relating to gas, fuel, electric, telephone, television, water, waste and other utility services certified as to its accuracy, within seven (7) days of issuance of the permit, by the utility furnishing, maintaining, owning or operating such utility service and the applicant. 
(b)  Upon completion of the work, the permitted, shall submit an accurate site plan showing by two dimensional drawings, the actual size and location of the existing structure, piping, etc., as modified or resulting from the said excavations and work certified as to its accuracy at the time of such completion of the work by the utility entity owning, operating, maintaining, and furnishing such utility services and the applicant. 
(c)  All utilities must be installed a minimum of thirty-six (36) inches below the existing or proposed surface, whichever applies. 
(d)  Inspection of installation is required before backfill can begin. 
(e)  Backfilling of trenches, sub-base compaction, road base and the installation of new asphaltic concrete surfaces shall be in accordance with the latest addition of the Dade County Public Works Department Manual and any subsequent revisions thereof. 
(Ord. No. 85-05, § 1, 7-17-1986) 
Sec. 5-73. - Contents of permit. 
    Such permit, when issued by the director of public works, shall provide and specify the purposes for which said performance of work or excavations in the streets, parks, sidewalks, alleys or easements are made, the period of time during which the streets, parks, parkways, sidewalks, alleys, or easements may remain dug up or cut into, and the period of time allowed for the completion of the work for which the excavations are made. 
(Ord. No. 85-05, § 1, 7-17-1986) 
Sec. 5-74. - Completion of work by City; assessment of permittee. 
    At the expiration of the time granted in said permit for the completion of the work, or any extension thereof, the City of West Miami shall have the right to complete said work and restore and repair said parks, parkways, streets, sidewalks, alleys, or easements which may be damaged and to charge the person, firm, or corporation to whom the permit is granted with the cost of the repair and/or competition of the said work, plus ten (10) percent thereof to cover overhead expense and administration. 
(Ord. No. 85-05, § 1, 7-17-1986) 
Sec. 5-75. - Replacements. 
    All replacements of streets, parks, parkways, sidewalks, alleys, or easements which are made as the result of such excavations shall comply with the latest edition of the Date County Public Works Department Manual and any subsequent revisions thereof, and shall further comply with the following regulations with regard to resurfacing: 
(a)  The entire pavement in a block shall be slurry sealed if: 
(1)  The length of the excavation is more than sixty (60) feet or ten (10) percent of the length of the block measured centerline of intersection to centerline of intersection. 
(2)  The excavation extends in whole or in part into more than one (1) lane of traffic or parking. 
(b)  Slurry seal will not be required if an excavation is made at right angles to the centerline of a street and the width of excavation is less than five (5) feet. 
    The width of the excavation shall be the width of asphalt surface required to patch the excavation, unless otherwise provided for in the latest edition of the Dade County Public Works Department Manual and any subsequent revisions thereof. 
(Ord. No. 85-05, § 1, 7-17-1986) 
Sec. 5-76. - Protective devices. 
    All excavations made in the streets, parks, parkways, sidewalks, alleys or easements shall be properly protected by guard rails, ropes, or barricades, and after sundown red lights, flashers, lanterns or flambeaus, shall be placed around said excavations in a manner which shall properly protect the public from the dangers incident to said excavations. 
(Ord. No. 85-05, § 1, 7-17-1986) 
Sec. 5-77. - Permit fees; schedule. 
    Any person, firm or corporation desiring to do work on or to make excavations in the streets, parks, parkways, sidewalks, alleys, or easements shall secure a permit thereof from the director of public works. The fee for such permit shall be as follows: 
    Asphalt Paving: 
Zero to 50 sq. yds. ..... $25.00 
Additional over 50 sq. yds., per 50 sq. yds. ..... 15.00 
    Barricades: 
Zero to 50 ft. ..... 25.00 
Additional over 50 ft. per 100 ft. or fraction thereof ..... 15.00 
    Covered Walkways: 
Zero to 50 ft. ..... 50.00 
Additional over 50 ft. per 50 ft., or fraction thereof ..... 25.00 
    Encroachments: 
Two and one half (21/2) times employee's hourly rate to include overhead. If applicable, Consultant's fee will be added. $100.00 minimum. 
    Excavations for Underground Construction: 
Zero to 250 sq. ft. ..... $50.00 
Next 250 sq. ft. ..... 25.00 
Additional over 500 sq. ft. per 250 sq. ft. or fraction thereof ..... 10.00 
    Landscaping: 
Zero to 250 sq. ft. ..... 100.00 
Additional over 250 sq. ft. per 250 sq. ft. or fraction thereof ..... 25.00 
    Sealing or Resurfacing Existing Asphalt Paving: 
Zero to 100 sq. yds. ..... 25.00 
Additional over 100 sq. yds. per 100 sq. yds. ..... 15.00 
    Fire Hydrant Installation and Fire Protection Sprinkler System, Approved by National Board of Fire Underwriters and/or Dade County Fire Department -No charge by City. 
(Ord. No. 85-05, § 1, 7-17-1986) 
Sec. 5-78. - Liability insurance by permittee. 
    Before any permit shall be issued, the applicant shall furnish to the City of West Miami, evidence that applicant is carrying public liability insurance with bodily injury liability limits of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00), each person; one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) each occurrence and property damage liability limits of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) each occurrence or bodily injury liability and/or property damage liability, single limit of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) each occurrence with endorsement on each such policy, making the City of West Miami, Florida an additional insured thereon. 
(Ord. No. 85-05, § 1, 7-17-1986) 
Sec. 5-79. - Performance deposit or bond. 
    No permit shall be issued to any applicant to perform, work on, or cut into the public right-of-way until a cash deposit has been made in a sufficient amount, but not less than one hundred twenty-five (125) percent of the cost of the work to be done on the public right-of-way, as determined by the City of West Miami, to insure the performance by the applicant of the work permitted, or in the alternative, a good and sufficient performance bond by a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Florida, in the foregoing amount to be approved by the City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 85-05, § 1, 7-17-1986) 
Sec. 5-80. - Tests required; reports. 
    Any and all tests that shall be required by the director of public works for the purposes as set forth in this article shall be made at either the contractor or owner's expense by a recognized testing laboratory. Copies of all test reports shall be furnished to the Department of Public Works. In addition, telephonic reports shall be made to the Department of Public Works of any previous day's tests. 
(Ord. No. 85-05, § 1, 7-17-1986) 
Sec. 5-81. - Penalties and violations. 
    Any person, firm or corporation performing work on or making excavations in the streets, parks, parkways, sidewalks, alleys or easements in the City of West Miami, Florida in violation of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in any sum not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. Each day's violation of any of the terms of this article shall be deemed and considered to be a separate and distinct violation of the terms of this article and hereby is declared specifically punishable as such. 
(Ord. No. 85-05, § 1, 7-17-1986) 
ARTICLE VI. - SELF-SERVICE LAUNDRIES 

Sec. 5-82. - Intention of article. 
    The intention of this article is to protect the safety of children who may be injured or killed as the result of entering into laundry machines and equipment contained in unattended self-service laundries or laundry rooms upon the premises of single- and multi-family residences. 
(Ord. No. 87-09, § 1, 6-17-1987) 
Sec. 5-83. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
(1)  Self-service laundries or laundry rooms shall mean any structure or location upon the premises of single- and multi-family residences containing laundry machinery, equipment or facilities available for washing and drying clothes or other material or both, and which is open and available for egress from the exterior of the structure or location where there is no adult attendant in charge of operation of said laundry machines, equipment or facilities. 
(2)  Self-closing doors or gates means doors or gates equipped with a spring device which automatically closes when not in use. 
(3)  Self-locking doors or gates means doors or gates which close automatically and have latches or locks which latch or lock automatically when said door or gate is closed. 
(4)  Shielded latches means latches or locks which are equipped with shields to prevent accidental opening of same. 
(5)  Nonpenetrable material means material which cannot be broken into, pierced, or penetrated without great force. 
(Ord. No. 87-09, § 1, 6-17-1987) 
Sec. 5-84. - Protection of exterior entranceways and openings to self-service laundries. 
(a)  Every exterior doorway, passageway or entranceway to self-service laundries or laundry rooms shall have self-closing doors or gates and self-locking doors or gates which shall contain or be equipped with: 
(1)  Exterior key locks which only can be unlocked from the interior without a key; 
(2)  Shielded latches; 
(3)  Handles installed at least five (5) feet above the bottom edge of the door or gate; and 
(4)  Nonpenetrable material. 
(b)  All other exterior openings, including but not limited to windows and other open spaces of self-service laundries or laundry rooms, shall have nonpenetrable metal screenings or coverings. 
(c)  All out-of-door laundry machinery, equipment or facilities shall be enclosed with a wall or metal fence in addition to the other requirements of subsections (a) and (b) of section 5-84 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 87-09, § 1, 6-17-1987) 
Sec. 5-85. - Applicability and exclusions. 
(a)  This article shall apply to all single- and multi-family residences and premises in the City now existing or hereafter constructed, reconstructed, or altered. 
(b)  This article shall not apply to any self-service laundries or laundry rooms where there are at least one (1) adult attendant in charge of the laundry premises during all hours of operations and are securely closed during nonoperational hours. 
(Ord. No. 87-09, § 1, 6-17-1987) 
Secs. 5-86-5-88. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - BUILDING TYPE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 87-20, § 2, adopted Nov. 18, 1987, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as Ch. 5, Art. VI, §§ 5-82 and 5-83. Inasmuch as there are already provisions so designated, Ord. No. 87-20 has been included as Ch. 5, Art. VII, §§ 5-89 and 5-90 at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 5-89. - Building construction. 
(a)  All buildings shall be constructed as specified in the Metropolitan Dade County Building Code and the South Florida Building Code, as amended from time to time. 
(b)  Where food frame construction is utilized for the principal building or additions thereto, such type of building shall be constructed as follows: 
(1)  Minimum of two (2) inches by four (4) inches wood studs sixteen (16) inches on center; 
(2)  Minimum of one-half (1/2) inch of exterior plywood on exterior wall side of wood studs protected at their ends by not less than the required fire-resistive thickness of such wall; 
(3)  Minimum of three-fourths (3/4) inches of solid plastic insulation meeting the minimum requirements of the South Florida Building Code; and 
(4)  Metal lath covered with a minimum of three-quarters (3/4) inches of exterior Portland cement plaster on each side of exterior wall. Said cement shall be mixed with fire-resistive fiber of not less than the maximum requirements of said code. Lath to be attached with 6d common nails seven (7) inches on center driven to one (1) inch of minimum penetration and bent over. Plaster mix one-half (1/2) scratch coat and one-third ( 1/3 ) brown coat, by weight, cement to sand or as provided in the South Florida Building Code as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 87-20, § 2, 11-18-1987) 
Sec. 5-90. - Approval of plans and specifications; public works director; duties and responsibilities. 
    The public works director shall examine all plans and specifications of building construction and shall only approve plans and specifications which do provide and meet the requirements of subsection 5-89(b), (1), (2), (3) and (4), and meet the requirements of the zoning laws of the City of West Miami, Florida. 
(Ord. No. 87-20, § 2, 11-18-1987) 
ARTICLE VIII. - LICENSES FOR HANDICAP FACILITIES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 87-21, § 1, adopted Dec. 2, 1987, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as Ch. 5, Art. VI, §§ 5-82 and 5-85. Inasmuch as there are already provisions so designated, Ord. No. 87-21 has been included as Ch. 5, Art. VIII, §§ 5-91 and 5-94 at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Licenses and business regulations, Ch. 9. 

Sec. 5-91. - Definition. 
    Handicapped person means any person residing in a single-family unit in "R-1", "R-2" and "A" zoned districts, who has a physical or mental impairment which substantially limits one (1) or more major life activities or who has a record of having, or is regarded as having, such physical or mental impairment. 
(Ord. No. 87-21, § 1, 12-2-1987) 
Sec. 5-92. - Application for license. 
    Applicants for a license under this section must file with the City Manager a sworn application in writing on a form to be furnished by the City Manager which shall give substantially the following information: 
(1)  Name of applicant; 
(2)  Address (legal and local); 
(3)  A description of the nature of applicant's handicap together with certification by applicant's physician attached on a form to be provided by the City Manager, certifying the exact nature of applicant's disability; 
(4)  A description of the handicap facilities intended to be built by applicant which are not permitted by any ordinance of the City of West Miami unless a variance is granted; 
(5)  The personal hardship for applicant presently existing requiring the need for the handicap facilities relating to the following: 
a.  Special equipment for mobility and special facilities to use such equipment; 
b.  Ramps, sidewalks, concrete slabs or other facilities for purposes of egress and ingress on the property; 
c.  Any other facilities, equipment, structure or any other need of applicant for the enjoyment and use of the real property and improvements thereon. 
(Ord. No. 87-21, § 1, 12-2-1987) 
Sec. 5-93. - Sufficiency; hearing; appeal; license; term. 
(a)  On receipt of an application for license under this article, the City Manager shall determine whether the application is complete and sufficient as to form and if so, the City Manager shall file same with the City Clerk. No filing fee shall be required of applicant. 
(b)  The City Clerk shall thereupon give notice to the applicant of the date of the hearing before the Planning and Zoning Board (the "Board"), and post a copy thereof in the City Hall, which hearing shall be had within thirty (30) days of the filing of the application with the City Clerk. The City Clerk shall transmit said application to the Board of the City of West Miami. 
    All hearings will be conducted by the said Board pursuant to rules and regulations adopted by the Board and will be open to the public. Within ten (10) days after the hearing, if the Board finds that the applicant has shown personal hardship requiring the need for the handicap facilities, then the Board shall render its decision of approval of the application; or if its findings are to the contrary, then the Board shall render its decision of disapproval. 
(c)  The decision of the Board shall become final twenty (20) days after the date of mailing of the decision by certified mail to applicant, unless there is an appeal filed within said period. 
(d)  An appeal to the City Commission (the "Council") from any adverse decision may be filed by an interested party within said twenty (20) days, by filing a notice of appeal with the City Clerk. No appeal fee is required. Within twenty (20) days after the filing of the appeal, at a regular meeting, the Commission shall hear arguments solely on the basis of the evidence produced before the Board. The Commission shall render its decision either upholding or overruling the decision. A four-fifths ( 4/5 ) majority of the entire Commission shall be required to overrule the decision of the Board on all applications under this article. 
(e)  Upon final approval of the application and upon issuance of a certificate of occupancy, the City Manager shall issue a license authorizing the use of said facilities by the applicant for the then fiscal year ending September 30. No license fee shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 87-21, § 1, 12-2-1987) 
Sec. 5-94. - Renewal of license; termination or suspension; removal of facilities by owner of property. 
(a)  The City Manager shall issue renewal licenses each year upon application filed on or before October 1, the form of which shall be furnished by the City Manager, where the applicant shall state under oath that no change of circumstances have occurred since final approval of the original application upon which the license was issued, and that the need for such handicap facilities still exists. 
(b)  In the event that application for renewal of the license is not made in a timely fashion each year, or in the event that the need for such handicap facilities is not shown in the renewal application, then and in that event, the handicapped person or the owner of the real property upon which such handicap facilities improvements were made shall within thirty (30) days remove said handicap facilities, upon written notice from the City. 
(Ord. No. 87-21, § 1, 12-2-1987) 
Secs. 5-95-5-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - ZONING INSPECTIONS AND SERVICES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 90-8, § 1, adopted July 11, 1990, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as Ch. 5, Art. VII, §§ 5-86-5-91. Inasmuch as there are already provisions so designated, Ord. No. 90-8 has been included as Ch. 5, Art. IX, §§ 5-101-5-106 at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 5-101. - Zoning certificate of use required; annual inspection of buildings and premises; issuance of certificates; renewals; nontransferable. 
(a)  No new buildings or premises and/or part thereof shall be occupied or used and no existing building or premises shall continue to be used until a zoning certificate of use shall have been issued by the Building and Zoning Department. Certificates of use shall not be issued initially or annually until the building and premises have been inspected and found to comply with all ordinances of the City of West Miami that may be applicable to the particular building or premises. 
(b)  Buildings designed or proposed to be used as office buildings shall require one (1) zoning certificate of use for each separate office tenant and one (1) [zoning certificate of use] for each commercial activity contained therein acquired by the tenant or occupant. Each separate office tenant in existing office buildings shall obtain a certificate of use on the effective date of this section. 
(c)  Apartment buildings, hotels, and other multiple-residential occupancies containing two (2) or more units and occupied only by residential tenants shall require one (1) zoning certificate of use per building acquired by the property owner. 
(d)  Apartment buildings, hotels, and other residential occupancies containing two (2) or more units also containing commercial tenants shall require additional zoning certificates of use for each commercial activity contained therein acquired by the commercial tenant or occupant. 
(e)  Commercial buildings containing more than one (1) tenant shall require a zoning certificate of use for each tenant acquired by each tenant or occupant. 
(f)  Uses within a commercial building or portion of a commercial building occupied by a single tenant which are incidental to the principal use will not require a separate zoning certificate of use. 
(g)  Where individual zoning certificates of use are required for multiple-tenant buildings, a zoning certificate of use shall be obtained and shall be charged for as established by this article. 
(h)  Upon the issuance of a zoning certificate of use for a building and/or premises, an annual inspection schedule will be established and annual inspections will be conducted thereafter. 
(i)  Renewal [of a] zoning certificate of use will be required, on October 1st of each year and each existing use and/or premises shall be inspected annually to determine that it complies with the provisions of all municipal ordinances that may apply to the particular building or premises. 
(j)  The owner, tenant or occupant will be notified of any deficiencies found and the time that the deficiencies shall be corrected. Appropriate reinspections may be made to determine that the deficiencies have been corrected. 
(k)  Only those provisions of municipal ordinances which were in effect at the time a particular occupancy or use was established will be applicable unless otherwise provided in any subsequent amendments, modifications or additions thereto. 
(l)  Should there be observed by a City inspector during the course of an onsite inspection that there appears to be a violation of any applicable federal, State and County statutes, codes, ordinances, laws, rules and regulations that may be applicable to the particular building or premises, the inspector shall report such violation to the appropriate governmental authority or agency for enforcement action. 
(m)  No certificate of use or removal thereof issued may be transferred. 
(n)  When a tenant or occupant fails to timely apply for and obtain a zoning certificate of use, or renewal thereof, the property owner shall become responsible for obtaining such zoning certificate of use, or renewal thereof for and on behalf of said tenant or occupant and payment of required fee. 
(Ord. No. 89-08, § 1, 11-1-1989; Ord. No. 90-8, § 1, 7-11-1990) 
Sec. 5-102. - Inspection and service fees for certificate of use and annual renewals. 
(a)  All persons applying for a certificate of use required under section 5-101 shall pay the following inspection and service fees which shall be valid through the following September 30th, and shall pay on the first day of October of each year thereafter the following renewal fees (all measurements of floor area are interior dimensions): 
(1)  Apartment building, including duplex: 
1-12 dwelling units ..... $50.00 
13-50 dwelling units ..... 100.00 
51 dwelling units or more ..... 100.00 
Plus, per unit over 50 ..... 2.00 
(2)  Hotel, motel, rooming house: 
2-12 rental sleeping units ..... 200.00 
13-50 rental sleeping units ..... 400.00 
51 rental sleeping units or more ..... 400.00 
Plus, per unit over 50 ..... 2.00 
(3)  Retail and/or wholesale sales and services, including public service utilities and storage: 
Not exceeding 500 square feet of floor area ..... 30.00 
Exceeding 500 square feet but less than 2,500 square feet of floor area ..... 50.00 
Exceeding 2,500 square feet but less than 5,000 square feet of floor area ..... 70.00 
Exceeding 5,000 square feet but less than 15,000 square feet of floor area ..... 100.00 
Exceeding 15,000 square feet but less than 25,000 square feet of floor area ..... 110.00 
Exceeding 25,000 square feet but less than 50,000 square feet of floor area ..... 200.00 
Exceeding 50,000 square feet of floor area ..... 400.00 
(4)  Office building used for general office use for services only without merchandise or storage on the premises: 
Less than 500 square feet of floor area ..... 30.00 
Exceeding 500 square feet but less than 2,500 square feet of floor area ..... 40.00

(13)  Miscellaneous. All uses of buildings or premises not previously covered by this section shall be assessed a fee as provided in (3) of this section. 
(14)  Fees imposed in cases of prior occupations. In the event that any building or premises is used or occupied prior to issuance of a zoning certificate of use or renewal thereof, there shall be imposed, charged and collected an additional fee of double the amount required under this section of this article. 
(Ord. No. 89-08, § 1, 11-1-1989; Ord. No. 90-8, § 1, 7-11-1990; Ord. No. 91-10, § 1, 12-4-1991; Ord. No. 93-04, §§ 1, 2, 10-27-1993) 
Sec. 5-103. - Exceptions. 
    The owner residing in a detached single-family residence or residing in a duplex unit shall not be required to comply with section 5-87 of this article, but annual inspections and other provisions of this article shall be applicable. However, any rental unit owner or tenant shall comply with section 5-102 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 89-08, § 1, 11-1-1989; Ord. No. 90-8, § 1, 7-11-1990) 
Sec. 5-104. - Fees for accessory use certificates. 
(a)  All persons desiring to use a residential building structure located within a residential zone permitting a home occupation shall apply to the Building and Zoning Department for an accessory use certificate, which shall be granted upon payment of an annual fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to the City and when issued shall be valid through the following September 30. In instances where a person sixty-five (65) years of age or over is engaged in the conduct of home occupations, there shall be no required payment of an accessory fee in conjunction with the issuance of an accessory use certificate or the subsequent renewal of such certificate. All renewals of accessory use certificates shall be made on or before October 1 of each calendar year. 
(b)  In the event that any building or premises is used or occupied prior to issuance of an accessory use certificate or renewal thereof, there shall be imposed, charged and collected an additional fee of double the amount required under this section of this article. 
(Ord. No. 89-08, § 1, 11-1-1989; Ord. No. 90-8, § 1, 7-11-1990; Ord. No. 93-04, § 3, 10-27-1993) 
Sec. 5-105. - Zoning inspections, fees. 
(a)  The City of West Miami will provide, upon request of the owner or owner's agent, an onsite inspection of properties within the City of West Miami, by the Building and Zoning Department, to ascertain whether zoning violations openly exist on the real property. 
(b)  The zoning inspection fee to be paid prior to each such inspection for each lot shall be one hundred sixty dollars ($160.00). 
(c)  A report on the results of each such inspection will be issued to the owner or owner's agent and shall only constitute prima facie evidence of compliance/noncompliance with the zoning ordinance and shall not be conclusive proof of compliance/noncompliance with said ordinance. 
(d)  Should a zoning violation be observed by a City zoning inspector during the course of an on-site inspection, the property owner will be summoned to appear before the Code Enforcement Board of the City of West Miami. 
(Ord. No. 89-08, § 1, 11-1-1989; Ord. No. 90-8, § 1, 7-11-1990; Ord. No. 93-04, § 4, 10-27-1993) 
Sec. 5-106. - Fee for inspections and examinations of plans for compliance with the provisions of the City of West Miami Zoning Ordinance. 
(a)  There is hereby established the following fee per square foot of total land area encompassed in the project at the time the application is made for the construction of a new building, change of use of building, or an addition to an existing building, for the purpose of examination of the plans and site development and subsequent inspections of the building site prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy and subsequent thereto to assure original and continued compliance with the provisions of the City zoning ordinance: 
Single-family and duplexes (owner-occupied) ..... $0.007 
All other uses ..... 0.01 
(b)  This fee shall be in addition to the building permit fee. 
(Ord. No. 89-08, § 1, 11-1-1989; Ord. No. 90-8, § 1, 7-11-1990; Ord. No. 93-04, § 4, 10-27-1993) 
Sec. 5-107. - Development impact fees. 
(a)  Intent. This section is intended to require that new development help address the need for capital facility capacity needed to accommodate the demand generated by new development. New development shares in this burden by paying a proportionate share of the reasonably anticipated average costs of public facilities needed to accommodate the demand for additional facilities created by new development as well as by complying with other appropriate development regulations and approval conditions. This section shall not be construed to authorize imposition of impact fees for public facility needs attributable to existing development. The development impact fees imposed pursuant to this section are based upon the data and calculation methodology incorporated in the "Impact Fee Report for the City of West Miami, Florida" by TischlerBise, Fiscal, Economic and Planning Consultants, dated May 30, 2007 (hereinafter "technical report"). 
(b)  Authority. In the creation of the impact fees, the Commission is exercising its Charter home rule powers and its local authority, including police powers, pursuant to article VII, sections 1(f), 1(g) and 2(b) of the Florida Constitution; the Municipal Home Rule Powers Act, F.S. ch. 166, as amended; and F.S. § 163.3161 et seq., as amended. The aforementioned provisions authorize and require the City to provide and finance public facilities; to provide for the health, safety and general welfare of the City; to coordinate the provision of adequate public facilities with land development; and to implement its Comprehensive Plan. Furthermore, the Local Government Comprehensive Planning and Land Development Regulation Act, F.S. § 163.3202(3), encourages the use of innovative land development regulations, including impact fees. The provisions of this section shall not be construed to limit the scope of the City's power necessary to accomplish these purposes. 
(c)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Applicant means the property owner, or duly designated agent of the property owner, of land on which a building plan approval pursuant to section 5-90 of the City Code is requested and impact fees are due pursuant to this section, or shall mean the property owner, or duly designated agent of the property owner, of land identified in a credit agreement pursuant to subsection (j)(4) of this section where such property owner or agent is responsible for the provision of system improvements. 
    Appropriation means funds identified in the CIP with the legal authority to expend such funds up to a certain dollar amount. 
    Building plan approval means the approval of the Director of Planning and Zoning pursuant to section 5-90 of the City Code, subsequent to site plan approval by the City Commission under a special use permit for planned development, required for new construction, remodeling, redevelopment and additions pursuant to the City Code, as amended. If no building plan approval is required for the construction or occupation of a structure then building plan approval shall be deemed to include any permit or other form of final City approval for the construction, change of use or occupancy of a structure, including but not limited to the conversion of hotel, motel or other lodging, with or without cooking facilities, to condominium or other residential use. The term "building plan approval," as used in this section, shall be deemed to include a mobile home installation permit issued pursuant to the City building code or any equivalent permit or approval. 
    Capital improvements program (CIP) means the five-year schedule of capital improvements adopted by the City annually as part of the City budget process. 
    Capital improvement projects means all projects for which funds are appropriated in the CIP. Capital improvement projects, including, but not limited to, capital equipment, land, facilities and site improvements, that are funded in whole or in part with Impact Fee funds must have a minimum total cost of $10,000.00 and have a minimum useful life of five (5) years. 
    City Commission or Commission means the City Commission of West Miami, Florida. 
    Collecting agency means the City department or official authorized to issue building plan approval. 
    Development has the meaning given it in F.S. § 380.04, as may be amended from time to time, subject to exclusions contained in this section. 
    Demand unit means the unit of public facility demand associated with various land uses and types of new development as identified in the technical report and used to calculate the impact fees listed for each type of new development in the impact fee schedules in subsection (g) of this section. 
    Dwelling unit means a room or interconnected rooms, containing sleeping and sanitary facilities and one (1) kitchen provided for the exclusive use of a single household. The term "dwelling unit," as used in this section, shall be deemed to include mobile home and manufactured home dwellings. 
    General government system improvement means system improvements that add capacity to the City's administrative office space, capital equipment, vehicle fleets, and other capital expenditures for the general governmental functions of the City. 
    Governmental uses means buildings or facilities owned and operated by the United States of America or any agency thereof, a sovereign State or nation, the State of Florida or any agency thereof, a County, a special district, a school district, a municipal corporation, or a charter school organized and approved as a public school under F.S. § 228.056. 
    Gross floor area (GFA) means the total square footage of a building measured in feet from the exterior faces of exterior walls or other exterior boundaries of the building, excluding parking areas within the interior of the building. If a site contains multiple buildings, the gross floor area shall be computed separately for each building. The definition of gross floor area in the ITE Trip Generation Manual shall be used to resolve any questions regarding calculation of gross floor area. 
    Impact fee means a monetary exaction imposed prior to building plan approval and calculated based upon a new development's proportionate share of the average cost of capital improvements needed to address the additional capital facility capacity and equipment needed to accommodate the demand for public facilities created by new development. 
    ITE Trip Generation Manual means the report entitled "Trip Generation" (Seventh Edition, 2003) of the Institute of Transportation Engineers, and any official updates thereto, as approved and accepted by the City. 
    Multi-family residential development means residential development consisting of a structure containing one (1) attached dwelling unit or two (2) or more dwelling units. 
    New development means the carrying out of any building activity or the making of any material change in the use of a structure or land that requires building plan approval, as defined in this section, and which generates demand for capital facilities over and above the previously existing documented use or development of the structure or land. New development shall include changes in the use of a structure, for example the conversion of a structure from lodging (with or without cooking facilities) to residential use, whether or not physical changes are required to an existing structure. New development excludes governmental uses as herein defined. New development includes those building activities that have obtained site plan approval prior to the effective date of the impact fee schedules in this section. 
    Nonresidential development means all new development other than residential development and governmental uses as herein defined. Nonresidential development includes, but is not limited to, industrial, manufacturing, warehousing, mini-warehousing, lodging (with or without cooking facilities), schools and daycare, hospital, nursing home, general office, medical-dental office, business park, and commercial uses, and includes those uses specified in the ITE Trip Generation Manual under Land Use Code Series 100, 300, 400, 500, 600, 700, 800, and 900. 
    Parks system improvement means land, capital improvements, capital facilities and capital equipment that add capacity to the City park system, including parks with City-wide service areas and associated improvements as well as open space and associated improvements. 
    Police system improvement means land, capital improvements, capital facilities, and capital equipment that add capacity to the City's police system. 
    Project costs means amounts spent or authorized to be spent in connection with the acquisition, planning, legal, fiscal, economic, engineering, administrative services, financing, construction, equipping, development, and other costs associated with a public facility project. 
    Residential development means development of a structure or structures solely dedicated to the housing of a person or persons to live, cook and/or sleep within on a permanent basis, as either owner, renter or lessee provided, however, that adult congregate living facilities, retirement homes, nursing homes and other structures operated by a social service organization to provide residential care to children, the aged, the destitute and the physically, mentally and/or emotionally challenged shall be considered to be nonresidential development as defined herein. 
    Service charge means a charge that, as established by resolution of the Commission, shall be collected in addition to the applicable impact fee amount for expenses associated with the establishment, amendment, periodic update and administration of the impact fee system and ordinance. The service charge shall be reviewed as part of the annual review provided for in subsection (h) of this section or at such other times as deemed necessary based upon information submitted by the City Manager. The service charge is in addition to the impact fee and shall be payable at the time of building plan approval. The service charge shall be for the purpose of defraying expenses of creating and maintaining the impact fee system, including but not limited to costs associated with consultants, administrative staff, equipment, software, and other expenses incurred in establishing, administering, updating, managing and maintaining the Impact Fee system. 
    Single-family detached residential development means residential development consisting of a detached structure containing only one (1) dwelling unit per structure and intended for occupancy by a single household. 
    System improvements means capital improvements projects, as defined in this section, that provide additional capacity needed to accommodate new development and that serve multiple development projects, multiple neighborhoods or the entire City. System improvements may include, but are not limited to, land, facilities, site improvements, furnishings, capital equipment, and vehicles. System improvements shall not include property, capital facilities or capital equipment needed solely to serve a specific development. System improvements shall not include replacement, rehabilitation, operations or maintenance of land, facilities or equipment. 
    System improvement cost means amounts spent or appropriated in connection with the planning, financing, acquisition, construction and/or development of a system improvement, including, without limitation, the costs of land acquisition and development, surveying, site testing, construction, design, engineering, construction management and inspection, permitting, legal services, financial services and administrative costs. Ancillary improvements directly related to a system improvement, including but not limited to, parking, drainage improvements, landscaping, and capital equipment and furnishings may be considered part of the cost of a system improvement. System improvement costs shall not include costs related to operations, maintenance, rehabilitation or replacement of capital facilities or equipment. 
    Technical report means the report titled "Impact Fee Report for the City of West Miami" by TischlerBise, Fiscal, Economic and Planning Consultants, dated May 30, 2007. The technical report is adopted by reference and is incorporated herein as if set forth in its entirety. The technical report shall be available from the City Clerk. 
(d)  Applicability. 
(1)  This section shall be uniformly applicable to all new development, and the appropriate impact fee, and applicable service charge, shall be collected prior to building plan approval, except where building plan approval is issued for additions, remodeling, rehabilitation or other improvements to an existing structure or reconstruction of a damaged or destroyed structure, whether voluntary or involuntary, which result in no net increase in the number of residential dwelling units for residential structures or no net increase greater than one thousand (1,000) gross square feet for a nonresidential structure. The applicant has the burden of submitting documentation to the City proving the type and amount of previously existing development or use for determination by the City of the net increase for calculation of impact fees due. No refund of impact fees previously paid shall be provided for any decrease in the amount or type of development except as provided under subsection (j)(3) of this section. 
(2)  Where this section becomes applicable due to: 
a.  Additions, remodeling, rehabilitation or other improvements to an existing structure; 
b.  Reconstruction of a damaged or destroyed structure, whether voluntary or involuntary; 
c.  A change in the use of a structure or land that increases the demand for public facilities; 
d.  An increase in the number of residential dwelling units for a residential structure; or 
e.  An increase in the gross square footage of a nonresidential structure; 
the amount of the impact fees shall be based solely upon the net increase in the demand for public facilities based on a comparison of the impact fees calculated for the prior development/use to the impact fees calculated for the proposed development/use. The applicant has the burden of submitting satisfactory documentation to the City proving the type and amount of previously existing use/development for use by the City in determining the net increase for calculation of impact fees due. 
(3)  Notwithstanding subsections (2) or (3) above, this section shall not be applicable to building plan approvals issued by the City prior to 8:00 a.m. on September 19, 2007, when the applicant proceeds to issuance of certificate of occupancy without invalidation, suspension or abandonment of the corresponding building plan approval. 
(e)  Establishment of impact fee districts. In furtherance of the implementation of this section, the Commission hereby establishes the following benefit districts for the identified impact fees: 
(1)  Police Impact Fee Benefit District, which boundary is identical with the boundary of the City, as may be adjusted from time to time; 
(2)  General Government Impact Fee Benefit District, which boundary is identical with the boundary of the City, as may be adjusted from time to time; and 
(3)  Park Impact Fee Benefit District, which boundary is identical with the boundary of the City, as may be adjusted from time to time. 
(f)  Imposition of impact fees. No building plan approval shall be issued for new development in the City unless the applicant therefor has paid the applicable impact fees imposed by this section, and applicable service charge if established by resolution of the Commission. Any building plan approval issued for new development without payment by the applicant and collection by the City of the applicable impact fees and service charge if applicable, shall be null and void. 
(g)  Calculation of impact fee and impact fee schedules. 
(1)  The City shall calculate the impact fees due under this section by: 
a.  Verifying the number and type of demand units which are proposed to be constructed as shown on the building plans by land use type, using dwelling units for residential uses, gross square footage of floor area for nonresidential uses, and specified demand units for certain types of nonresidential uses; and 
b.  Multiplying the number of demand units for each land use type represented by the proposed development by each applicable impact fee pursuant to subsection (g)(2) of this section. The total impact fees due shall be the sum of the amounts calculated for each applicable impact fee in subsection (g)(2) of this section. 
c.  If the land use applicable to a development is not listed in the fee schedules in subsection (g)(2) of this section, the fees for the most appropriate land use in the fee schedules, based on the characteristics of the proposed development as determined by the City Manager, shall be imposed. If the applicant believes that none of the land uses in the fee schedules are appropriate, the applicant shall be responsible for timely filing a petition under subsection (j) of this section. The land use characteristics and descriptions in the ITE Trip Generation Manual shall be used to determine the most appropriate land use. When multiple types of development are included in a building, the impact fees due shall be calculated for each type of development and included in the total impact fees due. When multiple buildings are included on building plans, the impact fees shall be calculated individually for each building and included in the total impact fees due. 
d.  Where a final petition determination has been made by the City Manager or a final decision issued by the Commission after a timely appeal, the impact fees due shall be calculated based on the petition determination or Commission decision.

(h)  Administration of impact fees. 
(1)  Collection of impact fee and service charge. Impact fees calculated and imposed pursuant to this section shall be collected by the collecting agency prior to issuance of building plan approval. If adopted by resolution of the Commission, the service charge shall be collected by the collecting agency at the same time as collection of the impact fees. 
(2)  Accounting and reporting of impact fee collections and expenditures. Impact fees shall be transferred from the collecting agency to the City Finance Department which shall be responsible for placement of such funds into the appropriate separate accounts by type of impact fee and applicable benefit district. The service charge, if adopted by resolution of the Commission, shall be placed in a separate account identified for management of the impact fee system and disbursed as set forth in this section. The City Finance Department shall maintain and keep adequate financial records for each such account which shall show the source and disbursement of all revenues, which shall account for all moneys received, including revenue by building plan approval, and which shall document and ensure that the disbursement of funds from each account shall be used solely and exclusively in accordance with provisions of this section. For purposes of petitions for refunds under subsection (j)(3) of this section, the expenditure and appropriation of impact fees shall be deemed to occur in the same sequential order as the collection of impact fees; in other words, the first fee in shall be the first fee out. 
(3)  Trust funds established. 
a.  There is hereby established a separate impact fee trust fund account for each of the following impact fees: police, general government and parks. If existing impact fee accounts comply with the requirements of this section, then such accounts may be deemed to be the impact fee trust fund accounts established herein. 
b.  Funds withdrawn from these accounts must be used solely in accordance with the provisions of subsection (h)(4) of this section. The disbursal of such funds shall be in accordance with the capital improvement program of the City. 
c.  Any funds on deposit not immediately necessary for expenditure shall be invested in interest-bearing accounts. Interest earned by each account shall be credited to that account and shall be used solely for the purposes specified for funds of such account. The funds of these accounts shall not be commingled with other funds or revenues of the City. 
(4)  Use of funds collected. Impact fees collected pursuant to this section shall be expended only for the type of system improvements for which the impact fee was imposed and only within the impact fee benefit district where the impact fee was collected. Impact fees shall be expended only on system improvements needed to accommodate the demand generated by new development. Impact fees shall not be expended to eliminate any deficiencies in facilities, land or equipment related to existing development or that may result from adoption of an increased level of service. The funds collected by reason of this section shall be used exclusively for the purpose of undertaking system improvements or for financing directly, or as a pledge against bonds, revenue certificates and other obligations of indebtedness, the costs of system improvements. 
(5)  Annual review and modification. Beginning with adoption of the fiscal year 2009-2010 budget, the City shall annually, no later than 120 days after the annual capital budget and capital improvements program adoption process, review the impact fee ordinance procedures, assumptions, formulas, benefit district designations, and fee calculations, and issue an annual report. The annual report shall be distributed to the Commission by the City Manager. The annual report should, at a minimum, include information by individual benefit district and facility type on account balances, annual collections, annual expenditures, and system improvement projects funded in whole or in part with impact fees. The annual report should present any recommendations related to the impact fee system, including but not limited to, the need for any updates to the impact fee calculations, district boundaries, and ordinance. In reviewing the impact fee system, the City may consider: development occurring in the prior year, construction of proposed public facilities, changing facility needs, inflation and other economic factors, revised cost estimates for public facilities, land and/or improvements, changes in the availability of other funding sources applicable to impact-fee-related capital improvements, and any other factors as may be relevant. The data in the annual report may be organized based on the City's fiscal year or calendar year. The annual report shall review the amount of service charges collected and the costs associated with the creation, administration, management and updating of the impact fee system and shall provide recommendations on any changes to the amount of the service charge. The annual report shall specifically analyze the need to incorporate new local data to comply with the requirement in F.S. § 163.31801, that the fees be based on the most recent and localized data. Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the Commission's authority to amend this section at any time. 
(6)  Optional annual impact fee increase. The City may, as part of the annual report or at any other time, calculate updated impact fee schedules using appropriate construction cost inflation rates in a nationally recognized publication such as the Engineering News Record (ENR) for the applicable time period. Such annual impact fee updates shall not require issuance of a new technical report. In order for impact fees updated under this subsection to be effective, the updated impact fee schedules shall be adopted by the Commission as an amendment to this ordinance and shall comply with applicable provisions of Florida Statutes, including the notice requirements in F.S. § 163.31801. 
(7)  Triennial review and modification. The City shall conduct a complete review of the impact fees every three (3) years to determine if changes in costs, facility needs, development patterns, demographics, and any other relevant factors indicate a need to update the impact fee calculations, data, methodology or other components of the impact fee system. The triennial report issued based on this review shall be distributed to the Commission by the City Manager. The triennial report may be used to fulfill the annual report requirement for that year. The City shall endeavor to adopt any changes and updates to the impact fee system, including updated fee calculations, within a year of completion of the triennial report. 
(i)  Service charges. Service charges may be established at the option of the Commission. If adopted by resolution of the Commission, the service charges shall be collected from each applicant and shall be distributed as appropriate for impact fee administration, for financial administration, and for costs related to the establishment, amendment and annual review/update of the impact fee ordinance and methodology. The service charge may also be used to defray expenses related to petitions, appeals and/or legal challenges to the impact fee system. The service charge, if adopted, shall be set based upon a review of incurred and anticipated costs to create, administer, update and manage the impact fee system and shall not exceed actual costs to the City. 
(j)  Administrative petitions for impact fee determinations, refunds and credits. 
(1)  Petition process. 
a.  Petitions for an impact fee determination refund of impact fees and/or credit against impact fees shall be submitted using the petition process, requirements and time limits provided herein. All petition requests shall be accompanied by a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
b.  All petitions shall be submitted to the City Manager for processing and preparation of a staff report and recommendations by the appropriate staff on the petition. The final determination on the petition shall be issued by the City Manager. The staff report and recommendations shall be forwarded to the City Manager no later than sixty (60) days after filing of a complete petition. The City Manager shall, no later than ninety (90) days after filing of the complete petition, issue a written determination on the petition, with the reasoning for the determination, and, if needed, direct the appropriate City staff to take the actions necessary to implement the determination. 
c.  The City Manager, or authorized representative, is authorized to determine whether a petition is complete and whether additional data or supporting statements by an appropriate professional are needed for evaluation of the petition. Determination of the completeness of a petition is solely at the judgment of the City. If the City Manager, or authorized representative, determines that the petition is not complete, a written statement identifying insufficiencies of the petition shall be provided to the petitioner within thirty (30) days of initial filing of the petition. The date of such written determination of insufficiency shall toll the time limits established in this section until submittal of a complete petition. 
d.  Upon written agreement by the City Manager and the petitioner, the time limits in this section may be waived for any reason, including, but not limited to, the submittal of additional data and supporting statements by the petitioner. 
e.  Except as otherwise provided in this subsection, the filing of a petition shall stay action by the City on the building plan approval and any other City action related to the development. No building plan approval or other City action shall be issued for development for which a petition has been filed unless the total impact fees due, as determined by the City and including any applicable service charge, have been paid in full or a sufficient bond or letter of credit satisfactory to the City Attorney has been filed with the City.
