    All fees provided for by this article shall be paid within the calendar month in which billed and if not paid within such calendar month shall thereupon be deemed delinquent and shall remain delinquent until paid in full together with any penalties as hereinafter provided. Fees paid at any time during the calendar month following the month of billing shall be increased by a penalty of fifty cents ($0.50); fees paid at any time during the second calendar month following the billing month shall be increased by a penalty of one dollar ($1.00); and fees paid in any calendar month thereafter shall be increased by an amount equal to fifty cents ($0.50) times the number of calendar months, or portions thereof, following the billing month. 
(Code 1965, § 9-25) 
Cross reference- Lien for city service charges, § 2-9. 
Sec. 8-29. - Annual fee for waste collection and disposal. 
(a)  The Sanitation Department is an Enterprise Fund to be included in the City budget titled "Sanitation Enterprise Fund". 
(b)  Effective October 1 st , 2011 there shall be an annual fee of three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) assessed upon all residential living units within the City of West Miami, as defined in section 8-1. The annual fee shall be collected quarterly in the amount of eighty-seven dollars and fifty cents ($87.50) due and collectible as defined below: 
$87.50 - 1st billing installment - October 15 th , 2011 1st payment due no later than - November 15 th , 2011 $87.50 - 2nd billing installment - January 15 th , 2012 2nd payment due no later than - February 15 th , 2012 $87.50 - 3rd billing installment - April 15 th , 2012 3rd payment due no later than - May 15 th , 2012 $87.50 4th billing installment - July 15 th , 2012 4th payment due no later than - August 15 th , 2012  
(Ord. No. 95-01, § II, 3-20-1995; Ord. No. 96-05, § II, 11-6-1996; Ord. No. 98-04, § I, 10-21-1998; Ord. No. 2009-05, § 1, 9-16-2009; Ord. No. 2010-05, § 1, 9-16-2010; Ord. No. 2011-06, § 1, 9-21-2011) 
Sec. 8-30. - Fee for collections in excess of eight cubic yards. 
    Commencing on October 1 st , 2011, a fee in the amount of seven dollars ($7.00) per cubic yard shall be imposed for individual trash collection in excess of eight (8) cubic yards for the entire collection. There shall be no charges for individual excess trash collection less than eight (8) cubic yard per living unit. 
(Ord. No. 95-01, § II, 3-20-1995; Ord. No. 96-05, § II, 11-6-1996; Ord. No. 2011-06, § 2, 9-21-2011) 
Sec. 8-31. - Fee imposed for the collection of bulky items. 
    Commencing with March 20, 1995, a fee in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) per item shall be imposed for the collection of bulky items. 
(Ord. No. 95-01, § II, 3-20-1995; Ord. No. 96-05, § II, 11-26-1996) 
Sec. 8-32. - Charges for the collection of municipal waste, individual trash collection and bulky items shall constitute a special assessment lien against all improved real property. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by this chapter, all owners of real property in the City are required to have accumulations of garbage, trash and waste removed and disposed of by the department of solid waste of the City, and for such governmental service of garbage, trash and waste collection and disposal, or the availability of such service, all such real property shall be liable for the payment of the waste fees set forth in sections 8-29-8-31. 
(b)  All waste fees becoming due and payable on and after March 20, 1995, shall constitute, and are hereby imposed as, special assessment liens against the real property aforesaid, and until fully paid and discharged, or barred by law, shall remain liens equal in rank and dignity with the license of City and County ad valorem taxes and superior in rank and dignity to all other liens, encumbrances, titles and claims in, to or against the real property involved. 
(c)  Such waste fees shall become delinquent if not fully paid thirty (30) days after due date. All delinquent waste fees shall bear a penalty of one and one-half (1.5) percent monthly, and if not fully paid with all accrued penalty assessments by the due date of the next succeeding waste fee payment, an additional one and one-half (1.5) percent penalty shall be added successively for each period until fully paid. 
(d)  Unpaid and delinquent waste fees, together with all penalties imposed thereon, shall remain and constitute special assessment liens against the real property involved for the period of five (5) years from the due date thereof. Such special assessment liens for waste fees and penalties may be enforced by any of the methods provided in chapter 85, Florida Statutes, or in the alternative, foreclosure proceedings may be instituted and prosecuted under the provisions of chapter 173, Florida Statutes, or the collection and enforcement of payment thereof may be accomplished by any other method authorized by law. 
(e)  Such liens, if filed, may be discharged and satisfied by payment to the City of the aggregate amounts specified in the notice of lien, together with interest thereon from the date of filing of the lien computed at the rate of eighteen (18) percent per annum, together with the administrative costs, filing and recording fees. When any such lien has been fully paid or discharged, the City Manager shall promptly cause evidence of the satisfaction and discharge of such lien to be filed with the Clerk of the Court. 
(f)  Any person, firm, corporation or legal entity, other than the present owner of the property involved, who pays any herein special assessment lien shall be entitled to receive an assignment of the lien held by the City and shall be subrogated to the rights of the City in respect to the enforcement of such lien. 
(g)  The City Manager is authorized and directed to execute and deliver upon request written certificates certifying the amount of waste fees due upon any parcel of real property subject to payment of waste fees, or certifying that no waste fees are due, which certificates shall be binding upon the City. 
(Ord. No. 95-01, § III, 3-20-1995; Ord. No. 96-05, § III, 11-6-1996) 
Sec. 8-33. - City not responsible for collection of construction debris. 
(a)  The City shall not be responsible for the collecting or hauling of trash, discarded building material, dirt, rock, plaster, lumber, metal or other like material originating from private property preliminary to, during or subsequent to the construction of new buildings, alteration or addition to existing buildings of whatsoever type. 
(b)  Such material shall be removed by the owner of the property or by the contractor. This section shall be enforced by the code enforcement officer of the City. 
(Ord. No. 95-01, § IV, 3-20-1995; Ord. No. 96-05, § III, 11-6-1996) 
Sec. 8-34. - Late charge. 
    A late payment charge of one and one-half (1.5) percent of the user charge bill shall be added to each delinquent bill for each thirty (30) days or portion thereof of delinquency. 
(Ord. No. 95-01, § V, 3-20-1995; Ord. No. 96-05, § V, 11-6-1996) 
Secs. 8-35-8-38. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PRIVATE DISPOSAL[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 88-05, §§ 1-10, 12, adopted July 20, 1988, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, its inclusion herein as Art. III, Div. 2, §§ 8-46-8-55 was at the discretion of the editor. Sections 8-39-8-45 have been redesignated as Div. 1, §§ 8-39-8-45, also at the discretion of the editor. Subsequently, Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, adopted July 11, 1990, amended §§ 8-41-8-45 to read as herein set out. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance, §§ 8-41-8-45 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1965, § 9-18. 
County Code reference- Regulation of waste collection and disposal businesses, MDCC § 15-17. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-39. - Permit required for property owner or occupant. 
    In all cases in which garbage or trash is removed and disposed of by persons other than the employees of the waste department, the owner or occupant of the premises from which such removal is made shall previously secure a written permit therefor from the City Manager. 
(Code 1965, § 9-17) 
County Code reference- Disposal of waste by burial on premises, MDCC § 15-15. 
Sec. 8-40. - Application for permit. 
    The application for a permit required by section 8-39 shall show the name and address of the person by whom such removal is to be made, the nature of the vehicle in which it is to be transported, and the location at which and the manner in which the ultimate disposition of the garbage or trash is to be accomplished. 
(Code 1965, § 9-17) 
Sec. 8-41. - Engaging in business of solid waste collection and disposal; issuance of permit to private solid waste collectors. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall remove or transport any garbage, trash, garden trash, construction debris, industrial waste or other solid waste and combination thereof from any premises in the city or through the streets of public rights-of-way of the City for hire or salvage without first applying for and receiving a non-exclusive franchise license from the City to carry on such business. The franchise required by this section shall be in addition to any occupational license which otherwise may be required by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 7-11-1990; Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1, 9-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-42. - Application for non-exclusive franchise license; terms and conditions. 
    Application for a non-exclusive franchise license shall be made to the city upon such forms and in such manner as shall be prescribed by the City Manager. Said form to elicit the following information and to be accompanied by supporting documents and such other information as may be required by the City Manager from time to time: 
(1)  Name of applicant . If applicant is a partnership or corporation, the name(s) and business address(es) of the principal officers and stockholders and other persons having any financial or controlling interest in the partnership or corporation. 
(2)  Character of applicant . The applicant under this section, if an individual, or in case of a firm, corporation, partnership, association or organization, any person having any financial, controlling or managerial interest therein, shall be of good moral character. Making such determination the following information, which shall be submitted by applicant, shall be considered: 
a.  Penal history . If the applicant is an individual, a record of all convictions and the reason there for shall be provided by the applicant. If the applicant is other than individual, then the record of all convictions and the reason therefore of the principal controlling officers of applicant shall be provided. Provided, however, that in the case of a publicly held corporation having twenty-five (25) or more shareholders, than only the aforementioned information applicable to its local managing officers shall be. 
b.  Finger prints . The finger prints of the persons mentioned in this subparagraph, a full set of which, for each of such persons shall accompany the application. Such service may be obtained from the City Police Department. 
c.  Business history . Whether such applicant has operated a solid waste collection-removal business in this or another State under a franchise, permit or license, and if so, where and whether such franchise, permit or license has ever been revoked or suspended and the reason therefore. 
d.  Existence of business entity . If applicant is a corporation, applicant shall submit proof of incorporation in good standing in the State of incorporation and if a foreign corporation, applicant shall provide information certifying that applicant is qualified to do business in the State of Florida. If applicant is other than a corporation and is operating under a fictitious name, applicant shall be required to submit information that such fictitious name registered and held by the applicant. 
(3)  Equipment and method of operation . The applicant for a license shall process equipment capable of providing safe and efficient service. In making such determination and approving the method of operation for each applicant, the City shall require the following information: 
a.  The type, number and complete description of all equipment to be used by the applicant providing service pursuant to this section. 
b.  A statement that applicant will use only County-approved disposal of all garbage, garbage-trash, industrial waste and solid waste material which applicant collects and removes, except those sites which the City may from time to time approve. 
c.  The names of customers, the addresses of each location served, and schedule of rates of the applicant. 
(4)  Insurance requirements . The applicant shall maintain insurance as specified herein and shall furnish a public liability policy to the City Manager and also file with the City Manager a Certificate of Insurance for all policies written in the applicant's name. The Certificate shall provide that said policies shall name the City as an additional insured and shall contain a provision that a written notice of cancellation or reduction in coverage of said policies shall be delivered to the City thirty (30) days in advance of the effective date thereof, by registered mail return receipt requested. 
a.  Comprehensive general liability and automobile liability insurance shall be maintained throughout the term of the franchise license. Liability insurance insuring the City and the franchisee with regard to all damages caused by the franchisee or its servants, employees and agents in the minimum amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury or death to any one person, within the limit, however, three million dollars ($3,000,000.00) for bodily injury or death resulting from any one accident, and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for property damage resulting from any one accident. 
b.  The insurance policies obtained by a grantee in compliance with this section shall be issued by company or companies acceptable to the City and a current Certificate or Certificate of Insurance along with written evidence of payment of all required premiums shall be filed and maintained with the City during the term of the license. 
c.  The above insurance requirements shall not be construed as imposing upon the City or any official or employee thereof, any liability or responsibility for injury to any person or property caused by the franchisee, his/her/its agents or employees. 
(5)  Application fee . Each applicant shall be accompanied by a fee of one thousand eight hundred dollars ($1,800.00). The completed application shall be submitted to the City Manager and upon receipt of a completed application, the City Manager or his designated representative, shall review said application. Should the City Manager deny an applicant for a nonexclusive franchise, the City Manager shall notify the applicant of such denial in writing not later than fourteen (14) days after taking such action. Notice of denial shall contain a statement of the reasons why the application was denied. The denial or revocation of a non-exclusive franchise by the City Manager may be appealed to the City Commission. The Notice of Appeal shall be filed in writing with the City Clerk no later than thirty (30) days after the mailing to the applicant of the denial or revocation. The hearing before the City Commission shall not be held any sooner than the second (2nd) regular meeting of the City Commission after the date of the filing of the Notice of Appeal or shall said hearing be held any later than the fourth (4th) regular meeting of the City Commission after the filing of the Notice of Appeal, the City Commission shall either affirm the decision of the City Manager or direct the City Manager to issue or reinstate the franchise license which decision shall be final. 
(6)  License term . Any license granted by the City Manager shall be for a term of three (3) years. 
(Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 7-11-1990; Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1, 9-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-43. - License Fee. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation granted a non-exclusive franchise license shall pay to the City, each year during the life of the license, a franchise license fee in the sum of eighteen (18) percent of the licensee's annual gross receipts derived from the licensee's operation within the City limits. 
(b)  A licensee shall file with the City Manager, a quarterly financial statement showing the gross revenue, as defined herein, of the licensee during said calendar quarter or portion thereof, which ever is applicable, no later than thirty (30) days from the ending of said quarter. It shall be the duty of the licensee to pay the City within fifteen (15) days after the time for filing said statement, the sum prescribed above for the quarterly period covered by said statement. 
(c)  A licensee shall file with the City Manager within ninety (90) days after expiration of any calendar year, or portion thereof, during which the licensee's license is in force, an annual financial statement, certified by a Certified Public Accountant, showing the gross revenue as defined herein, of the license during the preceding calendar year or portion thereof. It shall be the duty of the licensee to pay to the City within fifteen (15) days after said filing of the certified annual report, any deficiency that may be shown by said report in the calculation of the franchise fees. If there is an overpayment by licensee to the city, the City shall credit said overpayment on the next quarterly payment due the City. 
(d)  The City shall have the right to inspect the licensee's records showing the gross revenues from which the licensee's payments are computed and shall also have the right of audit and re-computation of any and all amounts paid under this chapter. No acceptance of payments shall be construed as a release or as an accord and satisfaction of any claim the City may have for further or additional sums payable under this chapter, or for the performance of any other obligation hereunder. 
(e)  The licensee shall set forth the initial rates which license shall charge its customers upon commencing service. 
(Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 7-11-1990; Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1, 9-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-44. - Information required of license. 
    At least annually, but not more frequently than quarterly as determined by the City Manager, each licensee shall supply the following information on a form and in a manner prescribed by the City Manager or his designee: 
(1)  A listing, as of the reporting date, of the names and addresses of customers, the addresses of each location served and schedule of rates charged by licensee to each customer. 
(2)  A summary of the number of cubic yards of garbage, trash, garden trash and other solid waste material collected weekly based on scheduled service, as of the reporting date. 
(3)  Each licensee shall file any change in its schedule of charges with the City manager in writing on a form prescribed by the City Manager or his designee prior to becoming effective. 
(Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 7-11-1990; Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1, 9-7-2011) 
Sec. 8-45. - Revocation of franchise license. 
(a)  The violation of any of the terms and conditions of the West Miami City Code or ordinances which endanger the public health, safety and welfare, or the violation of any of the terms and conditions of license, or the failure to promptly pay the fees and charges provided in this Chapter shall be cause for revocation of the license. The City Manager may revoke a license for a violation or violations as aforementioned, and may immediately declare such license null and void, and upon such declaration, the licensee shall immediately cease all operations and shall be considered to have forfeited such license and the rights required thereunder. Should the City Manager decide to revoke a license, he shall provide the licensee with notice of such revocation and the reason therefore. Upon receipt of such notice, the licensee may appeal such revocation to the City Commission and the appeal and hearing thereon shall be conducted in accordance with the procedure set forth in section 8-42(e) of this ordinance. 
(b)  The City hereby reserves the right to reject any application for franchise license and to terminate any franchise license. 
(Ord. No. 90-7, § 1, 7-11-1990; Ord. No. 2011-04, § 1, 9-7-2011) 
DIVISION 2. - DISPOSAL OF USED TIRES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Maintenance of municipal property, § 5-55 et seq. 

Sec. 8-46. - Dumping or disposal of used tires within City limits unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful to dump or dispose of used tires on any property within the City of West Miami, Florida. 
(Ord. No. 88-05, § 1, 7-20-1988) 
Sec. 8-47. - Approved methods of disposal. 
    Disposal of used tires by any person, firm, business, corporation or other entity shall be by resale, recycling, or disposal at an approved dumping facility or other legal facility. 
(Ord. No. 88-05, § 2, 7-20-1988) 
Sec. 8-48. - Registration required. 
    All persons, firms, businesses, corporations or other entities hereinafter referred to as "person," which accumulate used tires, including, but not limited to, tire dealers, service stations which perform tire services, garages which deal in the tire services, tire disposal companies, and department stores with automotive centers, shall register with the licensing division of the City of West Miami. 
(Ord. No. 88-05, § 3, 7-20-1988) 
Sec. 8-49. - Registration forms. 
    There shall be registration forms provided by the licensing division which shall include: 
(1)  Name and address of business; 
(2)  Owner's name and address; 
(3)  Storage location of all used tires; 
(4)  Method of disposal of used tires; and 
(5)  The forms shall be executed by the owner and all such registration forms shall be notarized. 
(Ord. No. 88-05, § 4, 7-20-1988) 
Sec. 8-50. - Registration fee. 
    The applicant for registration shall pay a registration fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) at the time of filing the application. 
(Ord. No. 88-05, § 5, 7-20-1988) 
Sec. 8-51. - Quarterly reports. 
    Quarterly (March 31, June 30, September 30 and December 31), each such registered person shall file a notarized report, describing the number of tires of disposed of during the quarter, and the method of disposal used, who is used for disposal, if other than the registered person, and the place of disposal. 
(Ord. No. 88-05, § 6, 7-20-1988) 
Sec. 8-52. - Responsibility of registered persons regarding disposal. 
    No registered person shall be permitted to give used tires to any nonregistered person for disposal by said nonregistered person, except as provided in section 8-47 of this division. 
(Ord. No. 88-05, § 7, 7-20-1988) 
Sec. 8-53. - Revocation. 
(a)  Noncompliance. Noncompliance by any registered person with any of the foregoing provisions may, in addition to other penalties, result in the revocation of the occupational license of the business. 
(b)  Illegal or improper disposal. Illegal or improper disposal of used tires by any registered business, firm, corporation, or person, or the illegal or improper disposal of used tires by any registered person, business, firm, or corporation, on behalf of said registered business, shall result in the revocation of the occupational license of the registered business, as well as other penalties provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 88-05, §§ 8, 10, 7-20-1988) 
Sec. 8-54. - Documentation of compliance required. 
    All registered persons shall, upon request, provide books, records, receipts or other documentation to any duly authorized inspector or police officer of the City of West Miami upon request during reasonable business hours, for the purpose of providing proof of compliance. 
(Ord. No. 88-05, § 9, 7-20-1988) 
Sec. 8-55. - Penalties for violations. 
    Any person, firm, corporation or entity convicted of violating the provisions of this division shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by a jail sentence not exceeding sixty (60) days, or both, in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 88-05, § 12, 7-20-1988) 
ARTICLE IV. - LITTERING[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Posting or distributing political matter on city property, § 2-40; littering parks generally, § 11-41. 
County Code reference- Littering prohibited, MDCC § 15-5.1. 
State Law reference- Litter control, F.S. § 403.413 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 8-56. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    Aircraft is any contrivance now known or hereafter invented, used or designated for navigation or for flight in the air. The word "aircraft" shall include helicopters and lighter-than-air dirigibles and balloons. 
    Authorized private receptacle is a garbage can or trash container as defined in section 8-1. 
    Commercial handbill is any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature: 
(1)  Which advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity, or thing; or 
(2)  Which directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting the interest thereof by sales; or 
(3)  Which directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, for which an admission fee is charged for the purpose of private gain or profit; but the terms of this clause shall not apply where an admission fee is charged or collection is taken up for the purpose of defraying the expenses incident to such meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, when the same is held, given or takes place in connection with the dissemination of information which is not restricted under the ordinary rules of decency, good morals, public peace, safety and good order; provided, that nothing contained in this clause shall be deemed to authorize the holding, giving or taking place of any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition, or event of any kind, without a license, where such license is or may be required by any law of this State, or under any ordinance of this City; or 
(4)  Which, while containing reading matter other than advertising matter, is predominantly and essentially an advertisement, and is distributed or circulated for advertising purposes, or for the private benefit and gain of any person so engaged as advertiser or distributor. 
    Garbage. See section 8-1. 
    Litter is garbage, refuse, and rubbish as defined herein or in section 8-1 and all other waste material which, if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited, tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. 
    Newspaper is any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any newspaper duly entered with the Postal Service of the United States, in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law; and, in addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four (4) issues per year, and sold to the public. 
    Noncommercial handbill is any printed or written matter, any sample, or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, newspaper, magazine, paper, booklet, or any other printed or otherwise reproduced original copies of any matter of literature not included in the aforesaid definitions of a commercial handbill or newspaper. 
    Park is a park, reservation, playground, recreation center or any other public area in the City, owned or used by the City and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Private premises is any dwelling, house, building, or other structure, designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building, or other structure. 
    Public place is any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds, and buildings. 
    Refuse is all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except body wastes), including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, inoperative or partially dismantled or parts thereof, and solid market and industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish is nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials. 
    Sample is an article of merchandise given or distributed without charge to advertise merchandise. 
    Vehicle is every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Code 1965, § 9-30; Ord. No. 373, § 1, 4-6-1977) 
Sec. 8-57. - Littering public places. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the City except in public receptacles, in authorized private receptacles for collection, or in official City dumps. 
(Code 1965, § 9-31) 
Sec. 8-58. - Placement of litter in receptacles. 
    Persons placing litter in public receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon private property. 
(Code 1965, § 9-32) 
Sec. 8-59. - Sweeping, depositing litter in streets, gutters, etc. 
    No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the City the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. 
(Code 1965, § 9-33) 
Sec. 8-60. - Maintenance of sidewalks and swales. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Swale area . A swale area is that between the property line and the back of the street curb or the edge of the paved roadway. 
(2)  Duty to maintain sidewalks and swale area . 
a.  Sidewalks, alley and rights-of-way to be kept clean. 
b.  Rental property . In the case of rental property, the occupant shall be held jointly and severally liable for compliance with those duties and obligations imposed upon the owner by this section. 
c.  All owners of unimproved property and occupants, or occupants and owners of improved property shall maintain their property in a clean and litter-free manner, including sidewalks, grass strips, alleys up to and including the median point of the alley, curbs, swale areas, or rights-of-way up to the edge of the pavement of any public street. 
d.  Every merchant, store keeper or operator of a business in the city shall sweep or cause to be swept the sidewalks adjoining his respective place of business, and continuing as often as necessary thereafter to keep the area clean, on each day such business shall be operated. 
e.  The sweepings shall be picked up and deposited into a garbage receptacle and not swept into the gutter as prohibited by section 8-59. 
f.  Enforcement; fines . The provisions of this section shall be enforced as provided in section 2-163. Fines shall be as follows: 
1.  First violation fifty dollars ($50.00) 
2.  Second violation within twelve (12) months of the first violation one hundred dollars ($100.00) 
3.  Third violation within twelve (12) months of the first violation two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) 
g.  For purposes of this section, "violation" shall mean either an uncontested citation issued by a code enforcement officer or a finding of violation by the Code Enforcement Board or a special master. Appeals from citations issued by a code enforcement officer shall be as provided in chapter 2 section 2-162. 
(Code 1965, § 9-33; Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, 5-4-2011) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-02, § 1, adopted May 4, 2011, amended § 8-60 and in so doing changed the title of said section from "Duty to keep abutting sidewalks free of litter" to "Maintenance of Sidewalks and Swales," as set out herein. 
Cross reference- Maintenance of commercial property, § 5-55 et seq. 
Sec. 8-61. - Throwing litter from vehicle. 
    No person, while a driver or passenger in a vehicle, shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the City, or upon private property. 
(Code 1965, § 9-35) 
Sec. 8-62. - Vehicles causing litter. 
    No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the City unless such vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley, or other public place; nor shall any person drive or move any vehicle or truck within the City, the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley, or other public place, mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter or foreign matter of any kind. 
(Code 1965, § 9-36) 
County Code reference- Vehicles spilling waste materials, MDCC § 15-7. 
Sec. 8-63. - Littering occupied private property. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private property within the City, whether owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private property. 
(Code 1965, § 9-46) 
Sec. 8-64. - Owner to maintain premises free of litter. 
    The owner or person in control of any private property shall at all times maintain the premises free of litter; provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection. 
(Code 1965, § 9-47) 
Sec. 8-65. - Littering vacant lots. 
    No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private property within the City whether owned by such person or not. 
(Code 1965, § 9-48) 
Sec. 8-66. - Clearing of litter from open private property by City. 
(a)  Notice to remove. The City Manager is hereby authorized and empowered to notify the owner of any open or vacant private property within the City, or the agent of such owner, to properly dispose of litter located on such owner's property which is dangerous to public health, safety or welfare. Such notice shall be by registered mail, addressed to said owner at his last known address. 
(b)  Action upon noncompliance. Upon the failure, neglect or refusal of any owner or agent so notified, to properly dispose of litter dangerous to the public health, safety or welfare within thirty (30) days after receipt of written notice provided for in subsection (a) above, or within thirty (30) days after the date of such notice in the event the same is returned to the City because of its inability to make delivery thereof, provided the same was properly addressed to the last known address of such owner, or agent, the City Manager is hereby authorized and empowered to pay for the disposing of such litter or to order its disposal by the City. 
(c)  Collection of costs from owner. When the City has effected the removal of such dangerous litter or has paid for its removal, the cost thereof shall be charged to the owner of such property and shall be collected and shall constitute a lien as provided by section 2-9. 
(Code 1965, § 9-49) 
Cross reference- Nuisances generally, § 10-21 et seq. 
Sec. 8-67. - Throwing or distributing handbills in public places. 
    No person shall throw, scatter or cast any kind of handbill in or upon any public place within the City; provided, however, it shall not be unlawful for any person to hand out or distribute handbills in any public place to any person willing to accept such handbill. 
(Code 1965, § 9-38; Ord. No. 84-01(A), § 1, 3-7-1984) 
Sec. 8-68. - Placing handbills on vehicles. 
    No person shall deposit, fasten, throw, scatter or cast any handbill in or upon any vehicle. The provisions of this section shall not be deemed to prohibit the handling of any handbill to the owner or other occupant of any vehicle who is willing to accept. 
(Code 1965, § 9-39; Ord. No. 84-01(A), § 1, 3-7-1984) 
Sec. 8-69. - Distribution of handbills on vacant private premises. 
    No person shall place any handbill in or upon any private premises which are vacant. 
(Code 1965, § 9-40; Ord. No. 84-01(A), § 1, 3-7-1984) 
Sec. 8-70. - Distributing handbills on private premises. 
(a)  Manner of handbill distribution on inhabited private premises. No person shall place any handbill in or upon any private premises which are inhabited, except by handling or transmitting any such handbill directly to any other person then present in or upon the private premises. However, in case of inhabited private premises which are not posted against handbill distribution as provided in this article, any person, unless requested by someone upon such premises not to do so, may place or deposit any handbill in or upon the inhabited private premises, if the handbill is placed or deposited so as to prevent it from being carried by the elements about such premises elsewhere. 
(b)  Premises posted against handbill distribution. No person shall place any handbill upon any premises if requested by anyone thereon not to do so if there is placed on the premises in a conspicuous position near the entrance thereof a sign bearing notice indicating that the occupants of said premises do not desire to have any such handbills left upon said premises. 
(Code 1965, § 9-41; Ord. No. 373, § 2, 4-6-1977; Ord. No. 84-01(A), § 1, 3-7-1984) 
Sec. 8-71. - Activities exempt from sections 8-67 through 8-71 inclusive. 
    The provisions of sections 8-67 through 8-71 inclusive shall not be deemed to apply to the distribution of mail by the United States, nor to the distribution of newspapers, political literature and other political information. 
(Ord. No. 84-01(A), § 1, 3-7-1984) 
Editor's note- 84-01(A), § 1, adopted March 7, 1984, provided in part that § 8-71 be amended to read as herein set out. Prior to said amendment, § 8-71 pertained to the distribution of noncommercial handbills at inhabited private premises as derived from Code 1965, § 9-42. 
Sec. 8-72. - Dropping litter from aircraft. 
    No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit within the City any litter, handbill or any other object. 
(Code 1965, § 9-44) 
Secs. 8-73-8-83. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS TO DISTRIBUTE COMMERCIAL MATTER[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Peddlers and solicitors regulated, § 9-70 et seq. 

Sec. 8-84. - Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute any sample or any commercial handbill within the City without first obtaining a permit therefor as provided herein, except as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cause the distribution of samples or commercial handbills within the City by a person or persons not permitted as provided herein, except as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1965, § 9-41A; Ord. No. 373, § 3, 4-6-1977) 
Sec. 8-85. - Application required; contents. 
    Applicants for permits under this division must file with the City Manager a sworn application in writing (in duplicate) on a form to be furnished by the City Manager, which shall give substantially the following information: 
(a)  Name and description of applicant; 
(b)  Address (legal and local); 
(c)  A brief description of the sample or commercial handbill to be distributed; 
(d)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
(e)  The length of time for which the right to distribute samples or commercial handbills is desired; 
(f)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the same, together with license number or other means of identification; 
(g)  Two (2) prints of a photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of the filing of the application, which prints shall be two (2) inches by two (2) inches, showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(h)  The fingerprints of the applicant; 
(i)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any felony, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 9-41A; Ord. No. 373, § 3, 4-6-1977) 
Sec. 8-86. - Application and permit fees. 
(a)  If the applicant for a permit hereunder is a paid distributor of samples or commercial handbills, an application fee of ten dollars ($10.00) shall be paid by the applicant to the City Manager. 
(b)  In addition to the application fee provided above, persons who are required to pay such fee shall also pay a permit fee of fifty cents ($0.50) per week, or two dollars ($2.00) per month, or twenty dollars ($20.00) per year; provided, however, that where one (1) or more persons are engaged in the delivery of samples or commercial handbills of one (1) publisher under the supervision of one (1) person, only the supervisor shall be required to pay the permit fee herein provided, but all persons working under such supervisor must obtain a permit as herein provided. 
(c)  For the purpose of this division any period of seven (7) calendar days or less shall be considered one (1) week; any period of more than seven (7) calendar days and not more than thirty (30) calendar days shall be considered one (1) month; any period of more than thirty (30) calendar days and not more than one (1) calendar year shall be treated as a year. The annual fees herein provided for shall be assessed on a yearly basis commencing October first of each year and on and after April first. The amount of the fee for such annual permit shall be one-half (1/2) the amount stipulated for the remainder of the year. 
(Code 1965, § 9-41A; Ord. No. 373, § 3, 4-6-1977) 
Sec. 8-87. - Approval of application, issuance of permit. 
    Upon receipt of an application hereunder, the City Manager shall endorse his approval on the application, execute a permit addressed to the applicant and, upon payment of the prescribed fee, deliver to the applicant his permit. Permits issued shall show the name and address of the person to whom issued, the amount of fee paid, the date of issuance and the length of time the same shall be operative, as well as the license number and the other identifying description of any vehicle to be used. The City Manager shall keep a permanent record of all permits issued. 
(Code 1965, § 9-41A; Ord. No. 373, § 3, 4-6-1977) 
Sec. 8-88. - Permit expiration. 
    All annual permits issued under the provisions of this division shall expire on September 30 following date of issue. Other than annual permits shall expire on the date specified in the permit. 
(Code 1965, § 9-41A; Ord. No. 373, § 3, 4-6-1977) 
Sec. 8-89. - Renewal of permits. 
    Permits issued hereunder may be renewed upon payment of the fees required by this division. 
(Code 1965, § 9-41A; Ord. No. 373, § 3, 4-6-1977) 
Sec. 8-90. - Identification card; distinctive uniform required. 
    The City Manager shall issue to each permittee at the time of delivery of his permit an identification card. The identification card shall bear the words "Registered Distributor," a photograph of the distributor, the period for which the permit is issued, and the number of the permit, in letters and figures plainly discernible. Such identification card shall be worn constantly by the distributor on the front of his outer garment in such a way as to be conspicuous during such time as he is engaged in distributing samples or commercial handbills within the City. In addition, persons distributing samples or handbills shall wear a distinctive uniform or shirt with the name of the distributing company in letters at least two (2) inches in height. 
(Code 1965, § 9-41A; Ord. No. 373, § 3, 4-6-1977) 
Sec. 8-91. - Misuse of permit or card. 
    No permit or identification card issued under the provisions of this division shall be used or worn at any time by any person other than the one to whom it was issued. 
(Code 1965, § 9-41A; Ord. No. 373, § 3, 4-6-1977) 
Sec. 8-92. - Duty to exhibit permit on request. 
    Persons holding permits issued pursuant to this division are required to exhibit their permits at the request of any resident or police officer of the City. 
(Code 1965, § 9-41A; Ord. No. 373, § 3, 4-6-1977) 
Sec. 8-93. - Enforcement by police. 
    It shall be the duty of any police officer to require any person seen distributing samples or commercial handbills, and who is not known by such officer to be duly registered, to produce his permit; and to enforce the provisions of this article against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Code 1965, § 9-41A; Ord. No. 373, § 3, 4-6-1977) 
Sec. 8-94. - Report, records of violations. 
    The chief of police shall report to the City Manager all convictions for violation of this article by permittees hereunder, and the City Manager shall maintain a record for each permit issued and record the reports of violation therein. 
(Code 1965, § 9-41A; Ord. No. 373, § 3, 4-6-1977) 
Sec. 8-95. - Grounds for permit revocation. 
    Violation of any of the terms of this article, or conviction of a felony or a crime of moral turpitude, shall be grounds for revocation of a permit issued pursuant to this division. 
(Code 1965, § 9-41A; Ord. No. 373, § 3, 4-6-1977) 
Chapter 9 - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Municipal code enforcement board, § 2-136 et seq.; regulation of alcoholic beverage establishments, Ch. 3; licenses for handicap facilities, § 5-91 et seq.; licensing and regulation of cable television systems, Ch. 6; permits to distribute commercial advertising matter, § 8-84 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Occupational licenses. 
    Occupational licenses shall continue to be governed by Ordinance Number 325, enacted July 19, 1972, as from time to time amended, and nothing contained in this Code, or in the ordinance adopting this Code, shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the provisions of said Ordinance Number 325, as amended. 
State Law reference- Local Business Tax Act, F.S. ch. 205. 
Secs. 9-2-9-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Permits to distribute commercial advertising matter, § 8-84 et seq.; shouting or crying by peddlers, § 10-5(1); vending in parks, § 11-67. 
County Code references- Vending merchandise in public right-of-way near school, MDCC § 21-27.1; near parks, § 21-27.2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-70. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division: 
    Canvasser or solicitor is any individual, whether a resident of the City or not, traveling either by foot, wagon, automobile, motor truck, or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise or personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, policies of insurance, or anything of value of whatever nature, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not. 
    Peddler is any person, whether a resident of the City or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle, or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, merchandise meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, garden truck, farm products or provisions, offering and exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers, or who, without traveling from place to place, shall sell or offer the same for sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, railroad car, or other vehicle or conveyance, and further provided, that one who solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this division shall be deemed a peddler subject to the provisions of this division. The word "peddler" shall include the words "hawker" and "huckster." 
    Peddler vehicle is any automobile, truck, motorcycle, bicycle, trailer, push-cart and any wheeled device, whether self-propelled or motor-driven, or propelled by, or pulled by, man or animal, for the purpose of carrying any inventory of tangible property for sale by a person in attendance of such vehicle. 
    Supervisor is a person who is in charge of, or supervises, one or more peddlers, canvassers or solicitors, who are required to be permitted under this division, and who are employed by, or agents of, the same company or organization as their supervisor. 
(Code 1965, § 18-2; Ord. No. 83-01, § 1, 5-4-1983) 
Sec. 9-71. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler, solicitor or canvasser to engage in such business within the City without first obtaining a permit therefor in compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1965, § 18-1) 
Sec. 9-72. - Application for permit generally. 
    Except as provided by section 9-74, applicants for permits under this division must file with the City Manager a sworn application in writing (in duplicate) on a form to be furnished by the City Manager, which shall give substantially the following information: 
(a)  Name and description of the applicant; 
(b)  Address (legal and local); 
(c)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold; 
(d)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
(e)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(f)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the same, together with its license number or other means of identification; 
(g)  Two prints of a photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of the filing of the application, which picture shall be two (2) inches by two (2) inches showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(h)  The fingerprints of the applicant and the names of at least two (2) reliable property owners of Dade County, who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or, in lieu of the name of references, such other available evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant as will enable an investigator to properly evaluate such character and business responsibility; 
(i)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor, or violation of any municipal ordinance excepting traffic violations, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 18-3) 
Sec. 9-73. - Application fee. 
    At the time of filing the application required by section 9-72, a fee of three dollars and fifty cents ($3.50) shall be paid to the City Manager to cover the cost of investigation. 
(Code 1965, § 18-3) 
Sec. 9-74. - Alternative application for insurance agents. 
    Insurance agents and solicitors holding valid current licenses from the department of insurance of the State and who come within the provisions of this division, in lieu of the application provided for above, may file with the City Manager a sworn application in writing (in duplicate) on a form to be furnished by the City Manager, which shall give substantially the following information: 
(a)  Name and address of applicant. 
(b)  Name of insurance company or companies represented. 
(c)  Length of time for which permit is desired. 
(d)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the same, together with the license number or other means of identification. 
(e)  Two (2) prints of a photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of the filing of the application, which picture shall be two (2) inches by two (2) inches showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner. 
(f)  The fingerprints of the applicant. 
(Code 1965, § 18-3) 
Sec. 9-75. - Application fee for insurance agents. 
    At the time of filing the application under section 9-74 a fee of one dollar ($1.00) shall be paid to the City Manager to cover costs of the application. 
(Code 1965, § 18-3) 
Sec. 9-76. - Investigation and action on application. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application for permit under this division, the City Manager shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as shall be necessary for the protection of the public good. 
(b)  If as a result of such investigation the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be such that it would be contrary to the interest of the residents of the City to issue a permit to such applicant, the City Manager shall endorse on such application his disapproval and reasons for the same, and shall notify the applicant that his application is disapproved and that no permit will be issued. 
(c)  If as a result of such investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be such that the welfare of the residents of the City would not be adversely affected by the issuance of the permit, the City Manager shall endorse approval on the application, execute a permit addressed to the applicant for the carrying on of the business applied for and upon payment of the prescribed permit fee, deliver to the applicant his permit. Such permit shall contain the signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall show the name and address of the permittee, the class of permit issued and the kind of goods to be sold thereunder, the amount of fee paid, the date of issuance and the length of time the same shall be operative, as well as the license number and the other identifying description of any vehicle used in such business. The City Manager shall keep a permanent record of all permits issued. 
(d)  Because of the stringent investigation and regulation of insurance agents and solicitors by the State insurance department, the presentation by an applicant of a current and valid solicitor's or agent's license issued by the State insurance department shall constitute prima facie evidence of good character and business responsibility of the applicant and the City Manager shall issue a permit to such applicant without further investigation. 
(Code 1965, § 18-4) 
Sec. 9-77. - Permit fees. 
(a)  The permit fee which shall be charged by the City for permits issued hereunder shall be fifty cents ($0.50) per week, two dollars ($2.00) per month or twenty dollars ($20.00) per year. 
(b)  For the purpose of this division any period of seven (7) calendar days or less shall be considered one (1) week; any period of more than seven (7) calendar days and not more than thirty (30) calendar days shall be considered one (1) month; any period of more than thirty (30) calendar days and not more than one (1) calendar year shall be treated as a year. The annual fees herein provided for shall be assessed on a yearly basis commencing October 1 of each year and on and after April 1 the amount of the fee for such annual permits shall be one-half (1/2) the amount stipulated for the remainder of the year. 
(c)  None of the permit fees provided for by this division shall be so applied as to occasion an undue burden upon interstate commerce. In any case where a permit fee is believed by a permittee or applicant for permit to place an undue burden upon such commerce, he may apply to the City Manager for an adjustment of the fee so that it shall not be discriminatory, unreasonable, or unfair as to such commerce. Such application may be made before, at or within six (6) months after payment of the prescribed fee. The applicant shall, by affidavit and supporting testimony, show his method of business and the gross volume or estimated gross volume of business and such other information as the City Manager may deem necessary in order to determine the extent, if any, of such undue burden on such commerce. The City Manager shall then conduct an investigation, comparing applicant's business with other businesses of like nature and shall make findings of fact from which he shall determine whether the fee fixed by this division is unfair, unreasonable or discriminatory as to applicant's business and shall fix as the permit fee for the applicant an amount that is fair, reasonable and nondiscriminatory, or, if the fee has already been paid, shall order a refund of the amount over and above the fee so fixed. In fixing the fee to be charged, the City Manager shall have the power to base the fee upon a percentage of gross sales, or any other method which will assure that the fee assessed shall be uniform with that assessed on businesses of like nature, so long as the amount assessed does not exceed the fees as prescribed by subsection (a) hereof. Should the City Manager determine the gross sales measure of the fee to be the fair basis, he may require the applicant to submit, either at the time of termination of applicant's business in the City or at the end of each three (3) month period, a sworn statement of the gross sales and pay the amount of fee therefor, provided that no additional fee during any one (1) calendar year shall be required after the permittee shall have paid an amount equal to the annual fee as prescribed in subsection (a) above. 
(d)  Permits issued hereunder may be renewed upon payment of the fees required by this division. 
(e)  The permit fee which shall be charged by the City for permits issued hereunder to supervisors shall be as follows: 
(1)  Where the supervisor has not more than five (5) employees or agents working within the City, the fee shall be two dollars ($2.00) per week, six dollars ($6.00) per month, or fifty dollars ($50.00) per year. 
(2)  Where the supervisor has more than five (5) agents or employees working within the City, the fee shall be as provided in (1) above, plus an additional one dollar ($1.00) per week, three dollars ($3.00) per month, or twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per year, for each additional group of five (5) or fewer, agents or employees. 
(f)  Any peddler, canvasser or solicitor who is employed by, or an agent of, a company or organization which has a permitted supervisor as provided herein and who is under the direction and control of such permitted supervisor shall not be required to pay the fee provided in subsection (a) above, but shall be required to obtain a permit and comply with all other requirements and provisions of this division. 
(Code 1965, § 18-5) 
Sec. 9-78. - When permits expire. 
    All annual permits issued under the provisions of this division shall expire on September 30 following date of issue. Other than annual permits shall expire on the date specified in the permit. 
(Code 1965, § 18-11) 
Sec. 9-79. - Identification cards. 
    The City Manager shall issue an identification card to each permittee under this division at the time of delivery of his permit. The identification card shall bear the words "Permitted Peddler" or "Permitted Solicitor," as the case may be, a photograph of the permittee, the period for which the permit is issued, and the number of the permit, in letters and figures plainly discernible. Such identification card shall be worn constantly by the permittee on the front of his outer garment in such a way as to be conspicuous during such time as said permittee is engaged in peddling, soliciting or canvassing. 
(Code 1965, § 18-6) 
Sec. 9-80. - Misuse of permit or card. 
    No permit or identification card issued under the provisions of this division shall be used or worn at any time by any person other than the one to whom it was issued. 
(Code 1965, § 18-7) 
Sec. 9-81. - Duty to exhibit permit. 
    Permittees are required to exhibit their permits at the request of any resident or police officer of the City. 
(Code 1965, § 18-8) 
Sec. 9-82. - Enforcement by police. 
    It shall be the duty of any police officer of the City to require any person seen peddling, soliciting or canvassing, and who is not known by such officer to be duly permitted, to produce his permit; and to enforce the provisions of this division against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Code 1965, § 18-9) 
Sec. 9-83. - Reports, records of violations. 
    The chief of police shall report to the City Manager all convictions for violation of this division and the City Manager shall maintain a record for each permit issued and record the reports of violation therein. 
(Code 1965, § 18-10) 
Sec. 9-84. - Areas off limits to peddler vehicles. 
    No peddler vehicle, as defined herein, shall be permitted in any part of the City zoned A use, R-1 use, R-2 use or R-5 use, for the purpose of making sales therefrom, and no peddler vehicles shall be stopped or parked on any public street, sidewalk, right-of-way or park for the purpose of making sales therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 83-01, § 2, 5-4-1983) 
Sec. 9-85. - Areas where peddler vehicles are allowed. 
    Peddler vehicles may park, for purposes of making sales, only on privately-owned parking lots or vacant property in the C use zoned areas of the City, with the written permission of the owner of such property; provided, however that if the parking of such peddler vehicles shall impede or impair the use of the parking area or adjacent rights-of-way and cause congestion or inconvenience to the public, or should the owner or operator fail to produce for inspection written permission of the property owner, upon request of a police officer, the owner or operator thereof shall, upon notice from a police officer of the City, cease the sale of goods and remove said peddler vehicle from such parking area. For the purpose of this section, the judgment of a police officer, assessed in good faith, shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public is impeded or inconvenienced. Failure of a peddler to have available for inspection by police written permission of the property owner, or providing a false or fraudulent instrument of permission shall constitute a violation of this section, and shall be grounds for removal from the site and cessation of sale of goods. 
(Ord. No. 83-01, § 2, 5-4-1983) 
Sec. 9-86. - Peddlers to have proof of ownership of goods for sale. 
    Peddlers licensed hereunder, at all times when making or offering to make sales within the City, shall have available bills of lading or other commercial documents proving their title to goods being sold and shall exhibit such proof at the request of any police officer of the City. Failure to exhibit proof when requested by such officer shall be grounds for, and reason for, the officer to require the peddler to cease making sales and to remove forthwith his peddler vehicle from the approved location. 
(Ord. No. 83-01, § 2, 5-4-1983) 
Sec. 9-87. - Other requirements of peddlers selling goods in the City. 
    The name of the peddler, as well as his address, shall be exhibited at the point of sales by a sign on the vehicle or by a sign prominently displayed at the site. If the peddler is a representative or agent of another who produces or sells the goods being offered for sale, the sign required by this section shall so state and shall contain the name and address of such other party. Any items sold by a peddler at a price of five dollars ($5.00) or more shall be accompanied by a receipt containing the name and address of the peddler, and if the peddler is an agent or representative of another who produces or sells the goods sold, then the name and address of such person as well. All merchandise must be displayed and sold from the vehicle; and merchandise shall not be displayed or placed on the ground in the vicinity of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 83-01, § 2, 5-4-1983) 
Sec. 9-88. - Exception for ice cream vendors. 
    The restrictions set out in sections 9-84 through 9-87 shall not apply to vendors of prepackaged ice cream products who possess valid, current licenses, as required by law, and comply with all State, County and City health regulations. 
(Ord. No. 83-01, § 3, 5-4-1983) 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 83-01, adopted May 4, 1983, not expressly amendatory of the Code, has been included herein as § 9-88, at the editor's discretion. 
Secs. 9-89-9-93. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - NONPROFIT SOLICITATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Soliciting contributions in parks prohibited, § 11-61. 

Sec. 9-94. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division: 
    Nonprofit organization means any organization, whether a club, partnership, society, corporation, corporation not for profit, church, religious sect, religious denomination, society, organization or league, and includes any trustee, receiver, assignee, agent, or any similar representative thereof; which has as its object, aim or purpose, religion, charity, education, civic betterment, fellowship, or improvement of the public welfare or any segment thereof. 
    Solicit means to request, directly or indirectly, money, credit, property, financial assistance or other thing of value on the plea or representation that such money, credit, property, financial assistance, or other thing of value will be used for the purpose of the organization for which the solicitation is made; and shall include any oral or written request, and any sale of, offer or attempt to sell, any advertisement, book, card, chance, coupon, device, magazine, membership, merchandise, subscription, ticket or other thing in connection with which any appeal is made for the purposes of the organization soliciting, or where the name of any organization is used or referred to in any such appeal as an inducement or reason for making any such sale, or when or where, in connection with any such sale, any statement is made that the whole or any part of the proceeds from any such sale will go or be donated to any charitable, religious, educational or civil purpose. 
    Solicitor or canvasser means one who solicits on behalf of a nonprofit organization. 
(Code 1965, § 18-20) 
Sec. 9-95. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any nonprofit organization, or solicitor or canvasser therefor, to solicit within the City without first obtaining a permit therefor in compliance with the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1965, § 18-21) 
Sec. 9-96. - Application for permit required. 
    Applicants for permits under this division must file with the office of the City Manager an application in writing in duplicate on a form to be furnished by the office of the City Manager which shall give substantially the following information: 
(a)  Name of the applicant, type of organization, purpose of organization, and name and address of its presiding officer and other officers. 
(b)  Affiliation with any parent organization, if any. 
(c)  The nature of the solicitation to be made. 
(d)  The length of time for which the right to solicit is desired. 
(e)  The names of at least two (2) reliable Dade County property owners, who will certify as to the validity of the organization and its purposes; or in lieu of the names of references, such other available evidence as will establish the good character and responsibility of the applicant and its officers. 
(f)  The name and address of each person who is to solicit on behalf of the applicant and a statement as to whether or not any of such solicitors has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance, excepting traffic violations, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 18-22) 
Sec. 9-97. - Action on application. 
    Upon receipt of such application, the City Manager shall investigate the truth of the matters therein and shall endorse his approval on the application and execute a permit addressed to the applicant for the purpose applied for. Such permit shall contain the signature of the issuing officer and shall show the name and address of the applicant, date of issuance, and length of time same shall be operative, names and addresses of persons authorized to solicit on behalf of applicant, and such other information as shall be desirable and necessary. The City Manager shall keep a permanent record of all permits issued. 
(Code 1965, § 18-23) 
Sec. 9-98. - Identification cards. 
    The City shall issue to the permittee identification cards showing the name and address of the solicitor, and the name of the nonprofit organization on whose behalf solicitations are made, and the expiration date of the card, in letters and figures plainly discernible. Such identification card shall be worn constantly by the solicitor on the front of his outer garment in such a way as to be conspicuous during such time as said solicitor is engaged in solicitation. After expiration of the time for solicitation set forth in the permit, the identification cards shall be returned by the nonprofit organization to the City Manager. 
(Code 1965, § 18-24) 
Secs. 9-99-9-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GARAGE SALES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 86-01, § 1, adopted Feb. 5, 1986, amended the Code by the addition of Art. IA, §§ 9-2-9-7, which provisions have been redesignated and included herein at the discretion of the editor as Art. III, §§ 9-111-9-116 to facilitate classification and reference. 

Sec. 9-111. - Definitions. 
    [As used in this article the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed as follows:] 
(a)  Garage sales shall mean and include all sales entitled "garage sales," "lawn sale," "attic sale," "rummage sale," "flea market sale," or any similar casual sale of tangible personal property which is advertised by any means whereby the public at large is or can be made aware of said sale. 
(b)  Used tangible personal property is meant to include any goods, warehouse merchandise or other property capable of being the object of a sale regulated hereunder, and are not meant to include any such items which are acquired for resale. 
(c)  Person shall mean and include individuals, partnerships, voluntary associations, and corporations. 
(Ord. No. 86-01, § 1, 2-5-1986) 
Sec. 9-112. - License required; fee. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a garage sale in any use district in the City except in R-1 and R-2 after first filing with the Clerk the information hereinafter specified and obtaining from such Clerk a license to do so, to be known as a "garage sale license." The fee for such license shall be five dollars ($5.00). 
(Ord. No. 86-01, § 1, 2-5-1986) 
Sec. 9-113. - Issuance of license; display. 
    Such license shall be issued to owners and tenants for conducting a garage sale of used tangible personal property owned by them at the same premises and location only once in a four (4) month period, and no such license shall be issued for more than four (4) consecutive calendar days for such sales to be held between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on each of such days. 
    Each license issued under this article must be prominently displayed on the premises upon which the garage sale is conducted throughout the entire period of the licensed sale. 
(Ord. No. 86-01, § 1, 2-5-1986) 
Sec. 9-114. - Information required to be filed with Clerk. 
    The information to be filed with the Clerk, pursuant to this article, shall be as follows: 
(a)  Name of person, firm, group, corporation, association, or organization conducting said sale. 
(b)  Name of owner of the property on which said sale is to be conducted, and consent of owner if applicant is other than the owner. 
(c)  Location at which sale is to be conducted. 
(d)  Number of days of sale. 
(e)  Date, nature of any past sale. 
(f)  Whether or not applicant has been issued any other vendor's license by any local, state or federal agency. 
(g)  Sworn statement or affirmation by the person signing that the information therein given is full and true and known to him to be so. 
(Ord. No. 86-01, § 1, 2-5-1986) 
Sec. 9-115. - Persons and sale excepted from provisions of article. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to or affect the following persons or sales: 
(a)  Persons selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(b)  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials. 
(Ord. No. 86-01, § 1, 2-5-1986) 
Sec. 9-116. - Penalty. 
    Any person, association or corporation conducting any such sale without being properly licensed therefor or who shall violate any of the other terms and regulations of this article, shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or be imprisoned for a period of not to exceed ten (10) days for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 86-01, § 1, 2-5-1986) 
ARTICLE IV. - TOWING COMPANY LICENSING AND REGULATION 

Sec. 9-117. - Authority. 
    The provisions of this article are enacted pursuant to the statutory power of the City of West Miami, Florida, to establish and enforce business regulations necessary for the protection of the public and pursuant to Section 715.07(2)(b), Florida Statutes (1988), and Article III of Chapter 30 of the Code of Metropolitan Dade County, Florida. 
(Ord. No. 89-07, § 1, 9-20-1989) 
Sec. 9-118. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Towing Company Licensing and Regulation Ordinance of the City of West Miami." 
(Ord. No. 89-07, § 1, 9-20-1989) 
Sec. 9-119. - Purpose. 
(a)  It is hereby declared that, in order to provide for and safeguard the life, health, safety, property and welfare of the people of West Miami, the licensor and regulation of business enterprises engaged in the practice of recovering, towing, removing and storing of motor vehicles are matters affecting the public interest; and that, therefore, any person desiring to conduct such a business enterprise shall be required to obtain a regulatory license and obey the regulations as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  The purpose of this article is to provide a uniform system for the licensor [licensing] and regulation of business enterprises which are engaged in or which intend to engage in the practice of recovering, towing, removing, and storing of motor vehicles which are parked on private property without the permission of the owner of the private property. 
(Ord. No. 89-07, § 1, 9-20-1989) 
Sec. 9-120. - Definitions. 
    Business enterprise means a unit of economic organization or activity in the form of an individual natural person, sole proprietorship, corporation, partnership, organization, joint venture, trust, foundation, firm, group, society, association or any combination thereof whose systemic purposeful activity is the recovering, towing, removing and storing of parked vehicles from private real property at the express instruction of the owners of such real property. However, "business enterprise" shall not mean nor include in its meaning the term "property owner." 
    The Police Department, together with the licensing division of the City, are responsible for administering all licenses pursuant to this division. 
    Express instruction means a clear, definite and explicit prior written request on a format approved by the chief of police, by a property owner or agent to a business enterprise relating to a specific and individual vehicle parked without permission of the property owner. Such agent shall not be an officer or employee of the business enterprise (as defined herein). Copies of all written express instructions for towing shall be maintained by both the property owner or agent and the business enterprise to be made available for review by the Police Department. The term "express instruction" shall not mean a general request unrelated to a specific and individual vehicle or which precedes in time the actual parking of a vehicle. 
    License means that certificate or document itself which permits a business enterprise to engage in the activity of recovering, towing, removing and storing of parked vehicles from private real property at the express instruction of the owners of such real property. This license shall be in addition to any occupational license held by the business enterprise. 
    License division or license department means the City Clerk or her designee of the City of West Miami, Florida which is responsible for issuing licenses and collecting license fees. 
    Parked means the state of a vehicle being temporarily left unattended by its owner or operator. 
    Property owner means that person who exercises dominion and control over private real property, including, but not limited to, the legal titleholder, lessee, designated representative of a condominium association or any person authorized to exercise or share dominion and control over private real property. The property owner shall designate the name of any authorized agent giving express instructions for towing to the chief of police and the licensing department. However, "property owner" shall not mean nor be included in the term "business enterprise." 
    Recover means to take possession of a vehicle and its contents and to exercise control and supervision over the vehicle. 
    Regulation means a rule set forth within this article made applicable to business enterprises. The disobedience of a regulation shall be sufficient grounds for revocation of a license. 
    Removing means the act of changing by tow the location of a parked vehicle from its location on private real property to the storage site of the business enterprise. 
    Revoke means the action of the City Manager or his designee of the City, whereby a license is annulled and made void. 
    Storing means to place and to leave a towed vehicle at a site where the business enterprise exercises control and supervision over the vehicle. 
    Towing means to draw or pull along a vehicle behind by means of another vehicle equipped with booms, car carriers, winches or similar equipment. 
    Vehicle means a mobile item which normally uses wheels. 
(Ord. No. 89-07, § 1, 9-20-1989) 
Sec. 9-121. - License required; prohibition. 
(a)  No business enterprise shall engage in the business of recovering, towing, removing and storing of motor vehicles which are parked on private real property and parked without the permission of the owner of the private real property unless such business enterprise shall first apply for and obtain, and subsequently maintain in unrevoked status, a license issued pursuant to this article.
