(b)  The requirement for a license hereinabove described is a requirement separate and apart from and in addition to any County or municipal requirements for "occupational licenses" and Dade County Towing License under section 30-462 of the Dade County Code. The required license is a regulatory license and not a revenue license. 
(c)  Nothing herein shall be construed to mean that a natural person cannot work in or for such business enterprises without such license. There is no requirement that employees or agents of such business enterprises apply for and obtain the license provided for the by this article. The practice of a business enterprise to consider persons as independent contractors or employees shall not be construed to permit avoidance of the requirement that the business enterprise itself apply for, obtain, and maintain a license. 
(Ord. No. 89-07, § 1, 9-20-1989) 
Sec. 9-122. - Issuance of license and renewal. 
(a)  A license issued or renewed pursuant to the provisions of this article shall not be transferable from one (1) business enterprise to another business enterprise. All licenses shall expire on September 30 of each year following the date of original issuance. Licenses shall be renewable annually, There shall be license fees charged to each business enterprise of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) annually, which license fee may be increased or decreased as determined and established by resolution of the City Commission of the City of West Miami from time to time. 
(b)  Licenses shall be issued in the name of the business enterprise meeting the standards and requirements of licensor. 
(c)  A business enterprise which has met the standards and requirements for licensor and which is otherwise qualified for licensor may be issued a license. 
(d)  The license division shall issue a license conditioned upon an indication of approval of the application by the City Manager or his designee and upon collection of license fees by the license division. 
(e)  The Police Department shall issue decals to be displayed in a manner to be determined by the chief of police on all towing vehicles licensed under this part. 
(Ord. No. 89-07, § 1, 9-20-1989) 
Sec. 9-123. - Application, fees and standards. 
(a)  Application. All business enterprises desiring to obtain an initial license or renew a previously issued and unrevoked license shall submit an application in writing, along with a nonrefundable processing fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00), to the license division on all prescribed forms. The application and all supporting documents shall be retained by the license division. All applications shall include: 
(1)  Name of business enterprise; 
(2)  If the business enterprise is a corporation, the name, date and state under whose laws such corporation was organized, and if a foreign (out-of-state) corporation, whether authorized to do business in the State of Florida, the fictitious name under which the corporation may be doing business, the names of the principal officers, directors, resident agent and local representatives, and their business addresses; 
(3)  If the business enterprise is a partnership, the fictitious name under which the partnership may be doing business, the name, business address of each partner; 
(4)  If the business enterprise is a sole proprietorship, the fictitious name under which the sole proprietorship may be doing business, the name, business address of the natural person who owns, controls or directs the sole proprietorship; 
(5)  The signature of the president or vice-president of the applicant corporation; or, the signature of a partner of the applicant partnership, or, the signature of the natural person who owns, controls or directs the applicant sole proprietorship; and 
(6)  Such other information and data as the chief of police may consider appropriate. 
(b)  Standards for issuance of license. The City Manager or his designee shall approve the application for issuance or renewal of a license hereunder where he or his designee finds: 
(1)  That the application has been fully completed and submitted; and 
(2)  That the initial or renewal application fee has been paid; and 
(3)  That the applicant has been subject to a complete background investigation and found suitable by the chief of police to hold a license under this part; and 
(4)  That the applicant business enterprise, if a corporation does not have an officer or director, a person who is or was an officer, director, partner or sole proprietor of a business enterprise which has a currently suspended license or has had its license revoked by action of the City Manager or his designee of the City of West Miami, as of the date of application; and 
(5)  That the applicant business enterprise, if a partnership, does not have as a partner, a person who is or was an officer, director, partner or sole proprietor of a business enterprise which has a currently suspended license or has had its license revoked by action of the City Manager or his designee of the City of West Miami within five (5) years of the date of application; and 
(6)  That the applicant business enterprise, if a sole proprietorship, does not have as the sole proprietor, a person who is or was an officer, director, partner or sole proprietor of a business enterprise which has a currently suspended license or has had its license revoked by the City Manager or his designee of the City of West Miami within five (5) years of the date of application; and 
(7)  That a license of the applicant is not currently under suspension; and 
(8)  That the applicant's towing license with Dade County, Florida is in good standing and that the applicant has complied with any and all requirements of Ordinance No. 89-67, Article III of Chapter 30 of the Code of Metropolitan Dade County, Florida and Amendments thereto. 
(Ord. No. 89-07, § 1, 9-20-1989) 
Sec. 9-124. - Regulation and revocation of license. 
(a)  Investigations; proceedings. On its own motion or the written complaint of any person, the Police Department may investigate the action of a business enterprise licensed under this article and cause to be conducted a proceeding before the City Manager or his designee of the City of West Miami, to consider whether or not to revoke or suspend a license. At the license revocation or suspension proceeding, witnesses shall be sworn and the rules of evidence applicable to quasi-judicial proceedings shall govern. A finding of fact by the City Manager of the City of West Miami, or his designee, that a licensed business enterprise has not complied with a regulation as hereinafter set forth or has not complied with any other provisions of this article, shall be sufficient grounds for the City Manager or his designee of the City of West Miami to revoke or suspend the license of a business enterprise and that action shall be final. 
(b)  Regulations. No business enterprise licensed under this article shall: 
(1)  Recover or tow or remove or store a vehicle unless the business enterprise's tow truck or other vehicle used in towing shall clearly display in at least three (3) inch-high letters on trucks or other vehicles, the business enterprise's name, address, and telephone number on the driver and passenger side doors; or 
(2)  Recover or tow or remove or store a vehicle unless the business enterprise shall file, and keep on record with the City Clerk of the City of West Miami, and the Police Department (and shall post in a conspicuous and clearly visible location at the storage site) a complete copy of the rate schedule of the current rates charged for towing and storage of vehicles; additionally, copies of all written contracts or agreements between the business enterprise and property owners which relate to the towing and removal of vehicles shall be filed with the City Clerk of the City of West Miami and the West Miami Police Department within twenty-four (24) hours of execution; or 
(3)  Pay or rebate money, or solicit or offer the payment or rebate of money, or other valuable consideration, to property owners from which vehicles may be towed or removed; or 
(4)  a.  Recover or tow or remove or store a vehicle unless notice is posted fulfilling the following requirements: 
1.  Notice, in the form of a sign structure, shall be prominently placed at each driveway access or curb cut allowing vehicular access to the property, within five (5) feet from the public right-of-way line. If there are no curbs or access barriers, signs shall be posted not less than one (1) sign for each twenty-five (25) feet of lot frontage. 
2.  The notice shall clearly display: 
i.  In not less than two (2) inch high, light-reflective letters on a contrasting background, that "unauthorized vehicles" will be towed away at the owner's expense; and 
ii.  In not less than four (4) inch-high, light-reflective letters on a contrasting background, the words "tow-away zone"; and 
iii.  In not less than two (2) inch high, light-reflective letters on a contrasting background, the days of the week and hours of the day during which vehicles will be towed away at the owner's expense where the property owner or business enterprise selectively causes the towing of vehicles dependent on the day of the week and hour of the day the vehicle is parked and if not on a twenty-four (24) hour a day continuous basis; and 
iv.  In not less than two (2) inch-high, light-reflective letters on a contrasting background, the name and telephone number of the towing business enterprise, if there exists a written contract between the property owner and business enterprise for the towing of vehicles; and 
v.  In not less than one (1) inch-high, light-reflective letters on a contracting background, an address or description of the location of the storage site; and 
3.  The sign structure displaying the required notices shall be permanently installed with the bottom of the sign not less than four (4) feet above ground level and the top no more than six (6) feet above ground level, and shall be continuously maintained on the property for not fewer than twenty-four (24) hours before the towing removal of vehicles. 
b.  The posting of notice requirements of subsection 4(a) above shall not be required where: 
1.  The private property on which a vehicle is parked is property appurtenant to and obviously a part of single-family type residents; or 
2.  Notice is personally given to the owner or operator of the vehicle that the private property on which the vehicle is or will be parked is reserved or otherwise not available for unauthorized vehicles and subject to being removed at the owner's expense; or 
(5)  Recover or tow or remove or store a vehicle except upon the express written instruction to the business enterprise, or the property owner, lessee, condominium manager, apartment manager, authorized officer or board member of the condominium association, security guard, West Miami Police officer, or any other person duly authorized by the owner or lessee of the property, except as hereinafter provided. Such agent shall not be an officer or employee of the business enterprise (as defined herein). No such instruction shall be considered to have been given by the mere posting of the notice requirement of subsection 4(a) of this section. No such instruction shall be considered to have been given by virtue of the mere terms of any contract or agreement between a business enterprise and a property owner. No such instruction shall be considered to have been given where the instruction is general in nature and unrelated to specific, individual and identifiable vehicles which are already improperly parked; or 
(6)  Tow or remove or store a vehicle where the registered owner or other legally authorized person in control of the vehicle arrives at the scene of potential towing prior to towing or removal, except where: 
a.  The registered owner or other legally authorized person in control of the vehicle refuses to remove the vehicle; or 
b.  The vehicle is connected to the towing or removal apparatus and the registered owner or other person in control of the vehicle refuses to pay a reasonable service fee of not more than one-half (1/2) of the posted rate for such towing service as required by this article; or 
c.  Tow or remove a vehicle unless the towing vehicle displays, during connection and operation, the amber emergency lights authorized by Chapter 316 of the Florida Statutes. 
(7)  Tow or remove a vehicle where there is a natural person occupying the vehicle; or 
(8)  Recover or tow or remove or store a vehicle unless the business enterprise shall: 
a.  First obtain the express permission of the Police Department of the City of West Miami; and 
b.  Upon such express permission being obtained, the business enterprise shall provide the Police Department of the City of West Miami, within thirty (30) minutes of the completion of the removal, recover, and towing, the information concerning: 
1.  The storage site; 
2.  The time the vehicle was towed or removed; 
3.  The make, model, color, and license plate number of the vehicle; and, 
c.  Obtain the name and badge number of the officer of the Police Department of the City of West Miami to whom such information was reported and indicate that name on a trip record, together with an indication of the date and time of the day in hours and minutes that the vehicle was removed; or 
(9)  Recover or tow or remove or store a vehicle unless the business enterprise shall maintain trip record(s) for a minimum of the previous twelve (12) months of operation, under this part. The trip record(s) shall legibly indicate at a minimum: 
a.  The name of the business enterprise; 
b.  The date and times of the day in hours and minutes when a specific vehicle was recovered, towed, removed and stored; 
c.  The make, model, color, and license plate number of the specific vehicle(s); 
d.  The precise address or description of the location from which the specific vehicle(s) was removed; 
e.  The full name of the property owner who expressly instructed the removal of the specific vehicle(s); and 
f.  The precise address or description of the location of the storage site of the business enterprise to which the specific vehicle(s) was removed and stored; or 
(10)  Recover or tow or remove or store a vehicle unless the vehicle shall be towed directly to the business enterprise's storage site and the vehicle shall not be kept in any temporary holding area; or 
(11)  Store or impound a towed vehicle at a distance that exceeds a five (5) mile radius of the location from which the vehicle was recovered, towed and removed; however, notwithstanding the foregoing, where there is no business enterprise licensed under this article that is located within a five (5) mile radius of the location from which the vehicle might be recovered, towed, and removed, then in that event, no business enterprise licensed under this article shall store or impound a towed vehicle at a distance that exceeds a ten (10) mile radius of the location from which the vehicle was recovered, towed, and removed; or 
(12)  Recover or tow or remove or store a vehicle unless the business enterprise shall permit the registered owner to enter on the storage site and remove and take into his possession and carry away whatever goods, chattels, things, and documents are contained within the stored vehicle; or 
(13)  Store or impound a vehicle unless a receipt acknowledging the legal obligations of the business enterprise is given to the owner or driver upon release of the vehicle; or 
(14)  Use physical force or violence, or threat of physical force or violence, in dealing with persons who have had or are about to have their vehicles recovered or towed or removed or stored. 
(Ord. No. 89-07, § 1, 9-20-1989) 
Sec. 9-125. - Rates. 
    The rate(s) charged for the towing and storage of motor vehicle(s) parked on private property without the property owner's permission shall not exceed the amount of sixty dollars ($60.00) for towing and five dollars ($5.00) per day for storage of which the business enterprise shall pay to the City of West Miami, the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) for administration cost. 
(Ord. No. 89-07, § 1, 9-20-1989) 
ARTICLE V. - HOTEL AND MOTEL LICENSING AND REGULATIONS 

Sec. 9-126. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    Hotel is any unit, dwelling, building, or group of buildings within a single complex of buildings, which is kept, used, maintained, or advertised as, or held out to the public to be, a place where sleeping or housekeeping accommodations are supplied for pay to transient or permanent guests or tenants, and which is recognized as a hotel by the public or by the industry. 
    License division or license department means the City Clerk or designee of the City of West Miami, Florida, which is responsible for issuing licenses and collecting license fees. 
    Motel is any unit, dwelling, building, or group of buildings within a single complex of buildings, which is kept, used, maintained, or advertised as, or held out to the public to be, a place where sleeping or housekeeping accommodations are supplied for pay to transient or permanent guests or tenants which offer rental units with an exit to the outside of each rental unit, daily or weekly rates, off-street parking for each unit, a central office on the property with specified hours of operation, a bathroom or connecting bathroom for each rental unit which is recognized as a motel in the community in which it is situated or by the industry. 
    Operator means the owner, licensee, proprietor, lessee, manager, assistant manager or appointed agent of a hotel or motel establishment. 
(Ord. No. 92-01, § 1, 1-8-1992) 
Sec. 9-127. - Duties of Police Department. 
    The Police Department shall carry out all of the provisions of this article and all other laws relating to the inspection or regulation of hotel and motel establishments, for the purpose of safeguarding the public health, safety and welfare. The Police Department shall be responsible for ascertaining that no hotel or motel licensed by the City, engage in any misleading advertising or unethical practices. 
(Ord. No. 92-01, § 1, 1-8-1992) 
Sec. 9-128. - Inspection of premises. 
    The Police Department or its designee, may inspect each hotel or motel establishment and for that purpose the Police Department or its designee shall have the right of entry and access to such establishments at any reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. 92-01, § 1, 1-8-1992) 
Sec. 9-129. - Maintenance of guest register. 
    It is the duty of each operator of a hotel or motel establishment renting to transit guests, to maintain at all times a register, signed by each guest who occupies rental units within the establishment, showing the name, permanent address, times and dates on each occupancy by such guest of any rental unit, and the rates charged for their occupancy. The register shall be maintained in chronological order and available for inspection by the Police Department or its designee at any time. Operators need not make available registers which are more than two (2) years old. Each operator shall maintain at all times, a current copy of this article in the office of the establishment, which shall be made available to the public upon request. 
(Ord. No. 92-01, § 1, 1-8-1992) 
Sec. 9-130. - Conduct on premises; refusal of service. 
    The operator of a public hotel or motel establishment may refuse accommodations to any person whose conduct on the premises of the establishment displays intoxication, profanity, lewdness, or brawling; who indulges in language or conduct such as to disturb the peace or comfort of other guests; who engage in illegal or disorderly conduct; who illegally possesses or deals in control substance as defined in chapter 893, Florida Statutes; or whose conduct constitutes a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 92-01, § 1, 1-8-1992) 
Sec. 9-131. - Disorderly conduct on the premises of an establishment; detention; arrest; immunity from liability. 
    A law enforcement officer may arrest, either on or off the premises of the hotel or motel establishment and without a warrant, any person the officer has probable cause to believe the person was engaging in disorderly conduct in violation of Section 877.03, Florida Statutes, on the premises of the licensed hotel or motel establishment and in the course of such violation, created a threat to life or safety of the person or others. A law enforcement officer who makes an arrest under the foregoing subsection, is not civilly or criminally liable for false arrest or false imprisonment or both. A person who resists reasonable efforts of a law enforcement officer to detain or arrest that person in accordance with this section, shall upon conviction be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or be imprisoned for not more than sixty (60) days or shall be both fined and imprisoned in the discretion of the court. 
(Ord. No. 92-01, § 1, 1-8-1992) 
Sec. 9-132. - License required; annual renewals. 
(a)  No hotel and motel business establishment shall engage in the business of rental of hotel and motel rooms and facilities without first filing application, initial or renewal, with the City Clerk of the City of West Miami and obtaining a license from the City to engage in such business. 
(b)  Such license may not be transferred from one (1) place or one (1) individual to another. 
(c)  The City shall refuse a license or renewal thereof to any establishment that is not constructed, operated and maintained in accordance with applicable federal, State, County and municipal laws and the rules of the division of hotel and restaurants of the Department of Business Regulations of the State of Florida. The City shall refuse to issue a license or renewal thereof to any establishment and operator of which, within the proceeding five (5) years, has been adjudicated guilty of or has forfeited a bond when charged with, any crime reflecting on professional character, including soliciting for prostitution, pandering, letting premises for prostitution, keeping a disorderly place, or illegally dealing in control substance as defined in chapter 893, Florida Statutes, whether in this State or any other jurisdiction within the United States, or has had a license denied, revoked, or suspended by any applicable federal, State, County or municipal agencies. 
(d)  Licenses shall be renewed annually on or before October 1 of each and every year. 
(e)  The requirements for the license herein provided are requirements separate and apart from and in addition to the license requirements for City occupational license under section 9-1 of article I [of] this chapter. The required license under this article is a regulatory license and not a revenue license. 
(Ord. No. 92-01, § 1, 1-8-1992) 
Sec. 9-133. - Application, fees and standards. 
(a)  Any person desiring to operate a hotel or motel shall obtain an initial license or renew a previously issued and unrevoked license and shall submit an application along with a nonrefundable processing fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) annually to the licensing division in the form prescribed by the licensing division. The application and all supporting documents shall be retained by the licensing division. All application shall include: 
(1)  Name of establishment; 
(2)  If establishment is a corporation, the name, date and state under whose laws such corporation was organized, and if a foreign (out-of-state) corporation, whether such corporation is authorized to do business in the State of Florida, the fictitious name under which the corporation may be doing business, the name of the principal officers, directors, resident agent and local representatives, and their business addresses; 
(3)  If the establishment is a partnership, the partnership name under which the partnership may be doing business, the name, business address of each partner; 
(4)  If the establishment is a sole proprietorship, the name under which the sole proprietorship may be doing business, the name, business address of the natural person who owns, controls or directs the sole proprietorship; 
(5)  The signature of the president or vice-president of the applicant corporation or the signature of a partner of the applicant partner, or the signature of the nature person who owns, controls or directs the applicant sole proprietorship; and 
(6)  Number of rental units in each establishment; and 
(7)  Date of proposed commencement of operation, if initial application; and 
(8)  Such other information or data that the City Manager or chief of police may consider appropriate for his background investigation. 
(b)  Standards for issuance of license. The City Manager or designee, shall approve the application for issuance or renewal of a license hereunder where he or his designee finds: 
(1)  That the application has been fully completed and submitted; and 
(2)  The initial or renewal application fee has been paid; and 
(3)  The applicant has been subject to a complete background investigation by the chief of police or his designee, and has been found to be of good moral character, or that applicant, if a corporation, does not have an officer or director, who is or was an officer, director, partner or sole proprietor of a hotel or motel establishment which has a currently suspended license or has had a license revoked by action of the City Manager or his designee of the City of West Miami as of the date of the application; and 
(4)  That the applicant, if a partnership, does not have a partner who is or was an officer, director, partner or sole proprietor of a hotel or motel establishment which has a currently suspended license or has had a license revoked by action of the City Manager or his designee of the City of West Miami within five (5) years of the date of the application; and 
(5)  That the applicant, if a sole proprietorship, does not have a sole proprietor who is or was an officer, director, partner or sole proprietor of a hotel or motel establishment which has a currently suspended license or has had its license revoked by the City Manager or his designee of the City of West Miami within five (5) years of the date of application; and 
(6)  That the license of the applicant is not currently under suspension; and 
(7)  That the applicant has all licenses in good standing with the State of Florida, County of Dade and City of West Miami. 
(Ord. No. 92-01, § 1, 1-8-1992) 
Sec. 9-134. - License fees. 
    In addition to the application fee, there shall be a regulatory license fee charged to each hotel and motel establishment of two dollars ($2.00) for each occupancy per day or less of each rental unit, payable to the City on or before the tenth day of the following month. There shall be a late fee of five (5) percent if not paid on the due date. In the event any rental unit is rented more than once per day, then and in that event, each change of occupancy shall require an additional two dollars ($2.00) per change of occupancy per day. Said license fee may be increased or decreased as determined and established by resolution of the City Commission from time to time. Licenses shall be issued in the name of the hotel or motel establishment meeting the standards and requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 92-01, § 1, 1-8-1992) 
Sec. 9-135. - Display of license. 
    Any license issued by the City shall be conspicuously displayed in the office or lobby of the licensed establishment. 
(Ord. No. 92-01, § 1, 1-8-1992) 
Sec. 9-136. - Revocation or suspension of license; fines, costs, investigation; proceedings and appeals. 
    On its own motion or the written complaint of any person, the Police Department may investigate the action of a hotel or motel establishment licensed under this article and may cause to be conducted a proceeding before the City Manager or his designee of the City of West Miami, to consider and determine whether or not a violation or violations of this article has occurred. A notice of the time and place of the proceedings shall be delivered or mailed by certified mail to the operator of the subject hotel or motel establishment at its street address in the City of West Miami, where such establishment is operating, at least fifteen (15) days before the commencement of the proceeding. At the proceeding, witnesses shall be sworn and the rules of evidence applicable to quasi judicial proceedings shall govern and the operator of said establishment shall be given an opportunity to be heard. 
    A finding of fact by the City Manager of the City of West Miami, or his designee, that the licensed establishment has violated any provisions of this article or has not complied with any other applicable federal, State, County or municipal laws or ordinances or any rules and regulations shall be sufficient grounds for the City Manager or his designee, to revoke or suspend the license of the hotel or motel establishment and/or fine the licensee in an amount not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) payable to the City. Such fine shall be in addition to any other penalties that may be imposed. In such event, the City Manager or his designee shall assess the costs of the proceedings against the establishment. 
    Upon a determination that there has been a violation of section 9-129 of this article, the City Manager or his designee shall issue a written reprimand and a warning on the first violation, a thirty (30) day suspension of license for the second violation, and revocation of the license for the third violation. 
    Any decision of the City Manager or his designee shall be final, unless within thirty (30) days an appeal from such findings of fact are made to the City Commission. At its next meeting, the matter shall then be reviewed solely upon the record of the proceedings before the City Manager or his designee. 
    Any aggrieved person, agent or representative, filing an appeal from the decision of the City Manager or his designee shall pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) and a deposit of three hundred dollars ($300.00) to cover the cost of transcribing the proceedings to the City Clerk upon filing such appeal. Upon such payment, an appeal shall stay all proceedings in the matter appealed from except if there is a fine imposed, said fine shall be paid to the City Clerk at the time of filing the appeal. In the event the City Commission reverses the decision of the City Manager or his designee, then and in that event said fine shall be refunded. 
(Ord. No. 92-01, § 1, 1-8-1992) 
Secs. 9-137-9-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CARWASHES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- This article was originally established by Ordinance No. 99-04, adopted on September 9, 1999, and later repealed by Ordinance No. 2001-02, adopted on April 18, 2001. 

Sec. 9-156. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Hand carwashes means business not utilizing machinery that automatically sprays water and detergents upon automobiles or that utilize electric or electronic fans and/or turbines and that will utilize human effort to spray water and detergents upon automobiles and will use human effort for the drying of the automobiles. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 2, 4-18-2001) 
Sec. 9-157. - Incidental use. 
    Hand carwashes shall be located and permitted only at automobile service stations or automobile mechanical garages within commercially zoned (C use) districts. Said use shall be considered an incidental use to the sale of gasoline or maintenance of an automotive vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 3, 4-18-2001) 
Sec. 9-158. - Special use permit. 
    In addition to zoning procedures and requirements relating to the issuances of permits and certificates of use, all hand carwashes shall obtain a special use permit as defined in section 2(a) of City of West Miami Zoning Ordinance No. 282. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 4, 4-18-2001) 
Sec. 9-159. - Existing carwashes. 
    All existing carwashes within the City shall conform its operations with the terms and conditions of the now existing Codes of Ordinances and the terms and conditions of this article. All establishments that had valid occupational licenses on the date of the passage of Ordinance No. 99-04 shall be allowed to continue to operate without conforming to this article until January 31, 2002. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 5, 4-18-2001; Ord. No. 2001-06, § 1, 11-28-2001) 
Sec. 9-160. - Minimum standards of operation. 
    Notwithstanding section 2(a) of City of West Miami Zoning Ordinance No. 282, all hand carwashes within the City shall operate under the minimum standards as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 6, 4-18-2001) 
Sec. 9-161. - Operation of carwashes. 
    All hand carwashes shall operate adjacent to the building and/or structure as defined in section 9-157 under a canopy, not permanent in nature, to be removed on a daily basis at the end of the hours of operation. There shall be a minimum setback of seventy-five (75) feet from the work station or said canopy to the nearest residential dwelling. All hand carwashes must be approved through a special use permit procedure. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 7, 4-18-2001) 
Sec. 9-162. - Noise pollution. 
    Noise pollution is strictly prohibited and all machinery shall be of such construction as to muzzle sound as not to disturb the peace and tranquility of adjacent residential neighborhoods. 
(1)  Hand-operated buffers shall be designed and used so as to muffle motor noise to the greatest extent possible, and may only be operated within the previously described structure. 
(2)  Hand-operated vacuum cleaners shall be designed and used so as to muffle motor noise to the greatest extent possible and must be operated at least seventy-five (75) feet from any residential dwelling and shall have off mechanisms as to disengage when not in operation. 
(3)  Hand-operated steam cleaning or pressure cleaning equipment shall be designed and used so as to muffle motor noise to the greatest extent possible, and may only be operated within the previously described structure. Said equipment shall be turned off when not in actual use. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 8, 4-18-2001) 
Sec. 9-163. - Walls. 
    Hand carwash use shall not be allowed on properties which are not in conformance with section 4.32-7 of the City of West Miami Zoning Ordinance No. 282. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 9, 4-18-2001) 
Sec. 9-164. - Displays. 
    There shall be no articles of sale displayed or merchandise outside of the carwash structure. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 10, 4-18-2001) 
Sec. 9-165. - Prohibition of rental, sale or storage of any vehicle. 
    Any rental, sale or storage of vehicle inside or adjacent to a carwash structure is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 11, 4-18-2001) 
Sec. 9-166. - Signs. 
    All carwash signs must be approved by the Planning and Zoning Department and must conform to section 14 of the City of West Miami Zoning Ordinance No. 282. The display of banners are prohibited at any carwash location. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 12, 4-18-2001) 
Sec. 9-167. - Cleaning equipment. 
    All cleaning equipment including rags, cleansers and bottles shall be stored inside an enclosed area. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 13, 4-18-2001) 
Sec. 9-168. - Licensing. 
    All hand carwash uses shall be separately licensed (occupational license) and zoning certificate of use by owner/operator of the principal use. Said license shall be applied for and approved by the City. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 14, 4-18-2001) 
Sec. 9-169. - Hours of operation. 
    Hand carwash uses shall only be in operation from Monday through Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. and Saturdays and Sundays from 9:30 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 15, 4-18-2001; Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 10-19-2011) 
Sec. 9-170. - Sales tax records. 
    The licensee of a hand carwash establishment shall maintain adequate required sales tax records and the City shall be authorized to examine all sales tax receipts of any carwash on a quarterly basis (i.e., March 30, June 30, September 30 and December 30). 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 16, 4-18-2001) 
Sec. 9-171. - Motor or undercarriage cleaning. 
    No cleaning, steam cleaning or pressure cleaning of automobile engines or undercarriages shall be allowed as a part of hand carwash uses. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 17, 4-18-2001) 
Sec. 9-172. - Vehicle types. 
    Hand carwash operators may wash automobiles, sports utility vehicles, pickup trucks, small vans and boats on trailers. All other vehicle types are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2001-02, art. 18, 4-18-2001) 
Sec. 9-173. - Car wash requirements. 
(a)  It is unlawful to throw, drain, run or otherwise discharge any industrial waste, liquid waste or other waste into a system designed to carry storm water. Similarly, it is unlawful to throw, drain, run or otherwise discharge any storm water into a sanitary sewer. 
(b)  In order to segregate storm water from industrial waste or liquid waste generated at a car wash and facilitate their correct handling and disposal, the following minimum requirements shall be incorporated into all car wash facilities: 
(1)  Car washing operations shall be conducted over an impervious area no smaller than twelve (12) feet by eighteen (18) feet. 
(2)  A berm or curb (of a minimum of four (4) inches in height) must be constructed around the wash stall in order to prevent industrial or liquid waste from flowing out of the stall into the stormwater sewer system or stormwater from entering the wash stall and the sanitary sewer system. 
(3)  A roof with a minimum two (2) feet overhang beyond the berm or curb must be installed and properly maintained over the wash stall on all sides to prevent rainwater intrusion. 
(4)  The industrial or liquid waste generated by the car wash operation must be discharged to the sanitary sewer system through an oil interceptor and with minimum capacity of seven hundred fifty (750) gallons (unless a self-contained water recycling system is used). 
No waste other than domestic sewage may be discharged to septic tanks. For car wash operations located on properties not served by sanitary sewers, a self-contained water recycling system must be installed. (Car wash recycling systems must have a general permit from the Florida Department of Environmental [Protection]. 
(5)  An easily accessible sampling point must be provided at the industrial waste discharge pipe at a point beyond which no further pretreatment is provided and prior to discharge to the sanitary sewer system to ascertain compliance with the sanitary sewer discharge standards stipulated in Section 24-11(9) of the Code of Metropolitan Dade County. 
(c)  If water hoses are used during the operation, the hose bib shall be protected by a vacuum breaker to prevent back-siphonage. In addition, a self-canceling or self-closing nozzle must be attached to the hose to minimize water usage. 
(1)  Additional administrative restrictions may be imposed during water shortage emergencies, or in accordance with other municipal, county or water management district water conservation requirements. 
(d)  The restrictions on use, generation, handling, disposal, discharge or storage of hazardous materials within any wellfield protection area apply. 
(e)  The applicant must: 
(1)  Obtain plan approval from the Department of Environmental and Regulatory Affairs of Miami-Dade County prior to the start of construction. A complete set of plans is needed for the Department's record. 
(2)  Existing car wash operators shall obtain approval of their operations by the Department of Environmental and Regulatory Affairs of Miami-Dade County. 
(f)  This policy applies to car washing operations only not operations using or discharging degreasers, solvents or other chemicals associated with pressure or steam cleaning of engines or the undercarriage. Operations engaged in degreasing or pressure/steam cleaning require an Industrial Waste Permit and further pretreatment of their waste. These types of operations are not allowed inside the average day or basic wellfield protection area of any public water supply wellfield. 
(g)  This policy does not apply to isolated one-day fund-raising car washes. 
(h)  All car wash applications must follow the county standards. 
(i)  All car washes must have a minimum of one thousand (1,000) feet distance from another car wash. (This policy applies only to new applications.) 
(j)  Hand carwash uses shall only be in operation from Monday through Friday from 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. and Saturdays and Sundays from 9:30 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 
(k)  Car washes shall not be permitted to play music which projects to the residential areas neighboring the car wash. 
(l)  Car washes shall follow the City of West Miami's alcoholic beverage laws at all times during its operation. 
(m)  Any violation of this ordinance by the car wash operator shall carry a fine in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense and double that amount for any offense(s) thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 2011-07, § 1, 10-19-2011) 
Chapter 10 - OFFENSES-MISCELLANEOUS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Regulations governing conduct in parks, § 11-36 et seq. 
County Code references- Offenses against Dade County generally, MDCC Ch. 21; uniform county penal ordinance, § 21-80 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Adoption of State misdemeanors. 
    Every offense which is defined by the Florida Statutes as a crime and is punishable as a misdemeanor is hereby adopted as a penal ordinance by the City; and any person violating any of said penal laws, which are punishable as misdemeanors, within the City, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided by section 1-9. 
(Code 1965, § 14-1) 
County Code reference- Similar provision, MDCC § 21-81. 
Sec. 10-2. - Trespassing upon private property by parking vehicles thereon. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to commit a trespass within this Municipality on the private property of another by parking any vehicle thereon in violation of a notice posted or exhibited thereon at any point or approach or entry or in violation of any notice, warning or protest given orally or in writing by any owner or occupant thereon. 
(Ord. No. 84-01, § 1, 5-16-1984) 
Sec. 10-3. - Hurricane precautions. 
    Upon the issuance of an advisory by the U.S. Weather Service alerting the Dade County area to a hurricane condition, every owner of any lot, tract, or parcel of land, occupied as well as unoccupied, within the City, shall securely tie down all loose lumber, trash, and other materials located on his property. 
(Code 1965, § 10-4) 
Sec. 10-4. - Noise prohibited generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise or any noise which either annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others. 
(Code 1965, § 14-20) 
Cross reference- Regulation of music and entertainment at alcoholic beverage establishments, § 3-15; noise prohibited in parks, § 11-66. 
County Code reference- Similar provisions, MDCC § 21-28. 
Sec. 10-5. - Noise; specific acts prohibited. 
    The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises in violation of this Code, and unlawful, but said enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive: 
(a)  Horns, signaling device, etc. The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, motorcycle, bus or other vehicle on any street or public place of the town, except as a danger warning; the creation by means of any such signaling device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; and the sounding of any such device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time; the use of any signaling device except one operated by hand or electricity; the use of any horn, whistle or other device operated by engine exhaust; and the use of any such signaling device when traffic is for any reason held up. 
(b)  Radios, phonographs, etc. The using, operating or permitting to be played, used or operated any radio receiving set, television set, musical instrument, phonograph, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for the person or persons who are in the room, vehicle or chamber in which such machine or device is operated and who are voluntary listeners thereto. The operation of any such set, instrument, phonograph, machine or device between the hours of 11 p.m. and 7 a.m. Monday through Sunday in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of fifty (50) feet from the building, structure, or vehicle in which it is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section; provided, however, that establishments vending alcoholic beverages shall be governed by section 3-15. 
(c)  Loudspeakers, amplifiers for advertising. The using, operating or permitting to be played, used, or operated of any radio receiving set, television set, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound which is cast upon the public streets for the purpose of commercial advertising or attracting the attention of the public to any building or structure; provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed as a prohibition against the use and operation of loudspeakers or amplifiers or other machines or devices for producing or reproducing of sound when such equipment is used in conjunction with parades, charitable affairs or municipal uses or purposes, for which proper permits have been issued by the municipal authorities. 
(d)  Yelling, shouting, etc. Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling, or singing on the public streets, between the hours of 11 p.m. and 7 a.m. Monday through Sunday, or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort, or repose of persons in any office, or in any dwelling, hotel or other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity. 
(e)  Animals, birds, etc. The keeping of any animal or bird which by causing frequent or long continued noise shall disturb the comfort or repose of any persons in the vicinity. 
Cross reference- Barking dogs prohibited, § 4-24. 
(f)  Reserved. 
(g)  Exhaust. The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine or motorboat, except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
(h)  Defect in vehicle or load. The use of any automobile, motorcycle, or vehicle so out of repair, so loaded or in such manner as to create loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noise. 
(i)  Loading, unloading, opening boxes. The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle or the opening and destruction of bales, boxes, creates, and containers. 
(j)  Construction or repairing of buildings. The erection (including excavating), demolition, alteration or repair of any building is strictly prohibited between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 9:30 a.m. Monday through Saturday, and permitted from 12:00 noon through 6:00 p.m. on Sundays, except in case of urgent necessity in the interest of public health and safety, and then only with a permit from the Building Official, which permit may be granted for a period not to exceed three (3) days or less while the emergency continues and which permit may be renewed for periods of three (3) days or less while the emergency continues. If the Building Official should determine that the public health and safety will not be impaired by the erection, demolition, alteration or repair of any building or the excavation of streets and highways within the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 9:30 a.m. Monday through Saturday, and permitted from 12:00 noon through 6:00 p.m. on Sundays, and if he shall further determine that loss or inconvenience would result to any party in interest, he may grant permission for such work to be done within the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 9:30 a.m. Monday through Saturday, and permitted from 12:00 noon through 6:00 p.m. on Sundays, upon application being made at the time the permit for the work is awarded or during the progress of the work. 
(k)  Schools, courts, churches, hospitals. The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church or court while the same are in use, or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the workings of such institution, or which disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospital, provided conspicuous signs are displayed in such street indicating that the same is a church, school, hospital or court street. 
(l)  Hawkers, peddlers. The shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers and vendors which disturbs the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. 
Cross reference- Regulation of peddlers generally, § 9-70 et seq. 
(m)  Drums, etc. The use of any drum or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention, by creation of noise, to any performance, show or sale; provided, however, that nothing herein shall be construed as a prohibition against the use and operation of drums or other instruments or devices for the purpose of attracting attention by creation of noise when such equipment is used in conjunction with parades, charitable affairs or municipal uses or purposes, for which proper permits have been issued by the municipal authorities. 
(n)  Metal rails, pillars and columns, transportation thereof. The transportation of rails, pillars or columns of iron, steel or other material, over and along streets and other public places upon carts, drays, cars, trucks, or in any other manner so loaded as to cause loud noises or as to disturb the peace and quiet of such streets or other public places. 
(o)  Pile drivers, hammers, etc. The operation between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 9:30 a.m. Monday through Saturday, and permitted from 12:00 noon through 6:00 p.m. on Sundays of any pile driver, steam shovel, pneumatic hammer, derrick, steam or electric hoist or other appliance, the use of which is attended by loud or unusual noise. 
(p)  Blowers. The operation of any noise-creating blower or power fan for any internal combustion engine, the operation of which causes noise due to the explosion of operating gases or fluids, unless the noise from such blower or fan is muffled and such engine is equipped with a muffler device sufficient to deaden such noise. 
(q)  Landscaping equipment and power tools; prohibiting the use of any such equipment between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 9:30 a.m. Monday through Saturday, and permitted from 12:00 noon through 6:00 p.m. on Sundays. 
(Code 1965, § 14-21; Ord. No. 2012-01, § 1, 4-4-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-01, §§ 1 and 2, adopted April 4, 2012, amended § 10-5 and established a fine of $100.00 per incident and/or per day on each violation of said section. 
County Code reference- Specific noisy activities prohibited, MDCC § 21-28. 
State Law reference- Mufflers and motor vehicle noise, F.S. §§ 316.272, 316.293, 403.415. 
Sec. 10-6. - Obstructing City officers, giving false information. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to obstruct or oppose any officer of the City, or other legally authorized person, in the execution of legal process or in the lawful execution of any legal duty, or knowingly to give false, untrue or misleading information upon inquiry by an officer of the City regarding the whereabouts or identity of a person for whom said officer shall have a warrant. 
(Code 1965, § 16-6) 
State Law reference- Neglect or refusal to aid peace officer, F.S. § 843.06. 
Sec. 10-7. - Planting trees, shrubs on City property. 
    No person other than duly authorized town personnel shall plant any tree, shrub, or other plant upon municipal property owned by the City, other than upon public parkways as provided in section 13-34, without first obtaining the permission of the City Manager. 
(Code 1965, § 19-4) 
Cross reference- Trees and shrubs near public ways, § 13-32 et seq. 
Sec. 10-8. - Posting notices. 
    No person shall post or affix any notice, poster or other paper or device, calculated to attract the attention of the public, to any lamppost, public utility pole or tree, or upon any public structure or building, except as may be authorized or required by law. 
(Code 1965, § 9-45) 
Cross reference- Posting or distributing political matter on city property, § 2-40. 
Sec. 10-9. - Spitting on public places. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to expectorate upon any sidewalk or upon the floor of any store, public building or public hall in the City. 
(Code 1965, § 14-5) 
Sec. 10-10. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-09, § 1, adopted Dec. 7, 2011 repealed § 10-10, which pertained to weapons and gas devices; carrying prohibited and derived from Code 1965, § 14-6. 
Sec. 10-11. - Temporary political signs in residential districts; number, size and location. 
(a)  No temporary political signs shall be allowed in any residential district within the City of West Miami except that one temporary political sign shall be allowed on the premises upon which the sign is displayed, which sign shall not exceed two (2) inches [feet] in height and three (3) inches [feet] in width and shall be placed no less than twenty-five (25) feet behind the front setback line of the property or adjacent to the main residential structure containing its front entrance, whichever is less. 
(b)  No temporary political signs shall be allowed in any commercial area within the City except that temporary political sign which shall be allowed in commercial premises upon which signs are displayed which shall not be more than eighteen (18) by twenty (20) inches, located inside the plate glass window of each business facing the street. 
(Ord. No. 86-02, § 1, 4-2-1986; Ord. No. 94-05, 9-21-1994) 
Sec. 10-12. - Penalty for violation of section 10-11. 
    Any person violating section 10-11 of this Code, including but not limited to, the property owner and person in possession of the premises where the violation occurs and any candidate who authorizes or permits such violation, shall, upon conviction, be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day that such violation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 86-02, § 1, 4-2-1986) 
Sec. 10-13. - Defacement of property; possession of aerosol paint cans and broadtipped felt markers; penalties. 
(a)  No person shall write, paint, or draw any inscription, figure, or mark of any type on any public or private building or other structure, or any other real or personal property, owned, operated, or maintained by a governmental entity or any agency or instrumentality thereof or by a person, firm, or corporation, unless the express permission of the owner or operator of the property has been obtained. 
(b)  No person shall carry an aerosol spray paint can containing a substance which is not water soluble, or broad-tipped indelible marker upon or into any public or private building, facility or structure with the intent to violate the provisions of subsection (a) above. 
(c)  For the purpose of this section, the term "broad-tipped indelible marker" means any felt-tip marker, or similar implement, which contains a fluid which is not water soluble and which has a flat or angled writing surface one-half (1/2) inch or greater. 
(d)  The parents or legal guardian of any minor found guilty of such offense shall be liable for full financial restitution. Offending minors shall also be sentenced to monitored community service hours at the judge's discretion. 
(e)  Adult offenders shall be responsible for full financial restitution and community service hours as specified above. 
(Ord. No. 88-09, § 1, 10-20-1988) 
Sec. 10-14. - Exception allowing pony rides, disc jockey or other outdoor entertainment; permit fees; standards and conditions. 
    Nothing in any provision of the Code and ordinances of the City of West Miami shall be construed as a prohibition against the use and operation of pony rides, disc jockey and other outdoor entertainment using loud speakers, sound amplifiers, musical instruments, phonographs, sound tapes, musical compact disks, or other machine system equipment or device for the producing or reproducing of sound which is cast upon the public streets for the purpose of commercial advertising, entertainment or attracting the attention of the public to any commercial business or establishment in commercial districts, provided and conditioned upon the following: 
(a)  A permit shall be obtained from the City Manager before commencement of such use, operation, activity or event. 
(b)  A permit for pony rides shall allow one (1) event per day per calendar month during the house of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. and the permit fee for such event shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) per day per calendar month. 
(c)  A permit for disc jockey or other outdoor musical entertainment shall allow one (1) event per day per week per calendar month during the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., and the permit fee for such event shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) per day. 
(d)  A permit fee shall be charged in the sum of thirty dollars ($30.00) per day per event, where both disc jockey or outdoor musical entertainment occur on the same day. 
(e)  A person seeking issuance of a permit hereunder shall file an application with the City Clerk and pay such permit fee. Where the applicant is a tenant, the landlord shall consent to the application. The application shall state: 
(1)  The name and address of applicant; 
(2)  The name and address and telephone number of all persons participating in the operation of the event. 
(3)  The day and hours for which the permit is desired. 
(4)  The location and area for which such permit is desired with attachment of a sketch showing location of the area of intended use or operation, including but not limited to the buildings, structures, parking lot, pedestrian walkways, landscape, driveways, egress and ingress to buildings, public streets and sidewalks. 
(5)  Any other information which the City Manager shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should issue hereunder. 
(f)  Standards for permit issuance. The City Manager shall issue hereunder when he finds: 
(1)  That the proposed activity or use applied for will not reasonably interfere with or endanger the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(2)  That the proposed activity or use is not reasonably anticipated to incite violence, crimes or disorderly conduct. 
(3)  That the proposed activity or use will not entail unusual, extraordinary or burdensome expense or police or other operation by the City. 
(4)  That all conditions of this section 10-14 are complied with. 
(Ord. No. 91-05, § 1, 8-7-1991) 
Cross reference- Music and entertainment in alcoholic beverage establishments, § 3-15; barking dogs, § 4-24; general noise prohibitions, § 10-4; specific acts prohibited, § 10-5. 
Secs. 10-15-10-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 89-11, adopted Nov. 15, 1989, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as Ch. 10, Art. II, §§ 10-26.1-10-26.7. In order to facilitate classification and ease of usage, said provisions have been redesignated as Ch. 10, Art. II, Div. 2, §§ 10-29-10-35 at the discretion of the editor. Sections 10-21-10-25 have been redesignated as Ch. 10, Art. II, Div. 1, also at the discretion of the editor. 
Charter reference- Authority to provide for abatement of nuisances, § 7.04. 
Cross reference- Maintenance of commercial property, § 5-55 et seq.; garbage and trash generally, Ch. 8; clearing of litter from open private property by city, § 8-66. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-21. - Defined. 
    The term "nuisance" as used herein shall include the following: 
(a)  Wrecked, abandoned or partially dismantled or otherwise inoperative automobiles, trucks, trailers, house trailers, boat trailers, boats and machinery of whatever nature which are unsightly and are in the open upon private or public premises within the limits of the City, unless stored in a completely enclosed garage or other completely enclosed building. 
(b)  Lawns, grass, weeds, shrubbery, hedges and other plants which have grown to an excessive height or are wild or untrimmed and are unsightly or noxious, weeds, grass or underbrush exceed twelve (12) inches in height will be considered excessive. 
(c)  Buildings, residences and other structures which are in a state of disrepair, dilapidated, unsafe, dangerous or unsanitary or otherwise substandard and a menace to the health, morals, safety or general welfare of the inhabitants of the City. 
(d)  All accumulations of trash, rubbish, filth and debris. 
(e)  All depressions or excavations in which there is a pool of water or in which water is likely to accumulate. 
(f)  The failure to keep a lot, tract, or parcel of land in a clean, sightly, safe and sanitary condition. 
(g)  Swimming pools that are not maintained in a clean and sanitary condition for human use or allowed to become unsafe, dangerous, unhealthy or an attractive nuisance and/or unattended. 
(h)  Swimming pools that are abandoned, unattended, unused by human occupancy or are allowed to become habitats or places for growth of insects, bugs, rodents, pests, varmints, fish, snakes, reptiles, animals, birds, plants, weeds, grass, fungus, germs, or other growths. 
(i)  Any other condition not specified herein which would constitute a nuisance at common law. 
(Code 1965, §§ 10-5, 14-34; Ord. No. 90-12, § 1, 10-17-1990) 
Sec. 10-22. - Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any property or any other person to cause any nuisance or unlawful condition described herein upon any private or public property within the City, or to suffer or permit such condition to exist upon any private or public property within the City. 
(Code 1965, § 14-35) 
Cross reference- Maintenance of commercial property, § 5-55 et seq. 
Sec. 10-23. - Notice to abate. 
    Upon determining that any owner or occupant of real estate in the City shall have caused or suffered or permitted to exist any nuisance or other unlawful condition described herein, the City Manager shall notify in writing the owner and occupant of said property that: 
(a)  Said parties must abate said nuisance or other unlawful condition in the manner and within the time set forth in said notice; or 
(b)  Said parties may file with the City Clerk a written appeal to the City Commission within fifteen (15) days of the mailing of said notice appealing from the determination of the City Manager that the condition described in the notice is a nuisance or otherwise unlawful within the meaning of this article. 
The notice provided above shall be given by registered or certified mail addressed to the occupant at the property address and addressed to the owner at the address shown therefor upon the tax rolls used by the City, and said notice shall require the owner and occupant to abate the nuisance or other unlawful condition by taking the action described in said notice within a reasonable time after the mailing of such notice, which time shall not be less than fifteen (15) days nor more than sixty (60) days. 
(Code 1965, § 14-36) 
Sec. 10-24. - Appeal. 
(a)  Upon the filing of a notice of appeal by the owner or occupant of real estate as provided in section 10-23, the City Manager shall give written notice to the owner or occupant to appear before the City Commission on the date specified in the notice to show cause why the nuisance or other unlawful condition described in the notice to abate provided in section 10-23 should not be abated in the manner set forth in said notice. 
(b)  The City Commission shall promptly hold a hearing after written notice as provided above and hear such testimony as the City Manager or owner or occupant shall offer relative to the alleged nuisance. 
(c)  The Commission shall thereupon determine whether or not the condition in question is a nuisance within the terms of this article. If the Commission shall determine that the condition in question is not a nuisance within the terms of this article it shall then order the findings and notice of the City Manager revoked. If the Commission shall determine that the condition in question is a nuisance within the meaning of this article it shall direct the City Manager to issue an order directing the owner and occupants to abate said nuisance within a period not less than fifteen (15) days nor more than sixty (60) days from date of mailing said order by certified or registered mail to the occupant at the address of said property and to the owner at the address shown therefor upon the tax rolls used by the City. 
(Code 1965, § 14-37) 
Sec. 10-25. - Abatement by the City. 
(a)  Upon the occurrence of any of the following: 
(1)  The owner and occupant of real estate having been served with notice to abate as provided in section 10-23 shall have failed to comply with said notice or to appeal to the City Commission within the time provided therefor; or 
(2)  If the owner and occupant of real estate having been served with notice to abate as provided in section 10-23 and having appealed to the City Commission within the time provided therefor, and the Commission having determined that the condition complained of constituted a nuisance within the meaning of the article and the City Manager having thereafter issued order to abate, shall not comply with said order; the City Manager shall thereupon promptly cause the nuisance or other unlawful condition complained of to be abated and the costs of such abatement shall thereupon be and become a lien or charge against the land in question upon the filing by the City of a notice of lien with the circuit court; and the City Manager with the assistance of the City Attorney shall thereupon take such steps to perfect a lien of the City against such real estate. The liens herein provided for shall bear interest at maximum rate allowed by law for interest on real estate tax certificates from date of filing until paid, and shall remain in full force and effect for a period of ten (10) years or until earlier satisfied. Such liens may be enforced by suit in chancery in the manner provided by law for enforcement of other liens upon real estate. In the alternative, the City may collect the costs of such abatement by suit at common law or by any other procedure or method provided by law. 
(b)  Abatement of any such nuisance shall be carried out by the City Manager in the manner deemed by him most economical and considered by him to best preserve any property interest therein for the owner. He shall have authority to sell any salvage material in such manner as he shall deem proper and apply all proceeds from such sales against the expense of abating such nuisance. 
(Code 1965, § 14-38) 
State Law reference- Maximum interest rate on tax certificates, F.S. § 197.173(2). 
Secs. 10-26-10-28. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DRUG-RELATED NUISANCES 

Sec. 10-29. - Definitions. 
    [For the purposes of this division, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:] 
    Board shall mean the Nuisance Abatement Board of the City of West Miami. 
    City Attorney shall mean the legal counselor for the City of West Miami or such assistant City Attorney as may from time to time be designated. 
    Clerk shall mean a person appointed by the local governing board of the City of West Miami to perform the clerical duties necessary to carry out the activities of the Nuisance Abatement Board. 
    Operator shall mean the tenant, lessee or person having control or possession of the premises. 
    Public nuisance shall mean any place or premises within the City of West Miami which has been used on more than two (2) occasions as the site of the unlawful sale or delivery of controlled substances as defined in Chapter 893 of the Florida Statutes and any amendment thereto. 
(Ord. No. 89-11, § 1, 11-15-1989; Ord. No. 89-12, § 1, 12-6-1989) 
Sec. 10-30. - Nuisance Abatement Board; organization. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established a Nuisance Abatement Board to hear evidence relating to the existence of drug-related public nuisances on premises located in the City of West Miami, Florida. Said Board shall consist of the members of the City Commission. 
(b)  The presence of three (3) or more members shall constitute a quorum. Members shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for such travel, mileage, and per diem expenses as may be authorized by the City Manager. 
(Ord. No. 89-11, § 1, 11-15-1989; Ord. No. 89-12, § 1, 12-6-1989) 
Sec. 10-31. - Operating procedures. 
(a)  Any employee, officer or resident of Dade County or of the City of West Miami may file a complaint and request for prosecution with the City Attorney regarding the existence on premises located in West Miami of a public nuisance as defined in section 10-29, after first giving not less than three (3) days' written notice of such complaint to the owner of the place or premises complained of at his last known address. 
(b)  The City Attorney, when he has received the aforesaid complaint and request for prosecution and has reason to believe that a public nuisance as defined in section 10-29 exists on the premises complained of located in the City of West Miami and that the aforesaid written notice has been duly sent to the owner of the premises, shall promptly request a hearing before the Nuisance Abatement Board. 
(c)  The Nuisance Abatement Board, through its Clerk, shall schedule a hearing, and written notice of said hearing shall be sent by certified mail or hand delivered to the owner and operator(s) of the premises complained of at their last known addresses at least five (5) days prior to the scheduled hearing. If an attempt to reach the owner and operator(s) by hand delivery or certified mail is unsuccessful, notice of the hearing may be posted on the place or premises alleged to be a public nuisance or hand delivered to any person located therein. 
(d)  The aforesaid notice of hearing shall include: 
(1)  A statement of the time, place and nature of the hearing; 
(2)  A statement of the legal authority and jurisdiction under which the hearing is to be held; 
(3)  A reference to the particular sections of the statutes and ordinances involved; and 
(4)  A short and plain statement summarizing the incidents complained of. 
(Ord. No. 89-11, § 1, 11-15-1989; Ord. No. 89-12, § 1, 12-6-1989) 
Sec. 10-32. - Conduct of hearings. 
(a)  The Chairman of the Board may call hearings of the Board. Hearings may also be called by written notice signed by at least three (3) members of the Board. The Board, at a hearing, may set a future hearing date. The Board shall attempt to convene no less frequently than once every month but may meet more or less often as the demand necessitates. The Board shall adopt rules for the conduct of its hearing. Minutes shall be kept of all hearings and all hearings shall be open to the public. The City shall provide clerical and administrative personnel as may be reasonably required for the proper performance of the Board's duties. 
(b)  The City Attorney shall present cases before the Board. All parties shall have an opportunity to present evidence and argument on all issues involved, to conduct cross-examination and submit rebuttal evidence, and to be represented by counsel. When appropriate, the general public may be given an opportunity to present oral or written communications. If the Board proposes to consider such material, then all parties shall be given an opportunity to cross-examine or challenge or rebut it. The Board may consider any evidence, including evidence of the general reputation of the place or premises. All testimony shall be under oath and shall be recorded. Formal rules of evidence shall not apply, but fundamental due process shall be observed and shall govern the proceedings. Orders of the Board shall be based on competent and substantial evidence. 
(c)  After considering all evidence, the Board may declare the place or premises to be a public nuisance as defined in section 10-29 and may enter an order immediately prohibiting: 
(1)  The maintaining of the nuisance; 
(2)  The operating or maintaining of the place or premises; or 
(3)  The conduct, operation, or maintenance of any business or activity on the premises which is conducive to such nuisance. 
All orders of the Board shall be by motion approved by a majority of those members present and voting, except that at least three (3) members of the Board must vote in order for the action to be official. 
(d)  An order entered under subsection (c) above shall expire after one (1) year or at such earlier time as stated in the order. The Board may retain jurisdiction to modify its orders prior to the expiration of said orders. 
(e)  The Board may bring a complaint under F.S. § 60.05, seeking a permanent injunction against any public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 89-11, § 1, 11-15-1989; Ord. No. 89-12, § 1, 12-6-1989) 
Sec. 10-33. - Appeals. 
    An aggrieved party, including the City Administration, may appeal final administrative order of the Nuisance Abatement Board to the circuit court of the Eleventh Judicial Circuit. Such an appeal shall not be a hearing de novo but shall be limited to appellate review of the record created before the Board. An appeal shall be filed within thirty (30) days of the date of the written order appealed from. 
(Ord. No. 89-11, § 1, 11-15-1989; Ord. No. 89-12, § 1, 12-6-1989) 
Sec. 10-34. - Enjoining of nuisances. 
    When any nuisance as defined in F.S. § 823.05 exists, the City Attorney or any citizen of the City or County may sue in the name of the State on his relation to enjoin the nuisance, the person or persons maintaining it, and the owner or agent of the building or ground on which the nuisance exists. 
(Ord. No. 89-11, § 1, 11-15-1989; Ord. No. 89-12, § 1, 12-6-1989) 
Sec. 10-35. - Rights preserved. 
    This chapter does not restrict the right of any person to proceed under section 60.05 of the Florida Statutes, against any public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 89-11, § 1, 11-15-1989; Ord. No. 89-12, § 1, 12-6-1989) 
Sec. 10-35.5. - Cannabis dispensing facility; temporary moratorium. 
(a)  Definitions . For the purposes of this ordinance, the following words, terms, and phrases, including their respective derivatives, have the following meanings: 
(1)  Cannabis means all parts of any plant of the genus Cannabis , whether growing or not; the seeds thereof; the resin extracted from any part of the plant; and every compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of the plant or its seeds or resin. 
(2)  Low-THC cannabis means a plant of the genus Cannabis , the dried flowers of which contain 0.8 percent or less of tetrahydrocannabinol and more than ten (10) percent of cannabidiol weight for weight; the seeds thereof; the resin extracted from any part of such plant; or any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of such plant or its seed or resin that is dispenses only from a dispensing organization approved by the Florida Department of Health pursuant to F.S. § 381.986. 
(3)  Low-THC cannabis dispensary means an establishment where low-THC cannabis is dispensed at retail. 
(b)  Temporary moratorium . Beginning on the effective date of this ordinance for one hundred eighty (180) days, or sooner as provided pursuant to subsection (c) of this section, a moratorium is hereby imposed on the opening of new cannabis dispensaries and low-THC cannabis dispensaries. 
(1)  During the moratorium, it is unlawful and a violation of this ordinance for any person, firm, or corporation to open or cause to be opened any cannabis dispensary or low-THC cannabis dispensary within the City. 
(2)  During the moratorium, it is unlawful and a violation of this ordinance for any person, firm, or corporation to relocate or cause to be relocated any cannabis dispensary or low-THC cannabis dispensary within the City. 
(c)  Expiration of the temporary moratorium . The temporary moratorium imposed by subsection (b) expires as of the earliest of the following occurrences: 
(1)  One hundred eighty (180) days or sooner; or 
(2)  Sooner, if provided by ordinance of the City Commission of the City. 
(d)  Recommendations for land development regulations . The planning official is hereby directed to study, develop, and recommend land development regulations for cannabis dispensaries and low-THC cannabis dispensaries in the City, with such recommendations being delivered to the City Commission of the City by no later than one hundred eighty (180) days. 
(Ord. No. 2016-05 , §§ 2-5, 11-16-2016) 
ARTICLE III. - STOLEN, ABANDONED AND CONFISCATED PROPERTY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Seizure and sale of vehicles and apparatus used in alcoholic beverage violations, § 3-6. 
State Law reference- Lost or abandoned property, F.S. ch. 705. 

Sec. 10-36. - Police Department to take possession. 
    The Police Department is hereby authorized to seize and reduce to its possession all stolen or abandoned personal property, including bicycles, found within the City, with all personal property which the court shall order confiscated as the fruits of a crime or used in the commission of such crime. 
(Code 1965, § 16-1) 
Sec. 10-37. - City may store for six months. 
    The City may keep and maintain a warehouse or storage space where personal property possessed under section 10-36 may be kept for a period of six (6) months from the date of seizure. 
(Code 1965, § 16-2) 
Sec. 10-38. - Notice, redemption by owner. 
    During the period of six (6) months, as specified in section 10-37, the Police Department shall make diligent effort to notify the owner of such personal property that such property is being retained, and during said period of six (6) months shall permit the owner to regain possession thereof upon proof of ownership and upon payment of reasonable storage charges and costs connected with the seizure and storage of said property; provided, however, that no person may regain possession of any property which has been adjudged and ordered confiscated by a court. 
(Code 1965, § 16-3) 
Sec. 10-39. - Sale by City. 
    After the expiration of said period of six (6) months the police chief may sell at public sale any personal property in the City's possession pursuant to this article, which has not been claimed or reduced to the possession of the owner thereof, after ten (10) days' written notice to the owner if he can be found, and by posting of said notice in three (3) public places in the City for a period of ten (10) days preceding said sale.
