At the public sale the City may retain and commit to use by the City any items usable to the City, and may commit to use by the City any items offered for sale but not sold. 
(Code 1965, § 16-4) 
Sec. 10-40. - Disposition of proceeds of sale. 
    From the proceeds of the sale of personal property sold pursuant to section 10-39, storage and costs first shall be paid, and any balance remaining shall be deposited in the general funds of the City. In the event the said personal property shall be offered for sale, and no bids shall be received thereof, it shall be deemed that such property has no value, and the police chief, in his discretion, may order it destroyed or otherwise disposed of. 
(Code 1965, § 16-5) 
Secs. 10-41-10-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - VEHICLE IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 10-61. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Commercial purpose. The words "commercial purpose" shall mean for the purpose of economic gain. 
    Commercial vehicle. The words "commercial vehicle" shall mean a vehicle that is owned or used by a business corporation, association, partnership or sole proprietorship or any other entity conducting business for a commercial purpose. 
    Dump. The word "dump" shall mean to dump, throw, discard, place, deposit, or dispose of. 
    Hazardous waste. The words "hazardous waste" shall mean solid waste, or a combination of solid waste, which because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics, may cause, or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness or may pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly transported, disposed of, stored, treated, or otherwise managed. 
    Innocent owner. The word "innocent owner" shall mean co-registered owner or person in interest or holding an interest, who lacks knowledge that the property subject to impoundment was to be used or being employed in criminal activity. 
    Litter. The word "litter" shall mean any garbage, rubbish, trash, refuse, can, bottle, box, container, paper, tobacco products, tire, appliance, mechanical equipment or part, building or construction material, tool, machinery, wood, motor vehicle or motor vehicle part, vessel, farm machinery or equipment, sludge from a waste treatment facility, water supply treatment plant, or air pollution control facility, or substance in any form resulting from domestic, industrial, commercial, mining agricultural, or governmental operations. 
    Motor vehicle. The words "motor vehicle" shall mean an automobile, motorcycle, truck, trailer, semitrailer, truck, tractor, or semitrailer combination or any other vehicle that is powered by a motor. 
    Owner. The term owner shall have the same meaning as provided in F.S. § 316.003(26), as amended. 
    Person. The word "person" shall mean any individual, firm, sole proprietorship, partnership, corporation or unincorporated associations. 
    Vessel. The word "vessel" shall mean a boat, barge, or airboat or any other vehicle used for transportation on water. 
(Ord. No. 98-01, § 1, 2-4-1998; Ord. No. 2001-01, § 1, 4-18-2001; Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 10-3-2012) 
Sec. 10-62. - Impoundment of motor vehicles controlled substances, prostitution, and illegal dumping of waste. 
(a)  A motor vehicle shall be subject to seizure and impoundment whenever a police officer has probable cause to believe that the vehicle: 
(1)  Contains any controlled substances or cannabis as defined in F.S. Ch. 893; 
(2)  Was used in the purchase, attempt to purchase, sale, or attempt to sell such controlled substances or cannabis; 
(3)  Was used to facilitate the commission of any act of prostitution, assignation or lewdness as defined in F.S. § 796.07; or 
(4)  Was used to dump litter in any manner as prohibited in F.S. § 403.413(4) (1997), in an amount exceeding fifteen (15) pounds in weight or twenty-seven (27) cubic feet in volume, but not exceeding five hundred (500) pounds in weight or one hundred (100) cubic feet in volume and not for commercial purposes; or 
(5)  Was used to dump litter as prohibited in F.S. § 403.413(4) (1997) in an amount exceeding five hundred (500) pounds in weight or one hundred (100) cubic feet in volume or in any quantity for commercial purposes, or dumps litter which is hazardous waste. 
(b)  Upon seizing the motor vehicle, the police officer shall: 
(1)  Provide for the towing of the vehicle pursuant to the city rotational wrecker system and all applicable towing procedures; and 
(2)  Provide written notice of such seizure and impoundment to all persons whom the city knows, or with reasonable investigation should know, have a legal interest in the subject property. The written notice shall advise the persons of the following: 
a.  The right to request a preliminary hearing pursuant to section 10-63 to contest the seizure and impoundment of the vehicle; 
b.  The right to request a preliminary hearing pursuant to section 10-63 to contest the seizure and impoundment of the vehicle and immediately retrieve the vehicle from the towing facility upon the posting with the city of a cash bond in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus towing and storage costs; or 
c.  The right to waive the preliminary hearing and immediately retrieve the vehicle from the towing facility upon the payment of the five hundred dollars ($500.00) civil penalty, administrative fee, towing and storage costs. 
(c)  The required notices to be given pursuant to this section shall be provided by hand delivery at the time of the seizure and impoundment of the vehicle to the person in control of the vehicle and all other persons whom the city knows, or with reasonable investigation should know, have a legal interest in the subject property by certified mail, return receipt requested, within forty-eight (48) hours of the time of the impoundment excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays. 
(d)  This section shall not apply and the vehicle shall not be seized or impounded if: 
(1)  The possession, use or sale of the controlled substance and/or cannabis is authorized by F.S. ch. 893 or ch. 499; 
(2)  The vehicle was reported stolen at the time that it is subject to seizure and impoundment; 
(3)  The vehicle was operating as a common carrier at the time it was subject to seizure and impoundment; 
(4)  A law enforcement agency has expressed its intent, in writing, to institute state forfeiture proceedings on the vehicle; or 
(5)  The vehicle is rented from a company engaged in the business of renting vehicles. 
(Ord. No. 98-01, § 2, 2-4-1998; Ord. No. 2001-01, § 2, 4-18-2001; Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 10-3-2012) 
Sec. 10-63. - Hearings, administrative civil penalties. 
(a)  The owner of the motor vehicle, or his/her agent or authorized representative or any person in interest, shall make a written request for a preliminary hearing within five (5) days from the date notice is received then: 
(1)  The city shall hold such hearings before a special master or Code Enforcement Board of the city within ten (10) days of receipt of the written request, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays. 
(2)  At the hearing, the city shall have the burden to show that probable cause exists to believe that the motor vehicle is subject to impoundment and continued seizure under this ordinance. 
(3)  If the vehicle owner or person in interest raises as a defense at the preliminary hearing that he/she was unaware that the vehicle was being used or was likely to be used in violation of this article, the city shall establish by clear and convincing evidence that the owner or person in interest either knew, or should have known after a reasonable inquiry, that the vehicle was being used or was likely to be used in criminal activity. 
(4)  The formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the hearing and hearsay and circumstantial evidence is admissible. 
(5)  If, after the hearing, the special master or Code Enforcement Board determines that probable cause exists to believe that the motor vehicle is subject to impoundment and continued seizure, he/she or the Code Enforcement Board, by majority vote, shall order the continued impoundment of the vehicle and set the date for a final hearing. The owner or his/her agent or authorized representative, or person in interest, if he/she has not already done so, may immediately retrieve the vehicle from the towing facility upon the posting with the city of a cash bond in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus the accumulated costs of towing and storing the vehicle, without impairing the right to a final hearing. 
(6)  If, after the hearing, there is a finding of no probable cause, the vehicle shall be released forthwith to the owner or his/her agent or authorized representative without the imposition of the administrative civil penalty. If the owner, agent, authorized representative or person in interest has already posted a bond for the immediate release of his/her vehicle, the bond shall be refunded to the owner, agent or authorized representative. 
(b)  The final hearing shall be scheduled and held, unless continued by order of the special master or Code Enforcement Board, no later than thirty (30) days after the date that the vehicle was seized and impounded. 
(c)  At the final hearing, the city shall have the burden to show by clear and convincing evidence that the vehicle was used as set forth in this ordinance. If the owner of the vehicle or person in interest asserts as a defense that he/she was not aware that the vehicle was being used or was likely to be used in violation of this article, the city shall have the burden to establish by clear and convincing evidence that the owner or person in interest either knew, or should have known after a reasonable inquiry, that the vehicle was being used or was likely to be used in violation of this article. If, after the hearing, a finding is made that the vehicle is subject to impoundment and seizure then the special master or Code Enforcement Board of the city, by majority vote, shall enter an order finding the owner of record of the vehicle civilly liable to the city for an administrative civil penalty of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00), as outlined in this ordinance, plus towing and storage costs. If, after the hearing, a finding is made that the city did not meet its burden of proof as set forth in this subsection or that one of the exceptions of this ordinance applies, the vehicle shall be returned to the owner along with any cash bond posted. 
(Ord. No. 98-01, § 3, 2-4-1998; Ord. No. 2001-01, § 3, 4-18-2001; Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 10-3-2012) 
Sec. 10-64. - Administrative civil penalties; payment. 
    If an administrative civil penalty is imposed pursuant to this ordinance, such penalty shall constitute a debt due and owing the city and shall be independent of the city's return or release of the vehicle. If a cash bond has been posted pursuant to this ordinance, the bond shall be applied toward payment of the civil penalty, fees or administrative costs. 
(Ord. No. 98-01, § 5, 2-4-1998; Ord. No. 2001-01, § 5, 4-18-2001; Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 10-3-2012) 
Sec. 10-65. - Return of vehicle; disposition of unclaimed vehicles. 
    Except as provided otherwise in this ordinance, an impounded vehicle shall be returned to its record owner, or to the person who is legally entitled to possess the vehicle, upon his/her payment of the administrative civil penalty to the city, plus towing and storage fees, unless the vehicle had been sold or otherwise disposed of to satisfy a judgment or enforce a lien as provided by law. 
    Vehicles which remain unclaimed after a final determination is made by a special master or Code Enforcement Board shall be disposed of pursuant to Florida Statutes and all other applicable laws. 
(Ord. No. 98-01, § 6, 2-4-1998; Ord. No. 2001-01, § 6, 4-18-2001; Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 10-3-2012) 
Sec. 10-66. - Appeal. 
    The owner of the motor vehicle that has been the subject of a seizure and impoundment pursuant to this ordinance or the city may appeal the final ruling and decisions of the special master or Code Enforcement Board of the city, to the circuit of the 11th Judicial Circuit of Dade County, Florida, within thirty (30) days of the date of the final order being appealed. The city may charge the appellant a reasonable fee for preparation of the record for purposes of making the appeal. 
    An appeal of a final administrative order by the special master or Code Enforcement Board of the City, shall not be a hearing de novo but shall be a limited appellate review of the record created before the special master or Code Enforcement Board of the City. 
(Ord. No. 98-01, § 7, 2-4-1998; Ord. No. 2001-01, § 7, 4-18-2001; Ord. No. 2012-03, § 1, 10-3-2012) 
Chapter 11 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Planting trees or shrubs on city property, § 10-7. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    Director is the person immediately in charge of any park area and its activities, and to whom all park attendants of such area are responsible. 
    Nonscheduled group activity is any activity or function conducted or held in a park under the sponsorship of any group other than the City, and to which the general public is not invited or in which the general public is not allowed to participate. 
    Park is a park, reservation, playground, recreation center or any other area in the City, owned or used by the City, and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Vehicle is any wheeled conveyance, whether motor-powered, animal-drawn, or self-propelled. The term shall include any trailer in tow of any size, kind or description. Exception is made for baby carriages and vehicles in the service of the City parks. 
(Code 1965, § 15-1) 
Sec. 11-2. - Supervised recreation system. 
(a)  All matters pertaining to the establishment, maintenance and conduct of a supervised recreation system for the City shall be planned, administered and supervised by the City Commission or by such person or persons as it may appoint to perform said duties according to law. 
(b)  In order to provide for the establishment, maintenance and conduct of a supervised recreation system, an annual levy of one (1) mill is hereby fixed upon all taxable property within the City limits; said tax to be designated as a playground and recreation tax, and the Tax Collector be, and he is hereby directed that commencing with the year 1953 and successive years, until repealed according to law, that he levy and collect said taxes in the same manner as the general taxes of the City are collected. 
(c)  The proceeds of said tax be paid into a special fund to be designated as a playground and recreation fund, and to be used only for the purpose set forth in this section and as provided by law. 
(d)  Chapter XI, section 11-2 of the City of West Miami Code is hereby amended in that all annual fees for nonresidents for the use of the parks and recreation center; child care, after school care, use of tennis courts, baseball fields and other uses shall be set by a resolution of the City Commission. 
The City Manager is hereby instructed to conduct a yearly assessment, based on the cost of operation of these facilities and certify to the Commission, suggested fees for the use, by nonresidents of these facilities. 
The City Manager may also, if so required by the economic circumstances, report to the City Commission at any time, any special needs or changes necessary in the fee structure. 
Upon the report by the City Manager, the Commission may assess the fee structure of these facilities. 
(Code 1965, §§ 15-10-15-12; Ord. No. 94-03, § 1, 6-1-1994; Ord. No. 2005-05, § 1, 8-17-2005; Ord. No. 2007-08, § 1, 10-17-2007; Ord. No. 2013-06, §§ 2-5, 9-18-2013) 
Editor's note- The ordinance on which this section is based was enacted pursuant to F.S. ch. 418, pt. I, and therefore the system and tax here established was approved at referendum as provided by F.S. § 418.08. 
Sec. 11-3. - Enforcement officers. 
    The Director and park attendants shall, together with the police officers of the City, in connection with their duties imposed by law, diligently enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 15-9) 
Sec. 11-4. - Authority to eject violators. 
    The Director, any park attendant, and any police officer of the City shall have the authority to eject from the park any person acting in violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 15-9) 
Sec. 11-5. - Seizure of violating property. 
    The Director, any park attendant and any police officer of the City shall have the authority to seize and confiscate any property, thing or device in a park, or used in a park, in violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 15-9) 
Sec. 11-6. - Hours. 
    Except for unusual and unforeseen emergencies, parks shall be open to the public on such days and between such hours as the City Commission may designate by resolution. The opening and closing hours for each individual park shall be posted therein for public information. 
(Code 1965, § 15-8) 
Sec. 11-7. - Closing of particular areas. 
    Any section or part of any park may be declared closed to the public by the Director at any time and for any interval of time, either temporarily or at regular and stated intervals (daily or otherwise) and either entirely or merely to certain uses, as the Director shall find reasonably necessary. 
(Code 1965, § 15-8) 
Sec. 11-8. - Lost and found articles. 
    The finding of lost articles by park attendants shall be reported to the Director, who shall make every reasonable effort to locate the owners. The Director shall make every reasonable effort to find articles reported as lost. 
(Code 1965, § 15-8) 
Secs. 11-9-11-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GROUP ACTIVITIES 

Sec. 11-19. - Permit required. 
    A permit shall be obtained from the City Manager before participating in any nonscheduled group activity in a park. 
(Code 1965, § 15-8) 
Sec. 11-20. - Application for permit. 
    A person seeking issuance of a permit hereunder shall file an application with the City Clerk. The application shall state: 
(a)  The name and address of the applicant; 
(b)  The name and address of the person, group, or association sponsoring the activity, if any; 
(c)  The day and hours for which the permit is desired; 
(d)  The park or portion thereof for which such permit is desired; 
(e)  An estimate of the anticipated attendance; 
(f)  Any other information which the City Manager shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should issue hereunder; 
(g)  Attached to said application shall be a release and indemnification agreement executed by the applicant releasing the City from any liability to the applicant or persons claiming through the applicant for any injuries or damages sustained in the park and agreeing to indemnify the City for any losses which it may suffer from any claims of the applicant or persons claiming by, through or against the applicant. 
(Code 1965, § 15-8) 
Sec. 11-21. - Standards for permit issuance. 
    The City Manager shall issue a permit hereunder when he finds: 
(a)  That the proposed activity or use of the park will not unreasonably interfere with, or detract from the general public's enjoyment of the park; 
(b)  That the proposed activity or use will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the promotion of public health, welfare, safety and recreation; 
(c)  That the proposed activity or use is not reasonably anticipated to incite violence, crime or disorderly conduct; 
(d)  That the proposed activity or use will not entail unusual, extraordinary or burdensome expense or police operation by the City; 
(e)  That the facilities desired have not been reserved for other use at the day and hour requested in the application. 
(Code 1965, § 15-8) 
Sec. 11-22. - Appeal from permit denial. 
    Within five (5) days after receipt of an application the City Manager shall apprise an applicant in writing of his reasons for refusing a permit, and any aggrieved person shall have the right to appeal in writing within ten (10) days to the City Commission, which shall consider the application under the standards set forth in section 11-21, and sustain or overrule the City Manager's decision within twenty-one (21) days. The decision of the City Commission shall be final. 
(Code 1965, § 15-8) 
Sec. 11-23. - Permit subject to rules, regulations, ordinances. 
    A permittee shall be bound by all park rules and regulations and all applicable ordinances as fully as though the same were inserted in his permit. 
(Code 1965, § 15-8) 
Sec. 11-24. - Liability of permittee. 
    The person or persons to whom a permit is issued shall be liable for any loss, damage or injury sustained by any person whatever by reason of the negligence of the person or persons to whom such permit shall have been issued. 
(Code 1965, § 15-8) 
Sec. 11-25. - Permit revocation. 
    The Director shall have the authority to revoke a permit upon a finding of violation of any rule or ordinance, or upon good cause shown. 
(Code 1965, § 15-8) 
Sec. 11-26. - Reserved use of Edmund P. Cooper Park; gazebo; permit fee; deposit; terms. 
(a)  Permit fees; reserved use of Edmund P. Cooper Park. 
(1)  Before any permit is issued for the reserved use of that portion of Edmund P. Cooper Park abutting Southwest 15th Street and Southwest 16th Street between Southwest 58th Avenue and Southwest 59th Avenue, under sections 11-19 through 11-21 of this Code, the permittee shall pay to the City the following fees and deposits for reserved use of the park, provided that all events conclude at sundown: 
a.  Resident permittee: one hundred dollars ($100.00); 
b.  Nonresident permittee: two hundred and twenty-five dollars ($225.00). 
(2)  If an inspection by the Police Department after such use shows that the area used by the permittee is cleaned and orderly and that all provisions of Chapter 11 of this Code have been complied with, then the following refund shall be made: 
a.  Residential permittee: forty dollars ($40.00); 
b.  Nonresidential: Seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
c.  If such inspection shows evidence of noncompliance with the aforesaid provisions, no refund shall be made. 
(b)  Permit fees and refunds for reserve use of gazebo. 
(1)  Before any reserved use of the gazebo in the park may be issued, the permittee shall pay for said use the following sums: 
a.  Resident permittee: one hundred dollars ($100.00); forty dollar ($40.00) deposit and seventy-five ($75.00) non-refundable clean up fee. 
b.  Nonresident permittee: two hundred twenty-five dollars ($225.00); seventy-five dollar ($75.00) deposit and seventy-five ($75.00) non-refundable clean up fee. 
(2)  If an inspection by the Police Department after such use shows that the area used by the permittee is cleaned and orderly and that all provisions of Chapter 11 of this Code have been complied with, then the following refund shall be made: 
a.  Residential permittee: forty dollars ($40.00) 
b.  Nonresidential permittee: seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
c.  If such inspection shows evidence of noncompliance with the aforesaid provisions, no refund shall be made. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, § 1, 7-11-1990; Ord. No. 2007-06, § 1, 10-17-2007; Ord. No. 2011-05, §§ 1, 2, 9-7-2011) 
Sec. 11-27. - Community center; nonresident fees. 
    The City shall impose the following fees upon nonresidents for the multiple uses of the City's community center: 
Nonresidents-Parties $375.00 rental fee $150.00 deposit $75.00 clean-up fee (nonrefundable) Nonresidents-Wedding $600.00 rental fee $200.00 deposit $75.00 clean-up fee (nonrefundable) Nonresidents-New Year's Party $600.00 rental fee $200.00 deposit $75.00 clean-up fee (nonrefundable) Nonresidents Non-profit organizations $75.00 Profit organizations $150.00  
(Ord. No. 2007-07, § 1, 10-17-2007) 
Secs. 11-28-11-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - REGULATIONS GOVERNING CONDUCT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 11-36. - Obedience to closing hours. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter or be in or upon any park after the closing hours designated by the Commission or before opening hours designated by the Commission; provided however, that this provision shall not apply to any official or employee of the City in the performance of any duty in connection with the maintenance, operation or regulation of such park. 
(Code 1965, § 15-6) 
Sec. 11-37. - Entering closed area, disobeying posted notices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter an area in a park posted as "Closed to the Public," nor shall any person use, or abet the use of, any area in violation of posted notices. 
(Code 1965, § 15-6) 
Sec. 11-38. - Gambling. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to gamble, or to participate in or abet any game of chance, in a park. 
(Code 1965, § 15-6) 
Sec. 11-39. - Possessing, drinking alcoholic beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bring alcoholic beverages into a park, or to drink alcoholic beverages in a park. 
(Code 1965, § 15-6) 
Cross reference- Drinking in public places prohibited generally, § 3-18. 
Sec. 11-40. - Ejection of drunks. 
    Any person who is under the influence of intoxicants in a park may be ejected by the Director, any park attendant, or any police officer of the City. 
Cross reference- Drinking in public places prohibited generally, § 3-18. 
Sec. 11-41. - Littering generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bring in or dump, deposit or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage or refuse or other trash in a park. No such refuse or trash shall be placed in any waters in or contiguous to any park or left anywhere on the grounds hereof, but shall be placed in proper receptacles provided; where receptacles are not so provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence, and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(Code 1965, §§ 9-37, 15-3) 
Sec. 11-42. - Damaging, removing property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a park to willfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with, or displace or remove, any building, bridges, tables, benches, fireplaces, railings, paving or paving material, water lines or other public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof, signs, notices or placards, whether temporary or permanent, monuments, stakes, posts, or other boundary markers, or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal. 
(Code 1965, § 15-2) 
Sec. 11-43. - Removal of natural resources. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dig or remove any soil, rock, stones, trees, shrubs or plants, downtimber or other wood or materials, or make any excavation by tool, equipment, blasting, or other means or agency, in a park. 
(Code 1965, § 15-2) 
Sec. 11-44. - Damaging, removing vegetation generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to damage, cut, carve, transplant or remove any tree or plant or injure the bark, or pick the flowers or seeds, of any tree or plant in a park, nor shall any person attach any rope, wire, or other contrivance to any such tree or plant. A person shall not dig in or otherwise disturb grassy areas, or in any other way injure or impair the natural beauty or usefulness of any park area. 
(Code 1965, § 15-2) 
Sec. 11-45. - Erecting structures, installing utilities. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or erect any building or structure of any kind, whether permanent or temporary in character, or run or string any public service utility into, upon, or across, any park lands except on special written permit from the City Manager. 
(Code 1965, § 15-2) 
Sec. 11-46. - Climbing trees or other park property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a park to climb any tree or to walk, stand or sit upon monuments, vases, fountains, railings, fences or gun-carriages or upon any other property not designated or customarily used for such purposes. 
(Code 1965, § 15-2) 
Sec. 11-47. - Domestic animals. 
    Subject to the exception provided by section 41-8 [4-18], it shall be unlawful for any person to be responsible for the entry of a dog, cat, horse, or other domestic animal into any park. 
(Code 1965, § 15-6) 
Cross reference- Dogs prohibited in parks, § 4-17. 
Sec. 11-48. - Hitching animals to plants. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tie or hitch a horse or other animal to any tree or plant in a park. 
(Code 1965, § 15-2) 
Sec. 11-49. - Molesting wildlife. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to hunt, molest, harm, frighten, kill, trap, chase, tease, shoot or throw missiles at any animal, reptile or bird in a park; nor shall he remove or have in his possession the young of any wild animal, or the eggs or nests or young of any reptile or bird; nor shall he collect, remove, have in his possession, give away, sell or offer to sell, or buy or offer to buy, or accept as a gift, any specimen, alive or dead, of any of the group of tree snails. Exception to the foregoing is made in that snakes known to be deadly poisonous, such as rattlesnakes, moccasins, coral snakes, or other deadly reptiles, may be killed on sight. 
(Code 1965, §§ 15-2, 15-5) 
Sec. 11-50. - Feeding harmful substances to wildlife. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a park to give or offer, or attempt to give, to any animal or bird, any tobacco, alcohol or other known noxious substances. 
(Code 1965, § 15-2) 
Sec. 11-51. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-09, § 2, adopted Dec. 7, 2011, repealed § 11-51, which pertained to firearms, weapons prohibited; shooting into park and derived from Code 1965, § 15-5. 
Sec. 11-52. - Fireworks, explosives. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a park to have in his possession, or set off, or otherwise cause to explode or discharge or burn, any firecrackers, torpedo, rocket, or other fireworks or explosives or inflammable material, or discharge them or throw them into a park area from land or highway adjacent thereto. This prohibition includes any substance, compound, mixture, or article that in conjunction with any other substance or compound would be dangerous from any of the foregoing standpoints. 
(Code 1965, § 15-6) 
Sec. 11-53. - Use of restrooms, washrooms. 
    It shall be the duty of every person in a park to cooperate in maintaining restrooms and washrooms in a neat and sanitary condition. No person over the age of five (5) years shall use restrooms and washrooms designated for the opposite sex. 
(Code 1965, § 15-2) 
Sec. 11-54. - Use of picnic areas regulated. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to picnic or lunch in a park in a place other than one (1) designated for that purpose. Attendants shall have the authority to regulate the activities in such areas when necessary to prevent congestion and to secure the maximum use for the comfort and convenience of all. Visitors shall comply with any directions given to achieve this end. 
(Code 1965, § 15-5) 
Sec. 11-55. - Availability of picnic space. 
    Use of the fireplaces, tables and benches in picnic areas shall follow generally the rule of "first come, first served." 
(Code 1965, § 15-5) 
Sec. 11-56. - Hogging picnic areas. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use any portion of a park picnic area or of any of the buildings or structures therein for the purpose of holding picnics to the exclusion of other persons, nor shall any person use such area and facilities for an unreasonable time if the facilities are crowded. 
(Code 1965, § 15-5) 
Sec. 11-57. - Duties of picnicker when leaving area. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave a park picnic area before the fire is completely extinguished and before all trash in the nature of boxes, papers, cans, bottles, garbage and other refuse is placed in the disposal receptacles where provided. If no such trash receptacles are available, then refuse and trash shall be carried away from the park area by the picnicker to be properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(Code 1965, § 15-5) 
Sec. 11-58. - Fires and fire prevention. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to build or attempt to build a fire in a park except in such areas and under such regulations as may be provided by the Director. No person shall drop, throw or otherwise scatter lighted matches, burning cigarettes or cigars, tobacco paper or other inflammable material within any park area or on any highway, road or street abutting or contiguous thereto. 
(Code 1965, § 15-6) 
Sec. 11-59. - Camping. 
    No person shall set up tents, shacks, or any other temporary shelter for the purpose of overnight camping in a park, nor shall any person leave in a park after closing hours any movable structure or special vehicle to be used or that could be used for such purpose, such as house-trailer, camp-trailer, camp-wagon, or the like. 
(Code 1965, § 15-5) 
Sec. 11-60. - Certain games prohibited or regulated. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to take part in or abet the playing of any games involving thrown or otherwise propelled objects such as balls, stones, arrows, javelins or model airplanes in a park, except in areas set apart for such forms of recreation. The playing of rough or comparatively dangerous games such as football, baseball and quoits is prohibited except on the fields and courts or areas provided therefor. 
(Code 1965, § 15-5) 
Sec. 11-61. - Begging, soliciting contributions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit alms or contributions for any purpose, whether public or private, in a park. 
(Code 1965, § 15-6) 
Sec. 11-62. - Improper clothing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to appear at any place in a park in other than proper clothing. 
(Code 1965, § 15-6) 
Sec. 11-63. - Sleeping, lounging, boisterousness. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sleep or protractedly lounge on the seats, or benches, or other areas of a park, or engage in loud, boisterous, threatening, abusive, insulting or indecent language, or engage in any disorderly conduct or behavior tending to a breach of the public peace, in a park. 
(Code 1965, § 15-6) 
Sec. 11-64. - Duty to exhibit permits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a park to fail to produce and exhibit any permit from the City Manager or the Director he claims to have upon request of any authorized person who shall desire to inspect the same for the purpose of enforcing compliance with any ordinance or rule. 
(Code 1965, § 15-6) 
Sec. 11-65. - Interfering with permittees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a park to disturb or interfere unreasonably with any person or party occupying any area, or participating in any activity, under the authority of a permit. 
(Code 1965, § 15-6) 
Sec. 11-66. - Noise. 
(a)  Yelling, shouting, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person to yell, shout, hoot, whistle, or sing in any park at any time so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office, dwelling, hotel or other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity. 
(b)  Radios, phonographs, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person in a park to use, operate, or permit to be played, used or operated any radio, receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, motion picture projector or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is necessary for convenient hearing for the person or persons who are voluntary listeners thereto. The operation of such set, instrument, phonograph machine, motion picture projector or other machine or device between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. in such a manner as to be plainly audible at a distance of fifty (50) feet from the outside boundaries of the park in which it is located shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
(Code 1965, § 15-6) 
Cross reference- Noise prohibited generally, § 10-4 et seq. 
Sec. 11-67. - Vending prohibited; exceptions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a park to expose or offer for sale any article or thing, nor shall he station or place any stand, cart, or vehicle for the transportation, sale or display of any such article or thing. Exceptions are hereby made as to any regularly licensed concessionaire acting by and under the authority of and regulation of the Director with approval of the City Commission and any civic groups or clubs acting by and under the authority and regulation of the Director. 
(Code 1965, § 15-7) 
Cross reference- Regulation of peddlers and solicitors generally, § 9-70 et seq. 
Sec. 11-68. - Advertising prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a park to announce, advertise, or call the public's attention in any way to any article or service for sale or hire. 
(Code 1965, § 15-7) 
Sec. 11-69. - Signs prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to paste, glue, tack or otherwise post any sign, placard, advertisement, or inscription whatever in a park, nor shall any person erect or cause to be erected any sign whatever on any public lands or highways or roads adjacent to a park. 
(Code 1965, § 15-7) 
Secs. 11-70-11-79. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRAFFIC 

Sec. 11-80. - Obedience to State laws. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in a park to fail to comply with all applicable provisions of the State traffic laws in regard to equipment and operation of vehicles, together with such regulations as are contained in this chapter and other ordinances. 
(Code 1965, § 15-4) 
State Law reference- State traffic law, F.S. ch. 316. 
Sec. 11-81. - Authority to direct traffic; obedience required. 
    Traffic officers and park employees are hereby authorized and instructed to direct traffic whenever and wherever needed in the parks and on the highways, streets or roads immediately adjacent thereto in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and such supplementary regulations as may be issued subsequently by the Director. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to obey any such direction. 
(Code 1965, § 15-4) 
Sec. 11-82. - Obedience to signs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to observe any traffic sign in a park indicating speed, direction, caution, stopping, parking, or otherwise posted for proper traffic control and to safeguard life and property. 
(Code 1965, § 15-4) 
Sec. 11-83. - Speed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or drive a vehicle at a rate of speed exceeding five (5) miles an hour in a park, except upon such roads as the City Manager may designate, by posted signs, for speedier travel. 
(Code 1965, § 15-4) 
Sec. 11-84. - Operation confined to roads, parking areas. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle on any area in a park except the paved park roads or parking areas, or such other areas as may on occasion be specifically designated as temporary parking areas by the Director. 
(Code 1965, § 15-4) 
Sec. 11-85. - Parking in designated areas. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle in a park in other than an established or designated parking area, and such use shall be in accordance with the posted directions thereat and with the instructions of any attendant who may be present. 
(Code 1965, § 15-4) 
Sec. 11-86. - Double parking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to double park any vehicle on any road or parkway in a park, unless directed by a park official. 
(Code 1965, § 15-4) 
Sec. 11-87. - Bicycles. 
(a)  Where permitted. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle in a park on other than a paved vehicular roadway or path designated for that purpose. A bicyclist shall be permitted to wheel or push a bicycle by hand over any grassy area or wooded trail or on any paved area reserved for pedestrian use. 
(b)  Operation. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle in a park other than on the right-hand side of the road paving as close as conditions permit, and bicycles shall be kept in single file when two (2) or more are operating as a group. Bicyclists shall at all times operate their machines with reasonable regard to the safety of others, signal all turns, pass to the right of any vehicle they are overtaking, and pass to the right of any vehicles they may be meeting. 
(c)  Rider prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride any other person on a bicycle in a park. 
(d)  Use of racks. It shall be unlawful for any person to leave a bicycle in a park in a place other than a bicycle rack when such is provided and there is a space available. 
(e)  Leaving constituting hazard. It shall be unlawful for any person to leave a bicycle in a park lying on the ground or paving, or set against trees, or in any place or position where other persons may trip over or be injured by it. 
(Code 1965, § 15-4) 
Chapter 12 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Municipal code enforcement board, § 2-136 et seq.; building regulations generally, Ch. 5; plans review board, § 5-36 et seq.; maintenance commercial property, § 5-55 et seq. 
State Law reference- Planning, F.S. § 163.2511 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Zoning ordinances not affected by adoption of Code. 
    The basic zoning ordinance of the City, being Ordinance No. 282, as from time to time amended, and all other ordinances relating to zoning, including those zoning or rezoning specific parcels of property or adopting or amending a zoning map or maps, shall continue in full force and effect; and nothing contained in this Code or in the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed as repealing or otherwise affecting such ordinances. 
Cross reference- Locational regulations for beverage establishments, § 3-7 et seq. 
Sec. 12-2. - Subdivisions to conform to County Code. 
    Except as otherwise provided herein, the subdividing and platting of lands within the City shall conform to the requirements of chapter 28 of the Code of Metropolitan Dade County. 
County Code references- County subdivision regulations to apply in both incorporated and unincorporated areas of county, MDCC § 28-3; authority of municipalities to impose higher standards, § 28-20. 
State Law reference- Plats and platting generally, F.S. ch. 177. 
Sec. 12-3. - Building on unplatted lands prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section: 
(1)  Platted land means any land in the City recorded by record plat in the office of the Clerk of the Circuit Court. 
(2)  Unplatted land means any land in the City that has not been recorded by record plat in the office of the Clerk of the Circuit Court. 
(b)  Prohibited; exceptions. It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, have constructed, or cause to be erected or constructed any building upon any unplatted land within the City, except the erection of a home and accessory buildings thereto by the owner. Provided, however, the recording of a plat will not be required if: 
(1)  The subdivision involved consists only of the dedication of a road, highway, street, alley or easement and due to unusual conditions and circumstances, the City Commission finds that it is not necessary that a plat be recorded. In lieu of the recording of a plat, the dedication may be required by deed on a form furnished by the City and may be subject to compliance with such conditions as may be deemed appropriate under the particular circumstances, such as improvements of sidewalks, streets, or drainage facilities and the acceptance of the dedication by the City Commission. Posting of bond may be required. 
(2)  The land to be subdivided is to be divided into no more than two (2) parcels and because of: 
(a)  Unusual conditions created by ownership or development of adjacent lands; or 
(b)  The isolation or remoteness of the land concerned in relation to other platted or improved lands; or 
(c)  Improvements and dedications existing on the land substantially in accordance with the requirements of chapter 28 of the Code of Metropolitan Dade County. 
    It is determined by the City Commission that waiving of the requirement for platting would not conflict with the purpose and intent of chapter 28 of the Code of Metropolitan Dade County. 
    In lieu of platting, the City Commission may require any dedications, reservations, or improvements required in connection with platting under chapter 28 of the Code of Metropolitan Dade County, including the posting of a performance and maintenance bond, as may be necessary to carry out the intent and purpose of said chapter 28. 
(3)  The resubdivision of land heretofore platted is of such unusual size or shape, or is surrounded by such development or unusual conditions as may be determined by the City Commission to justify the waiving of the requirement for recording a plat. In lieu of the recording of a plat, such conditions may be imposed as may be deemed necessary and appropriate to preserve the public interest. 
(4)  All waivers of plat as herein provided shall be subject to and conditioned upon approval by Dade County as provided in chapter 28 of the Code of Metropolitan Dade County. 
(Code 1965, § 20-2) 
County Code references- Similar provisions, MDCC § 28-4; procedure for waiver of plat, § 28-4.1. 
Sec. 12-4. - Agreement to accompany application for approval of plat. 
    Unless specifically waived by the Commission in the resolution approving any particular plat, all persons submitting to the Commission for approval any plat of lands previously platted or unplatted are hereby required to accompany any such proposed plat with a suitable agreement with the City providing for: 
(1)  The construction of streets, pavements, sidewalks, curbs and gutters, if necessary, parkways, water mains and services in connection therewith, storm drainage structures and any other necessary improvements. 
(2)  The filling of all depressions lying within the area platted to conform with established street grades in order to provide adequate drainage. 
(Code 1965, § 20-3) 
Sec. 12-5. - Standard of specifications of improvements. 
    All improvements, except water mains and services in connection therewith, are to be constructed in accordance with the City's standard specifications, as may be from time to time established by the City Engineer, and at the expense of the owner of the land platted. The water mains and services in connection therewith shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the water department at the expense of the owner of the land platted, in accordance with the policy of the water department then in effect. 
(Code 1965, § 20-4) 
Sec. 12-6. - Bond required; liability of principal and surety; construction of improvements by City. 
    The agreement as required by this chapter shall be accompanied by a surety bond in the penal sum of not less than one hundred ten (110) percent of the estimated cost of all such construction. Such agreement shall be approved by the City Commission and such bond shall be approved by the City Clerk. The condition of such bond shall be such that if the principal shall fully and faithfully perform all the terms and conditions of the principal's agreement and within the times therein specified, then the same shall be void; otherwise the City shall have the right to construct such improvements including street, alley or other rights-of-way, necessary storm drainage structures, water mains and services, and filling of depressions, or, pursuant to public advertisement and receipt and acceptance of bids, to cause the same to be constructed. The principal and surety jointly and severally shall agree to pay and indemnify the City, upon completion by the City, the final total cost of such construction, including but not limited to engineering, legal and contingent costs, together with any damages, either direct or consequential which the City may sustain on account of the failure of the principal to comply with the terms of such agreement. 
(Code 1965, § 20-5) 
Sec. 12-7. - Time limitation for completion of subdivision improvements. 
    A subdivider shall complete the construction of all required improvements, including street, alley, or other rights-of-way, necessary storm drainage structures, water mains and services, and the filling of depressions, within six (6) months from and after the date of the approval of his final plat by the Commission; provided, however, that the Commission may, in case of unusual circumstances, extend the time for completion of such construction for not to exceed an additional six (6) months. 
(Code 1965, § 20-6) 
Secs. 12-8-12-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COMPREHENSIVE PLAN 

Sec. 12-16. - Authority cited. 
    This article is enacted pursuant to and in accordance with the provisions of F.S. §§ 163.3161 through 163.3211, being the Local Government Comprehensive Planning Act of 1975. 
(Ord. No. 370, § 1, 6-2-1976) 
Sec. 12-17. - Declaration of intent. 
    The City Commission hereby declares that it is the intent of the City to exercise authority to proceed under the Local Government Comprehensive Planning Act of 1975 as provided in F.S. § 163.3171. 
(Ord. No. 370, § 10, 6-2-1976; Ord. No. 388, § 1, 4-4-1979) 
Sec. 12-18. - Local agency designated. 
    Pursuant to, and in accordance with F.S. § 163.3174, the City Commission is hereby designated and established as the local planning agency for the incorporated territory of the City. 
(Ord. No. 370, § 2, 6-2-1976) 
Sec. 12-19. - Duties, responsibilities of local agency. 
    The local planning agency, in accordance with F.S. §§ 163.3161-163.3211, shall: 
(a)  Conduct the comprehensive planning program and prepare the comprehensive plan or elements or portions thereof for the City; 
(b)  Coordinate said comprehensive plan or elements or portions thereof with the comprehensive plans of other appropriate local governments and the State of Florida; 
(c)  Recommend said comprehensive plan or elements or portions thereof to the City Commission for adoption; and 
(d)  Monitor and oversee the effectiveness and status of the comprehensive plan and recommend to the City Commission such changes in the comprehensive plan as may be required from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 370, § 3, 6-2-1976) 
Sec. 12-20. - Organization, rules, procedures for agency. 
    Members of the local planning agency shall continue to be appointed and follow such rules of procedure, methods of choosing officers, setting of public meetings, providing of financial support, and accomplishing its duties as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 370, § 4, 6-2-1976) 
Sec. 12-21. - Meetings, records to be public; public participation. 
    All meetings of the local planning agency shall be public meetings and all agency records shall be public records. The local planning agency shall encourage public participation. 
(Ord. No. 370, § 5, 6-2-1976) 
Sec. 12-22. - Financing of agency. 
    The City Commission shall appropriate funds at its discretion to the local planning agency for expenses necessary in the conduct of its work. The local planning agency may, in order to accomplish the purposes and activities required by the Local Government Comprehensive Planning Act of 1975, expend all sums so appropriated and other sums made available for use from fees, gifts, State or federal grants, State or federal loans, and other sources; provided acceptance of loans or grants must be approved by the City Commission. 
(Ord. No. 370, § 6, 6-2-1976) 
Chapter 13 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Requirements for contracts for public improvements, § 2-78; sidewalks prerequisite to certificate of occupancy, § 5-3; cash bond to guarantee repair of sidewalks, curbs, drains, etc., after construction activities, § 5-7; maintenance of commercial property, § 5-55 et seq.; excavations, § 5-71 et seq.; conditions on street occupancy by cable television systems, § 6-10; subdivisions to conform to county code, § 12-2. 
County Code reference- Review of and recommendations on local improvement projects by county, MDCC § 2-11.7 et seq. 
State Law reference- City street system designated, F.S. § 334.03(3). 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Obstructing streets prohibited. 
    Unless otherwise specifically permitted, no person shall place rocks, concrete blocks or portions thereof, stones, bricks, metal objects or any other similar obstruction within the right-of-way of the streets or highways of the City, nor shall any property owner suffer or permit any such concrete blocks or portions thereof, rocks, stones, bricks, metal objects or any other similar obstructions to be placed or remain within the right-of-way of any street or highway within the City abutting his property. 
(Code 1965, § 19-11) 
Sec. 13-2. - Certain markers allowed in portions of parkways. 
    Concrete buttons or markers not over six (6) inches in height, rounded and without sharp or jagged edges may be placed within the parkway, provided said buttons must be at least twenty-four (24) inches apart and set back at least two (2) feet from the edges of the pavement of the street or highway. Such buttons may not be placed so as to interfere with the ingress and egress of an automobile for parking purposes, nor may such buttons be placed so as to interfere with or prevent parking in the parkways. Such buttons may not be placed so as to block or interfere with the ingress and egress of adjacent residents to and from the property of such adjacent residents. 
(Code 1965, § 19-12) 
Sec. 13-3. - Display of merchandise on streets and sidewalks restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to display, store or keep any articles of merchandise for sale on the public sidewalks or streets; or to display, place or store any merchandise for sale where said merchandise is not contained within a building or in the alternative, where there is no covering or roof over said merchandise, or in the alternative, where said merchandise is more than five (5) feet from the front of the building, but not on the public streets or sidewalks. 
(Code 1965, § 19-13) 
Sec. 13-4. - Standard requirement for street resurface; performance bond. 
(a)  Any person, firm, or corporation, who causes excavation of more than eight (8) inches in width and ten (10) feet in length on any street, shall completely resurface the entire width and length of the street where such excavation occurred. 
(b)  Before any excavation may be permitted under subsection (a), a standard performance bond must be obtained in an amount equal to one hundred fifty (150) percent of the cost of the street resurfacing requirement, as determined by the City Engineer, which bond may be a cash bond or a surety bond issued by a duly licensed surety company authorized to do business in the State of Florida, and approved by the City Attorney. 
(Ord. No. 86-11, § 1, 11-5-1986) 
Sec. 13-5. - Display outside licensed structure prohibited. 
    The display of merchandise and wears outside of the premises of a licensed structure within the City, whether the display is on private or public property, is strictly prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2000-3, § 1, 5-17-2000) 
Sec. 13-6. - Driving prohibited over a street curb and gutter. 
(a)  Driving over the edge of a street curb and/or gutter to park between a street curb and/or gutter or the sidewalk shall be prohibited. 
(b)  It is hereby established that violation of this ordinance is be punishable by a fine in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per violation. 
(c)  This ordinance is to be enforced as provided by the Code Enforcement procedures of the City of West Miami Code. 
(Ord. No. 2013-07, §§ 2-4, 9-18-2013) 
Sec. 13-7. - Shade trees in public rights-of-way. 
(a)  Authority and power . 
(1)  Delegation of authority and responsibility . The Public Works Department, under the direction of the Public Works Director, and/or his/her designee, hereinafter referred to as the "Director", shall have the authority and responsibility to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees and woody plants growing in or upon all city streets, rights-of-ways, city parks, and other public property. This shall include the removal of trees that may threaten electrical, telephone, gas, or any municipal water or sewer line, or any tree that is affected by fungus, insect, or other pest disease. 
(2)  Coordination among city departments . All city departments will coordinate as necessary with the Director and will provide services as required to ensure compliance with this ordinance as it relates to streets, alleys, rights-of-way, drainage, easements and other public properties not under direct jurisdiction of the Director. 
(3)  The Director of the Public Works Department shall implement the recommendations made by the Park, Trees Advisory Board as directed by the Mayor and City Commission after adoption. 
(4)  Interference . No person shall hinder, prevent, delay, or interfere with the Director or his agents while engaged in carrying out the execution or enforcement of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2017-01 , § 1, 2-1-2017) 
Secs. 13-8-13-13. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Excavations, § 5-71 et seq. 

Sec. 13-14. - Provisions declared additional and supplemental. 
    The provisions of this article shall constitute an additional and supplemental procedure for the construction or repair of sidewalks, and shall not be construed to preclude the construction or repair of sidewalks in any other manner allowed by law. 
Sec. 13-15. - Resolution ordering property owners to do work, establishing specifications. 
    Whenever the Commission deems it necessary that existing sidewalks be repaired or that new sidewalks be constructed within the City, the Commission may, by resolution passed and adopted by a three-fifths ( 3/5 ) majority vote, require the property owners around or along whose several lots such sidewalks are constructed or are to be constructed to repair such existing sidewalks or to construct new sidewalks around such property, where none exist, in accordance with specifications and requirements established by the Commission, such specifications and requirements to be set forth in said resolution. Such resolution shall further require that repair or construction of such sidewalks shall be completed by said property owners within sixty (60) days after passage of said resolution and notification thereof as hereinafter provided. The City Clerk shall have on file in his office a copy of such resolution setting forth such specifications and requirements for inspection by property owners, their agents and other members of the public. 
(Code 1965, § 19-22) 
Sec. 13-16. - Notice to property owners. 
(a)  Required. The City Clerk shall, within ten (10) days after the passage of a resolution requiring the repair or construction of sidewalks within the City, issue a notice to each and every property owner of lots around or along which sidewalks are to be repaired or constructed. Said notice shall be substantially in the following form, to wit: 
    "To: ____________ 
    You, as the owner of the following described real estate fronting and abutting on ____________ Street in the City of West Miami, Florida, to wit: 
    are advised that the City Council of West Miami has ordered that you repair existing sidewalks, or construct new sidewalks, in front of and abutting your property on said street, and you are hereby required to repair or construct same within sixty (60) days from date hereof. Said sidewalks are to be constructed in accordance with certain specifications and requirements as contained in Resolution of the City Council dated ____________ , 19 ____________ , being numbered ____________ , which is on file in the City Clerk's Office, 901 S.W. 62nd Avenue, West Miami, Florida, and subject to city inspection. 
    CITY OF WEST MIAMI, FLORIDA 
    By ____________ 
    City Clerk" 
(b)  Service by mail. Said notices shall be served upon the owners of said property as shown by the real estate tax rolls of the City, by mail, within ten (10) days after passage of such resolution. Upon certification by the City Clerk that such notices have been mailed to the property owners at the addresses shown on said tax roll, said notices shall be deemed served upon said owners. 
(c)  Service by posting. The City Clerk shall, within ten (10) days after the passage of such resolution requiring repair or construction of sidewalks, post a copy of such resolution at a conspicuous place in the City Hall for a period of sixty (60) days, and upon certification by the City Clerk of such posting, such posting shall be deemed and shall constitute notice to the owners of property whose names and addresses are unknown. 
(Code 1965, § 19-23) 
Sec. 13-17. - Bids and contracts to do work not done by owners. 
(a)  If any or all of the property owners shall not comply with the resolution and notice requiring repair and construction of sidewalks within the time prescribed thereby, then the City Manager shall secure at least three (3) competitive sealed bids for the repair and/or construction of such sidewalks. After securing at least three (3) such bids the City Manager shall present said secured bids at the next meeting of the Commission for opening and for action by the Commission; provided, that prior to the opening of said sealed bids the City Manager may submit to the Commission in writing an estimate prepared by the City Engineer of the cost of such repairs and construction if performed by employees of the City; and the Commission may consider such estimate along with the other bids. The Commission at all times reserves the right to reject any and all bids for any reason whatsoever, or to waive any informalities in the bids, including the estimate submitted by the City Manager, if any. In the event the City Manager is unable to obtain three (3) bids, the Commission, by a four-fifths ( 4/5 ) majority vote, may authorize such repairs and construction. 
(b)  Any contract for the repair or construction of sidewalks shall be in writing and shall be filed in the office of the City Clerk, and shall provide that the whole amount due thereunder shall not be paid until the work shall have been inspected and accepted by the Commission; and twenty (20) percent of the original contract price shall remain unpaid until such final inspection and acceptance of the work by the Commission; provided, however, that this subsection shall not apply to repairs or construction of sidewalks done by employees of the City under the supervision of the City Manager or City Engineer. 
(Code 1965, § 19-24) 
Sec. 13-18. - Costs charged to property owners; lien declared. 
    The cost of repair and construction of such sidewalks, together with the cost arising under such resolution requiring the construction or repair of sidewalks, shall be charged to the owner of such real estate pro rata, according to the number of lineal feet of such real estate around which or along which such sidewalks are constructed or repaired pursuant to such resolution, and shall constitute a lien superior in dignity to all other liens upon such real property. 
(Code 1965, § 19-25) 
Sec. 13-19. - Commission to fix pro rata shares of costs. 
    The Commission is hereby authorized to fix the pro rata proportional amount of the cost of repair and construction of such sidewalks against each lot, piece or parcel thereof, around or along which such sidewalks are repaired or constructed; said proportionment to be made by a resolution passed and adopted by a three-fifths ( 3/5 ) vote of the Commission at the regular Commission meeting next following completion of the repairs and construction provided for by such resolution. 
(Code 1965, § 19-26) 
Sec. 13-20. - Notice to owners of costs; time limit for payment; filing notice of lien. 
    Within ten (10) days after passage of the resolution apportioning the cost of sidewalk repairs and construction, the City Clerk shall mail to the property owners a notice advising the pro rata cost assessed against such property owners and demanding payment thereof within thirty (30) days. At the expiration of said thirty (30) day period the City Clerk shall prepare a list of those property owners who have failed to pay their pro rata share of repair and construction cost in accordance with the resolution, and shall file claims of lien in the office of the Clerk of the Circuit Court in accordance with law. 
(Code 1965, § 19-27) 
Sec. 13-21. - Collection of costs, enforcement of liens. 
    Liens provided for herein may be enforced by suits at law or in equity or in any other manner provided for the collection of liens by the general laws of the State of Florida. The Commission may authorize the City Manager or City Clerk to enter into agreements with property owners for the payment of their pro rata share of repair and construction cost in annual installments, including interest at six (6) percent on unpaid balance, not to exceed a period of five (5) years; and the City Manager shall have the duty of enforcing collection of all amounts due the City Manager by property owners by reason of repair or construction of sidewalks pursuant to this article and resolutions adopted hereunder. 
(Code 1965, § 19-28) 
Secs. 13-22-13-31. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TREES AND SHRUBS NEAR PUBLIC WAYS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Planting trees or shrubs on city property, § 10-7. 

Sec. 13-32. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    Public parkway means that parcel of land lying between the sidewalk or sidewalk line of any property and the curb, or where there is no curb, the edge of street pavement. 
    Street intersection means the area of street right-of-way lying within the property lines of corner properties extended. 
(Code 1965, § 19-1) 
Sec. 13-33. - Planting near street intersections prohibited. 
    Except as is otherwise provided by section 13-34, it shall be unlawful for anyone to plant any tree, shrub or plant within thirty (30) feet of any street intersection within the City. Trees, plants and shrubs existing on October 2, 1963, shall be kept cut back and trimmed in such a manner as not to materially impede or obstruct the vision of persons using the street and sidewalk at such intersection. 
(Code 1965, § 19-2) 
Sec. 13-34. - Planting in parkway near intersection. 
    No person shall plant any tree, shrub or plant within any parkway within thirty (30) feet of any street intersection unless such plantings shall meet the following requirements: 
(a)  The plantings shall not obstruct the sidewalk, street, or any driveway through the parkway. 
(b)  The plantings will be of varieties whose root systems will not undermine or otherwise damage sidewalks, curbs, driveways or streets. 
(c)  The plantings will not be of varieties which shed leaves, flowers, seeds, nuts, fruit, bark, or other matter excessively, thereby causing undue maintenance and cleaning. 
(d)  The plantings will not materially interfere with or impede vision at street intersections or driveways. 
(e)  The plantings will not interfere with or adversely affect any public utility installation, in, upon, or over the parkway. 
(f)  The plantings shall be of varieties suitable to the area and compatible with the neighborhood. 
(g)  The plantings will not prohibit the parking of vehicles in the parkway and will be at least ten (10) feet from existing trees, shrubs, and other plantings. 
(h)  The proposed plantings will not be of varieties which are poisonous or produce poisonous fruits or flowers, or produce barbs, or spines, or are otherwise dangerous to humans, domestic animals or birds. 
(Code 1965, § 19-3) 
Sec. 13-35. - Plants extending over sidewalks. 
    No person owning or occupying property within the City shall permit any tree, shrub or plant growing thereon and which abuts or extends to or over a public sidewalk to grow out over the public sidewalk at a height of less than eight (8) feet, and every such person shall keep all such trees, shrubs and plants cut back or trimmed so that same do not interfere with or impede the use of the abutting public sidewalk by persons using same. 
(Code 1965, § 19-5)

Cross reference- Occupational license, § 9-1.
