adverse effects will be eliminated or minimized] to the maximum extent reasonably
feasible, and that the use and occupancy of the proposed planned development will be
compatible and harmonious with other development in the area to a degree which will
avoid substantial depreciation of the value of nearby property.
2B.5. Planned Development Generally:
How Designated:
2B.5-1. Designation on Official Zoning Map.
Upon approval of a special use permit for a planned development, the
boundaries of such development shall be placed upon the Official Zoning Map of the
City, with a reference in the margin to the "By Resolution No. Of the City
Commission of West Miami, Florida, adopted on (date) , a (indicate type) planned
development was approved for this property by special use permit. The requirements
applying to such permit are on file in the office of the City Clerk."
2B.6. Planned Developments Generally:
Procedures for Approval.
Application for special use approval for a planned development. shall be on
forms prepared by the City and shall be filed in the office of the Director of Zoning
Department. The following procedures shall be followed and requirements met:
2B.6-1. Pre-application Conference.
Before submitting an application for special use approval of a planned
development, a prospective applicant shall confer with a representative or
representatives of the City to be designated by the City Manager. The purpose of the
pre-application conference or conferences is to permit the prospective applicant to
obtain guidance and information before entering into binding commitments or incurring
substantial expense in the preparation of plans, surveys, and other data. The City, on
the other hand, becomes aware at the pre-application conference or conferences of the
location, character, and magnitude of the proposed planned development so that
appropriate City arrangements can be made for future proper review of any application
that may result. No statement made or information given during such pre-application
conference or conferences shall be binding upon the City or the prospective applicant.
2B.6-2. Applications; Materials to be Submitted.
Materials to be submitted with applications for approval of a special use
permit for planned development, or on subsequent request by the City Administration,
Planning and Zoning Board or City Commission shall include all plans, maps, designs,
studies, and reports which may reasonably be required to make the determinations
required by these regulations and are necessary to the decision in the particular case
with sufficient copies for referrals and records. More specifically, all of the following
shall be required before the application shall be considered for processing, together with
the required fee.
2B.6-2(l). Report.
A report identifying all property ownership and beneficial interest within the
boundaries of the proposed planned development and giving evidence of unified control
of the entire area. The report shall state agreement of all owners or holders of
beneficial interest to:
(a) Proceed with the proposed development according to the terms
of-' any final special permit approving the planned development,
including such modifications as may be set by the city commission in
the manner provided by subsection 2B; and (b) Conform in the process
of development to the preliminary development concept plan, and to
proposals for staging of development, according to requirements set
out below, and
2 B. 6-2 (2). Survey.
A survey of the proposed planned development showing property lines and
ownerships; and existing features, including streets, alleys, basements, utility lines,
existing land use, general topography, and physical features; and
2B.6-2(3) Preliminary Development Concept Plan.
A preliminary development concept plan(s) for the planned development,
indicating:
(a) the name of the proposed planned development, and the names of the
developers) and professional planner(s).
(b) Scale, date, north arrow.
(c) Location, height, floor area, residential density of existing structures, if
any; and approximate location, orientation,, height, floor area, residential or
other density, and use or uses (as applicable) of proposed structures or
portions of structures.
(d) Conceptual site plan(s), conceptual floor plan(s), and conceptual
elevations of all buildings, uses, and improvement as intended to be located,
constructed, and used.
(e) Points of ingress and egress for principal pedestrian, automotive, rapid
and/or mass transit and service traffic, and circulation patterns within and
around the proposed planned development.
(f) Location, character, and scale of parking and service facilities (area
and number of spaces in off-street parking areas, number and area of offstreet
loading facilities, character of rapid transit or other modes of mass
transit related facilities, and the like; location of principal service areas for
major structures or complexes).
(g) Relation of abutting land uses and zoning districts to the proposed
planned development, including, where view protection is an objective,
location of principal public viewpoints into or through the proposed planned
development.
(h) Existing lots or blocks, if any, and general pattern of proposed lots or
blocks, if any.
(i) Location of existing and proposed public and quasi-public systems for
pedestrian use or common enjoyment (excluding automotive uses); scale of
such systems; indication of open space, open air, and internal components.
(j) Where determined necessary a professional market analysis and an
analysis of the economic impact of the proposed development may also be
required. The preliminary development concept plan is one of the elements of
submittal required for determination as to internal relationships between or
among uses and activities proposed and their supporting systems and
facilities, and relationships to surrounding uses, activities, systems, and
facilities. With respect to preliminary development concept plans, it is the
intent of these planned development regulations that such plans shall include
all data reasonably necessary for determining whether or not the propose
development meets the general and specific requirements and limitations,
including the intent, of these planned development regulations. Therefore,
information in addition to that specified above may be requested in
connection with preliminary development concept plans when necessary to
make such determinations with regard to a particular planned development;
such information shall be provided by the applicant, if reasonably necessary
to make such determinations, before further processing of the application for
planned development proceeds. In addition there shall be provided:
21B.6-2(4).Special Surveys, Approvals, Preliminary Approvals, or Reports Required
Where
Development is Depended on Such Surveys, Approvals, or Reports.
Special surveys, approvals, or preliminary approvals (as appropriate to the
particular case), or reports (such as a report under Ch. 38O.O6, Florida Statutes., for
Development of Regional Impact) required by the Charter or ordinances of Dade
County, the laws of Florida, or the laws of the United States shall be submitted to the
City by the applicant prior to the public hearing by the Planning and Zoning Board on
the planned development application, where such proposed planned development, in
entirety or major element thereof, is dependent upon such special surveys, approvals,
or preliminary approvals, or reports.
2B.6-2(5).Indications as to Nature and Succession of Staging.
Where a planned development is to be constructed in stages, indications as
to the nature of the planned development, uses, location, and floor areas, residential or
other densities to be developed and timing of beginning of development of the first
stage; and similar information on succeeding states; provided, that in lieu. of an
indication of specific timing, initiation of succeeding stages may be made dependent
upon completion of all or substantial portions of earlier stages.
2B.6-2(6).Proposals on Provision and Continuing Operation and Maintenance of
Facilities for Common Use.
Proposals describing provisions to be made concerning establish-merit and
continuing operation and maintenance of such areas, facilities, and improvements as
will be for common use by some or all of the occupants or employees of the planned
development and/or persons visiting the development, but will not be provided,,
operated, or maintained at general public expense, giving adequate assurances to the
City that such areas, facilities and improvements will be continued, operated, and
maintained without future expense to the taxpayers of the City of West Miami.
21B.6-2(7).Proposals Concerning Restrictive Covenants.
Proposals concerning restrictive covenants, if any, to be recorded with
respect to property included in the planned development.
21B.6-3. Actions Following Receipt of Application for Approval of Special Permit for
Planned Development.
21B.6-3(l).Time Limitations for Zoning Department Review.
Upon receipt of a completed application for approval of a special use permit
for planned development, the Zoning Department shall review the application and
submit findings and recommendations which shall be delivered to the Planning and
Zoning Board and the City Commission within thirty (30) days (a) of the receipt of the
completed application, or (b) of termination of conferences described in 2B.6-3 below,
or (c) of time of request by applicant to proceed without further conferences.
2B.6-3(2).Zoning Department Review and Recommendation; Conferences with
Applicants.The purpose of review, findings, and recommendations by the Zoning
Department shall be to determine whether the application for approval of a special
permit for planned development and accompanying documents conform to the intent
and purpose of the adopted West Miami Comprehensive Plan and to the general and
specific requirements of this Subsection 2B as related to the type of planned
development proposed, and particularly, but without limitation thereby, whether
instruments or arrangements described in the documents submitted by the applicant are
adequate to protect the City's interests. In performing the function of review, the
Department shall refer the application and supporting documents to other
governmental- departments or agencies of the City or other levels of government having
interest in or expert knowledge of the matters and considerations involved. If
determined to be necessary because of lack of expertise in particular aspects of the
application by governmental agencies or departments, the City may authorize the
employment of qualified experts to evaluate specific aspects of the proposed planned
development; it shall be the responsibility of the applicant, before the application shall
be deemed complete and ready for further processing, to pay to the City an initial
deposit, with later supplemental deposits, as necessary to be placed in an escrow
account which will be used to pay all reasonable costs associated with the processing of
the application. If there are differences between the application as submitted and
details of generally applicable zoning or other City regulations, the Department shall
make recommendations as to whether the application, as submitted or with practicable
changes, justifies a recommendation for modification of such details of generally
applicable zoning or other City regulations, on grounds that the public interest will be
served or protected to at least an equivalent degree by such modifications as by strict
application of such regulations. Determinations and limitations on such modifications
shall be under standards as set out in Subsection 2B.
During such review, the applicant may be requested by the Department to confer
on the planned development applications as originally submitted concerning suggested
changes and/or additional information necessary to make essential recommendations,
in order to assist in bringing the application and material submitted therewith as nearly
as possible into conformity with those or other regulations applying in the case, or to
define specific modifications of such regulations which seem justified in view of
equivalent or greater service of public purposes by the applications.
In the course of such conferences, any recommendations for changes shall be
recorded in writing, and shall become part of the record of the case. All such
recommendations shall be supported by the stated reasons for the proposal for change.
Applicants shall in writing indicate their agreement to such recommendations, with or
without reservations, or their disagreement, with reasons therefore, and such response
by applicants shall also be included in the record. To the extent that there is agreement
as to changes, the original application and materials submitted therewith may be altered
before further processing.
Where conferences are proposed or conducted, the thirty (30) day period for
Departmental review, findings, and recommendations shall commence either upon the
completion of such conferences or at any time upon written request of the applicant that
the application be sent to the Planning and Zoning Board.
The recommendations of the Department shall be in writing, and shall set forth
reasons in specific terms. Recommendations shall be for (a) granting of the application
in its current form, or (b) granting with clearly-defined modifications, stipulations,
conditions, or safeguards, or (c) denial, with specific reasons therefore.
2B.6-3(3) Planning and Zoning Board.
Upon receipt of the completed application for special use permit for planned
development and the review and recommendations of the Zoning Department, the
Planning and Zoning Board shall, within thirty (30) days of such receipt, formally meet
and consider the preliminary development concept plan for the planned development.
Prior to such formal meeting, the Planning and Zoning Board may hold a
conferences or workshops with the applicant and his representatives and the City
representatives for the purpose of allowing the Planning and Zoning Board to become
familiar with the proposed planned development and, specifically, the preliminary
development concept plan. Any such conferences or workshops shall not be held
unless three (3) days notice of such conferences or workshops by posting at the City
Hall, has been given. Such conferences or workshops shall not be public hearings and
it shall be up to the discretion of the Chairman as to whether questions from members
of the public shall be entertained.
Formal consideration by the Planning and Zoning Board of the preliminary
development concept plan may take place at a special or regular meeting of the Board,
but no formal consideration shall be given by the Board unless at least three (3) days
notice of such meeting, together with the meeting agenda, has been posted at the City
Hall.
The Planning and Zoning Board shall take formal action on the preliminary
development concept plan and shall send its recommendations thereon to the Planning
and Zoning Board and the City commission, at least seven (7) days prior to the date for
public hearing on the matter by the Planning and Zoning Board. The Planning and
Zoning Board shall recommend (a) approval of the preliminary development concept
plan, (b) approval of the preliminary development concept plan with conditions,
modifications, safeguards, or stipulations, or (c) denial of the preliminary development
concept plan. Planning and Zoning Board recommendations shall be made in writing
and shall be based upon the applicable standards and requirements for the preliminary
development concept plan and the applicable provisions of Zoning Ordinance #282 of
the City of West Miami.
2B.6-3(4) Planning and Zoning Board Procedure;
Actions; Findings; Recommendations.
Within forty-five (45) days after receipt of the completed application for special
use permit for planned development and the review, findings, and recommendation of
the Zoning Department, the Planning and Zoning Board shall hold a formal public
hearing on the application and make recommendations to the City Commission in the
manner herein set out and in the context of the standards applying generally to planned
developments and the further particular standards applying to the type of planned
development proposed in the application.
Prior to such formal meeting, the Planning and Zoning Board may hold a
conferences or workshops with the applicant and his representatives and with City
representatives for the purpose of allowing the Planning and Zoning Board to become
familiar with the proposed planned development and, specifically, the preliminary
development concept plan. No such conferences or workshops shall be held unless
fifteen (15) days notice of such conferences or workshops has been given by:
1. Posting at City Hall; and
2. Posting of notice on each street frontage of the subject property; and
such conferences or workshops may be recessed to a date certain, without the giving of
additional notice in the manner set out above, and shall not be a public hearing(s). It
shall be up to the discretion of the Chairman as to whether questions from the public
shall be entertained at such conferences or workshop(s).
(a) Notice.
Notification of the formal public hearing on the application by the Planning and
Zoning Board shall specify the nature of the hearing; the type of planned development
proposed; the address and legal description of the property involved; and the date, time,
and location of the public hearing. Notification shall be given at least fifteen (15) days in
advance of the hearing by:
1. Posting at the City Hall; and
2. Advertisement in a newspaper of general circulation in the city
of West Miami, Florida, except where planned development
application relating to land development located in R-1 and R2
zoning district only; and
3. Regular mail to property owners as listed in the most recent tax
rolls located within 500 feet of the boundaries of the property
proposed for planned development; and
4. Posting of notice on each street frontage of the property
proposed for planned development.
The City official charged with giving notice shall certify at the start of the public
hearing that notice has been given as herein required.
(b) Public Hearing.
The public hearing shall be held. Such hearing may be recessed to a date
certain, if time requires, without the giving of additional notice.
(c) Recommendations.
Within fifteen (15) days after the conclusion of the public hearing on the matter,
the Planning and Zoning Board shall prepare and transmit in writing to the City
Commission recommendations in the case. The Board shall recommend that the City
Commission (1) approve the application, or (2) approval of the application with
recommended modifications, conditions, limitations, or safeguards, or (3) denial of the
application. In making its recommendations, the Board shall be bound by the general
standards and requirements of these planned development regulations and by the
particular standards and requirements for the type of planned development proposed.
The Board shall state reasons for the recommendations it has given.
In reaching conclusion as to its recommendations, the Board shall make its
recommendations by considering the competent evidence presented at the hearing, and
its recommendations shall be based upon the weight of such competent evidence.
2B.6-3(5). Action by city commission.
Within ninety (90) days of receipt of the findings and recommendations of the
Planning Board, the City Commission shall hold a public hearing on the application for
special permit for planned development.
(a) Notice.
Notice of the public hearing by the City Commission shall be given in the manner
set out in subsection 2B.6-3(4) (a) (1-4), except where there is a conflict with State law
in which case the more restrictive requirements shall apply.
(b) Public Hearing.
The public hearing shall be held by the City Commission. Such hearing may be
recessed to a date certain, if time requires, without the giving of additional notice.
(c) Decision.
The decision of the City Commission shall be by resolution, which shall be
adopted by a vote of not less than three (3) members of the Commission and the
resolution shall be (a) to grant. the application for special use permit for planned
development in its current form, or (b) to grant the application for special use permit for
planned development with clearly stated and defined stipulations, modifications, or
safeguards in the context of the intent and purposes of these planned development
regulations, or (c) to deny the application, with specific reasons stated therefore. In
performing this responsibility, the City Commission shall make written findings of fact
supporting its decision, and shall be bound by the general standards and requirements
of these planned development regulations and by The particular standards and
requirements for the type of planned development proposed.
Where the applicant demonstrates by the greater weight of competent evidence
that the application meets the standards and requirements, general and specific, of
these planned development regulations, the City Commission shall approve the
application in its current form or approve the application with conditions, modifications,
safeguards, or stipulations appropriately and reasonably related to the intent, purposes,
standards, and requirements of these planned development regulations.
Where the applicant does not demonstrate by the greater weight of competent
evidence that the application meets the standards and requirements, general and
specific, of these planned development regulations, or where the greater weight of
competent evidence deduced in the course of the public hearing before the City
Commission demonstrates that the application in its current form does not meet the
standards and requirements, general and specific, of' these planned development
regulations, the City commission shall deny the application for special use permit,
stating specifically and in the context of findings of fact the reasons therefore.
In cases where there are modifications in general zoning or other City regulations,
the City Commission shall be bound to make findings and take action subject to the
requirements of subsection 2B.6-3(5) of these regulations.
(d) Staging.
If approval or approval with conditions, modifications, safeguards, or stipulations
be granted for a planned development where such development is to be staged, the
City Commission may attach such conditions and safeguards as are reasonably
necessary to insure that each stage is logical in terms of the total preliminary concept
plan, and that, if any stage is left uncompleted, there are adequate guarantees on the
part of the applicant to the City to assure that where density or floor area limitations for
the stages completed exceed limitations based on the entire development,
compensating reduction shall be made in portions remaining undeveloped, and that
where open space or other requirements for the stages completed are less than
requirements based on the entire development, compensating increases shall be made
in portions remaining undeveloped, under the total staging plan.
(e) Guarantees.
The City Commission may attach such conditions and safeguards to an approval
of a planned development as are reasonably necessary and required to protect public
interest in (1) completion of the development according to approved plans, (2) provision
for continuing operation and maintenance of such areas, facilities, and functions as are
not to be provided, operated, or maintained at general public expense, and (3) provision
for such dedications, contributions, or guarantees as are required for provision of
needed public facilities and services.
(f) Other Conditions.
The statements of paragraphs (d) and (e) preceding shall not be deemed to deny
to the City Commission the authority to set other conditions and safeguards at the time
of special permit approval, but where such conditions and safeguards are attached the
Commission shall determine that they are reasonably necessary and required to protect
the public interest and to carry out the intent and purpose of these planned development
regulations.
(g) Effect of City Commission Approval
If the City Commission shall approve the grant of special permit for planned
development in the manner and under the standards herein set out, the development
shall be indicated on the Official Zoning Map as required by subsection 2B.5-1 of these
planned development regulations. All maps, plans, documents, covenants,
agreements, stipulation.,;, conditions, and safeguards constituting the development plan
as finally approved shall be placed on file in the office of the City clerk, and shall
constitute the regulations for the specific planned development that has been approved.
All development within the boundaries of the planned development as approved shall
take place in accord with such regulations. Deviations in the course of construction
from approved plans or failure to comply with any condition, modification, stipulation, or
safeguard imposed by the terms of the grant or special permit for planned development
shall constitute a violation of Zoning ordinance #282 of the City of West Miami. In
addition, the City may resort to civil remedies to enforce the special use permit for
planned development as approved by the City Commission.
2B.7. Planned Developments Generally: Action following City Commission Approval;
Final Plans and Reports; Issuance of Building Permits.
Action following approval by the City Commission of a special permit for planned
development shall be administrative in nature,, and shall be as follows:
2B.7-1. Approval of Final Plans and Reports.
The final plan shall be in substantial accord with the preliminary development
concept plan as approved by the City Commission.
After a planned development has been approved by the city commission, no
building permit for construction within such planned development shall be issued unless
and until:
(a) The Director of the Zoning Department, with the counter signature of the City
Manager, shall have approved final plans and reports, if necessary, for the development
as a whole or for stages or portions thereof as set out by the City Commission at the
time of special use permit approval.
(b) The Planning and Zoning Board, in the manner set out in Zoning Ordinance
#282 of West Miami, shall have approved final plans for buildings and structures for the
development as a whole or for stages or portions thereof as set out by the City
Commission at the time of special use permit approval.
Approvals of final plans and reports, if necessary, shall be based upon
regulations applying at the time the special use permit for planned development as
approved by the City Commission, including specific modifications made in general
zoning or other City regulations in the action of approval.
Upon approval of final plans, as herein set out, building permits shall be issued in
the same manner as for building permits generally, provided that any requirements
concerning the order or location in which building permits are to be issued as set out in
the City Commission resolution of approval of special use permit shall be observed.
2B.7-2. Status of Approved Final Plans.
Except as provided in subsection 2B.7-3 and section 2B.8, approved final plans
shall be binding upon the applicant and heirs, assigns, or successors in interest, so long
as the planned development regulations for the particular planned development, as
proved in subsection 2B.6-3(5)(g) remain in force and applicable to the land.
2B.7-3. Changes in Final Plans and Reports.
Minor changes, not involving increases in residential or other densities or floor
area ratio, may be permitted by the City Manager upon application to the Director of the
Zoning Department by the original applicants or their successors in interest, but only
upon a finding by the City Manager that such approval will result in the project meeting
the same requirements as for approval of the original approved final plans. The Director
shall notify promptly the City Manager of any such requests for minor changes and the
City Manager shall transmit such information to the City Commission.
Other changes may be permitted only by new application for special use permit
approval for planned development, and in the manner set out in these regulations, or as
they may be amended in the future.
2B.8. Planned Development Generally: Expiration of Time Limits; Failure to Meet Other
Requirements.
When time limits are set for beginning or completion of development or stages of
development, or where other requirements are established in connection with approval
by the City Commission of a special use permit for planned development, and where
such time limits or other requirements are not met, the Direction of the Zoning
Department shall in writing inform the developer and the City Manager. The City
Manager shall promptly call the matter to the attention of the City Commission with an
account of the circumstances and the findings and recommendations of the
Department. The City Commission may refer the matter to the Planning and Zoning
Board for review and recommendation in the matter or the City Commission may review
the matter in the first instance. The development shall be afforded full opportunity to be
heard in the matter. The Commission may take action:
(a) That the approval of the special use permit as previously granted be
continued with revised time lists; or
(b) That approval be continued for part of the planned development with or
without revised time limits, that appropriate steps be taken to correct any deficiencies in
designated portions of the planned development that have not been developed, and that
planned development approval be canceled for the remaining portions of the
development as originally approved; or
(c) That planned development approval be revoked; or
(d) That such other steps be taken as will be equitable
to the property owner and to the protection of the City's interests. (90-1)
Section 2C. Protection of Environmentally Sensitive Lands. (90-14)
2C.l. General Provisions
(a) Relationship to Other Requirements Relating to the Protection of
Environmentally Sensitive Lands. In addition to meeting the following protection of
environmentally sensitive lands requirements, development plans shall comply with
applicable federal, state and water management district, county and city laws, codes,
ordinances, rules, regulations and City Comprehensive Plan relating to environmentally
sensitive lands. In all cases the strictest of the applicable standards shall apply.
(b) Conservation Element Incorporated by Reference. The Conservation
Element of the City Comprehensive Plan as from time to time amended is hereby
incorporated by reference into this Code.
(c) Compliance When Subdividing Land. Each lot of a proposed
subdivision must include a site suitable for constructing a structure in conformity with
the standards of
2C.2. Definitions
(a) Accessory Use. A use of land or structure or portion thereof customarily
incidental and subordinate to the principal use of the land or structure and located on
the same parcel with the principal use.
(b) Adjacent To A Protected Environmentally Sensitive Area. Any location
within five hundred (500) feet of the boundary of any Protected Environmentally
Sensitive Area, whether the location is on or off the development site.
(c) Adverse Effects. Any modifications, alterations, or effects on waters,
associated wetlands, or shore lines, including their quality, quantity, hydrology, surface
area, species composition, or usefulness for human or natural uses which are or may
potentially be harmful or injurious to human health, welfare, safety or property, to
biological productivity, diversity, or stability or, which unreasonably interfere with the
reasonable use of property, including outdoor recreation. The term includes secondary
and cumulative as well as direct impacts.
(d) Associated Wetland. Any wetland that is adjacent or contiguous to waters,
or which has a direct hydrologic connection to waters.
(e) Beneficial Functions of a Protected Environmentally Sensitive Area.
Those functions, described in the Conservation Element of the Comprehensive Plan,
that justify designating an area as environmentally sensitive.
(f) Pollutant. Any substance, contaminant, noise, or man-made or man-induced
alteration of the chemical, physical, biological, or radiological integrity of air or water in
quantities or at levels which are or may be potentially harmful or injurious to human
health or welfare, animal or plant life, or property, or which unreasonably interfere with
the enjoyment of life or property, including outdoor recreation.
(g) Protected Environmentally Sensitive Area. An environmentally sensitive
area designated for protection in the Conservation Element of the City Comprehensive
Plan, the Metropolitan Dade County Environmental Protection ordinance, Chapter 24,
Dade County Code and any Federal and State laws, codes, rules and regulations.
(h) Significant Adverse Effect. Any modification, alteration, or effect upon a
Protected Environmentally Sensitive Area which measurably reduces the Area's
beneficial functions as delineated in the Conservation Element of the City
Comprehensive Plan, the Metropolitan Dade County Environmental Protection
Ordinance, Chapter 24, Dade County Code and any Federal and State laws, codes,
rules and regulations.
(i) Water or Waters. Includes, but is not limited to, water on or beneath the
surface of the ground or in the atmosphere, including natural or artificial watercourses,
streams, rivers, lakes, ponds, or diffused surface water and water percolating, standing'
or flowing beneath the surface of the ground.
(j) Water Body. Any natural or artificial pond, lake, reservoir, or other area with
a discernible shoreline which ordinarily or intermittently contains water.
(k) Watercourse. Any natural or artificial channel, ditch, canal., stream, river,
creek, waterway or wetland through which water flows in a definite direction, either
continuously or intermittently, and which has a definite channel, bed, banks, or other
discernible boundary.
(l) Water's Edge and Wetland's Edge. The water's or wetland's edge shall be
determined by whichever of the following indices yields the most landward extent of
waters or wetlands:
1) the boundary established by the average annual
high water mark,
2) the landward boundary of hydra soils, or
3) the landward boundary of wetland vegetation, based on the
wetland vegetation index.
2C.3. Creation of Protected Environmentally Sensitive Zones.
(a) Wetlands Protection Zone. There is hereby created a "Wetlands Protection
Zone" in which special restrictions on development apply. The boundaries of this zone
shall be the most landward extent of the following:
1) Areas within the dredge and fill jurisdiction of the Department of
Environmental Regulation as authorized by Section 403 of the Florida Statutes.
2) Areas within the jurisdiction of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers as
authorized by Section 404, Clean Water Act or Section 10, River and Harbor Act.
3) Areas within the jurisdiction of the South Florida Water Management
District.
4) Areas within the jurisdiction of Dade County, Florida, designated as
Wetlands Protection Zone and/or Environmentally Sensitive Zones pursuant to
Metropolitan Dade County Environmental Protection Ordinance, Chapter 24, Miami-
Dade County Code.
5) Areas designated as Environmentally Sensitive Zones under the City
Comprehensive Plan.
(b) Request For Determination of Boundaries.
A developer may obtain a determination of the boundaries of a Protected
Environmentally Sensitive Zone by submitting to the Department of Planning & Zoning
by certified mail or hand delivery, a Request for Determination of Boundaries. The
request must, as a minimum, set forth an adequate description of the land the developer
wishes to develop, the nature of the developer's right to ownership or control of the land,
and other information needed to make the determination. The Department shall make
the determination within ten (10) working days of receiving the needed information from
the developer.
2C.4. Development Activities Within Protected Environmentally Sensitive Zones.
(a) Generally. Except as expressly provided herein or in any Federal, State or
County law, code, ordinance, rule or regulation, no development activity shall be
undertaken in a Protected Environmentally Sensitive Zone.
(b) Activities Presumed To Have An Insignificant Adverse Effect on
Protected Environmentally Sensitive Zones. Certain activities are presumed to have
an insignificant adverse effect on the beneficial functions of Protected Environmentally
Sensitive Zones. Notwithstanding the prohibition in Section 4 (A) of this Part., these
activities may be undertaken unless it is shown by competent and substantial evidence
that the specific activity would have a significant adverse effect on the Protected
Environmentally Sensitive Area.
The following uses and activities are presumed to have an insignificant
adverse effect on protected environmentally sensitive zones, including but not limited to
wetlands protection zones:
1) Scenic, historic, wildlife, or scientific preserves.
2) Minor maintenance or emergency repair to existing structures or improved
areas.
3) Cleared walking trails having no structural components.
4) Timber catwalks and docks four (4) feet or less in width.
5) Commercial or recreational fishing or hunting, and creation and
maintenance of temporary blinds.
6) Cultivating agricultural or horticultural products that occur naturally on the
site.
7) Constructing fences where no fill activity is required and where
navigational access will not be impaired by construction of the fence.
8) Developing an area that no longer functions as a wetland, except a former
wetland that has been filled or altered in violation of any rule, regulation, statute, or this
Code. The developer must demonstrate that the water regime has been permanently
altered, either artificially or naturally, in a manner to preclude the area from maintaining
surface water or hydro periodicity necessary to sustain wetland structure and function.
If the water regime of a wetland has been artificially altered, but wetland species remain
the dominant vegetation of the area,, the Department shall determine the feasibility of
restoring the altered hydrology. If the wetland may be restored at a cost that is
reasonable in relation to benefits to be derived from the restored wet]-and, the
developer shall, as a condition of development, restore the wetland and comply with the
requirements of this Code.
9) Developing a "Wetlands Storm Water Discharge Facility" or "Treatment
Wetland" in accordance with state permits received under Chapters 17-25 and 17-6,
Florida Administrative Code.
10) Any other uses and activities presumed to have an insignificant
adverse effect on protected Environmentally Protected Zones including but not limited to
wetland protections provided in any Federal, State and county laws, codes, ordinances,
rules and regulations.
2C.5. Prohibited on-Going Activities
The following standards apply to post-development activities taking place within
any Protected Environmentally Sensitive Zone.
(a) Point Source and Non-point Source Discharges. Absent an amendment to
the development order, point source and non-point source discharges shall continue to
meet the standards applicable to the original development.
(b) Clearing. Absent an amendment to the development order, no person shall
clear more vegetation than was permitted for the original development.
(c) Handling and Storage of Fuel, Hazardous and Toxic Substances, and
Wastes. Developments where fuel or toxic substances will be stored, transferred, or
sold shall employ the best available facilities and procedures for the prevention,
containment, recovery, and mitigation of spillage of fuel and toxic substances. Facilities
and procedures shall be designed to prevent substances from entering the water or soil,
and employ adequate means for prompt and effective clean-up of spills that do occur.
No toxic or hazardous wastes or substances shall be stored in outdoor containers.
(d) Prohibited Uses. The long-term storage of equipment or materials, and the
disposal of wastes shall be prohibited.
(e) Fertilizers, Herbicides, or Pesticides. Fertilizers, herbicides, or pesticides
shall not be applied in a Protected Environmentally Sensitive Zone except for projects
conducted under the authority of Sections 373.451-373.4595, Florida Statutes, the
Surface Water Improvement and Management Act, and governmentally authorized
mosquito control programs. Fertilizers, pesticides, and herbicides used in Restricted
Development Zones shall be applied sparingly and at appropriate rates and time
intervals.
(f) Spray Vehicles. Vehicles used for mixing or spraying chemicals are
prohibited from withdrawing water directly from waters.
(g) Pump-out, Holding, and Treatment Facilities for Wastes from Mobile
Sources. Sewage, solid waste, and petroleum waste generated by vessels or vehicles
on the site shall be properly collected and disposed of.
Section 2D. Protection of Public Potable Water Supply Wells.
The Potable Water Supply Well Protection Ordinance, sec. 24-12.1, Dade County
Code, which is applicable in West Miami, Florida, is hereby adopted by reference as if
fully set forth herein.
Section 2E. Development within Flood Hazard Districts.
Before any development order may be issued in the City of West Miami,
compliance with Chapter 11C of the Dade County Code shall be fully complied with and
the City of West Miami hereby adopts by reference said Chapter 11C by reference as if
fully set forth herein.
Section 2F. Storm water Management and Control of Drainage.
(a) Levels of Service Standards. All storm water management level of service
standards provided in the City's Comprehensive Plan shall be met before any
development order may be issued in the City of West Miami, Florida.
(b) Permits. Before any development order may be issued in the City of West
Miami, except as hereinafter provided, all non-exempt development are required to
receive appropriate permits from Florida Department of Environmental Regulations in
accordance with Chapter 17-25, Florida Administrative Code, the South Florida Water
Management District and Dade County.
(c) Exemptions. The following development activities are exempt from these
storm water management requirements, except that steps to control erosion and
sedimentation must be taken for all development.
(1) The construction of a single family or duplex residential dwelling unit
and accessory structures on a single parcel of land.
(2) Any development within a subdivision if each of the following
conditions has been met:
(a) Storm water management provisions for the subdivision were
previously approved and remain valid as part of a final plat or development plan; and
(b) The development is conducted in accordance with the storm water
management provisions submitted with the final plat or development plan.
(3) Bona fide agricultural activity, including forestry, provided farming
activities are conducted in accordance with the requirements set forth in an approved
Soil Conservation Service Conservation Plan and forestry activities are conducted in
accordance with the Civil culture Best Management Practices (BMP) Manual (1979)
published by the Florida Division of Forestry. If the Conservation Plan and forestry
BMP's are not implemented accordingly, this exemption shall become void and a storm
water permit shall be required.
(4) Maintenance activity that does not change or affect the quality, rate,
volume or location of storm water flows on the site or of storm water runoff.
(5) Action taken under emergency conditions to prevent imminent harm or
danger to persons, or to protect property from imminent fire, violent storms, hurricanes
or other hazards. A report of the emergency action shall be made to the Department as
soon as practicable.
Section 2G. Consistency and Concurrency
Determinations
(a) Generally.
Purpose. It is the purpose of this Article to describe the requirements and
procedures for determination of consistency of proposed development projects with the
City of West Miami's Comprehensive Plan, including meeting the concurrent
requirements of the plan.
Concurrency. A condition where specified facilities and services have or will have
the necessary capacity to meet the adopted level of service standard at the time of
impact of the development project.
(b) Determination of Consistency. All development in the City of West Miami
shall be consistent with City's Comprehensive Plan and this Zoning Ordinance. Where
Zoning ordinance is inconsistent with the City's Comprehensive Plan, then and in that
event, all development shall be consistent with the Comprehensive Plan.
(c) System for the Management of Concurrency.
(1) Generally. The following method of ensuring concurrency shall be known as
the System for the Management of Concurrency (SYMCON). The SYMCON is based
upon the City Comprehensive Plan, especially the Capital Improvements Element and
adopted level of service standards. The system is designed to ensure that the issuance
of a Final Development Order will not result in a degradation of the adopted levels of
service for specified public facilities and services. The SYMCON also includes a
monitoring system for determination of the availability of adequate capacity of public
facilities and services to meet the adopted level of service standards.
(2) Adopted Levels of Service Shall Not Be Degraded.
A. General Rule. All applications for development orders shall demonstrate that
the proposed development does not degrade adopted levels of service in the City. An
application for a development permit shall demonstrate that the proposed development
does not degrade adopted levels of service if there exists no development order under
which the permit is sought, and no development order is required prior to the issuance
of the permit, e.g. a residence on a parcel of unplatted land. The latest point, at which
concurrency is determined is the final development order. If no development is
required, the latest point to determine concurrency is the first development permit on a
site.
B. Exception. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the prescribed levels of service
may be degraded during the actual construction of new facilities, if upon completion of
the new facilities the prescribed levels of service will be met.
3. Determination of Availability Capacity. For the purpose of these regulations
the available capacity of a facility shall be determined by:
A. Adding Together
1. The total capacity of existing facilities operating
at the required level of service; and
2. The total capacity of new facilities, if any, that will become available on or
before the date of occupancy of the development. The capacity of new facilities may be
counted only if one or more of the following is shown:
a. Construction of the new facilities is under way at the time of issuance
of the final development order.
b. The new facilities are the subject of a binding executed contract for the
construction of the facilities or the provision of services at the time of issuance of the
final development order.
c. The new facilities are guaranteed in an enforceable development
agreement. An enforceable development agreement may include, but is not limited to,
development agreements pursuant to Section 163.3220, Fla. Statutes., or an agreement
or development order pursuant to Chapter 380, Fla. Statutes. Such facilities shall be
consistent with the capital improvements element of the City Comprehensive Plan. The
agreement must guarantee that the necessary facilities and services will be in place
when the impacts of the development occur.
B. Subtracting From That Number the Sum Of
1. The demand for the service or facility created by existing development
as documented in the City Comprehensive Plan; and
2. The demand for the service or facility created by the anticipated completion
of other approved developments, redevelopment, or other development activity.
C. Action upon Failure to Show Available Capacity. Where available capacity
cannot be shown, the following methods may be used to maintain adopted level of
service:
1. The project owner or developer may provide the necessary
improvements to maintain level of service. In such case the application shall include
appropriate plans for improvements, documentation that such improvements are
designed to provide the capacity necessary to achieve or maintain the level of service,
and recordable instruments guaranteeing the construction, consistent with calculations
of capacity above.
2. The proposed project may be altered such that projected level of
service is no less than the adopted level of service.
3. Burden of Showing Compliance on Developer. The burden of showing
compliance with these levels of service requirements shall be upon the developer. In
order to be approvable, applications for development approval shall provide sufficient
information showing compliance with these standards.
4. Initial Determination of concurrency. The initial determination of
concurrency occurs during the review of the Preliminary Development Plan,
and shall include compliance with the level of service standards adopted by
the City.
(d) Adopted Levels of Service.
Development activity shall not be approved unless there is sufficient available capacity
to sustain the level of service established in the City Comprehensive Plan which is
hereby adopted by reference. (90-14)
Section 3. DISTRICTS
3.1 In order to regulate and restrict the erection, reconstruction, alteration,
location and use of buildings, structures, and land for trade,, industry, residence or other
purposes and the location thereof, and to regulate size of buildings, setbacks and other
open spaces and to regulate or limit the percentage of lot that may be occupied and the
density of population in the City of West Miami, Florida, the City of West Miami is
hereby divided into use and area districts as follows: 3.2 (85-02) -'R1' District being
resident or single family district subject to provisions of Sections 3, 4 and 5.
R-1 use shall include every use as a single family dwelling
R-2 use shall include every use as a duplex dwelling
R-3 use shall include every use as a golf course, tennis courts, places of
worship, private clubs, recreation buildings, playgrounds, private schools, or
other privately owned public gathering place
R-4 use shall include every Municipal or Governmental use
R-5 use shall include every use as commercial off-street parking including
commercial driveways not otherwise provided for in this Ordinance. No such
use may be permitted in any District nor shall any installation and
construction of any commercial off-street parking improvement, including offstreet
driveways be made thereon unless an application therefore is approved
by the Planning and Zoning Board subject to appeal to the City Council, as
provided for in Sections 18.9, 18.10, 18.10-1 and 18.10-2 herein. Such
approvals shall be granted if such use meets the following standards or
criteria:
(1) would not cause obnoxious odors;
(2) would not cause loud noises;
(3) would not be unsightly;
(4) would not be a public or private nuisance;
(5) would be compatible with the neighborhood;
(6) would not be otherwise detrimental to the residential community of this
City. (85-02)
3.21 No R-3 or R-4 use shall be permitted unless the City Council shall, after due
notice to owners of adjacent property and upon public hearing, order and direct the
issuance of a permit.
3.3 "A District being Multi-Family District, subject to provisions of Section 4 and 5,
permitting the following uses:
(a) Any use permitted in "R1' Districts
(b) Multiple dwelling use
3.4 C" District being Commercial District, subject to provisions of Section 4 and
5, and permitting the following uses:
(a) Any use permitted in "R1' Districts
(b) Any use permitted in "A' Districts
(c) A general business use
3.5 (90-2) The boundaries of the above use districts are those shown on the map
of the City of West Miami attached to and made a part of this Ordinance as Exhibits #1
through #4, inclusive, and that said map of the City of West Miami is amended by
providing that the following real property be re-zoned in accordance with the
Comprehensive Plan of the City, conditioned upon a Warranty Deed being executed by
the property owner thereof and duly recorded, granting to the City the East 50 feet of
the North 170 feet of the Northwest 1/4 of the Southwest 1/4 of the Northwest1/4 less
the South 56.67 feet of the East 144 feet, Section 12, Township 54 South, Range 40
East, Dade County, Florida, providing for the West 35 feet, the North 25 feet, and the
East 25 feet thereof dedicated to the public for street purposes for the use as a public
park, providing further that said real property conveyed to the city be counted for lot
coverage as to unit numbers and for green area planting requirements under the Code
of the City of West Miami, Florida, for the remaining portions of the property after
conveyance to the City of the East 50 Feet thereof.(90-2)
The Official Zoning Map of the City of West Miami, Florida, be and is hereby
amended and the following described real property be re-zoned in accordance with the
Comprehensive Plan of the City of West Miami:
North 170 feet of the Northwest 1/4 of the Southwest 1/4 of the Northwest
1/4, less the South 56.67 feet of the East 144 feet, Section 12, Township 54
South, Range 40 East, Dade County, Florida, less the West 25 feet, the North
25 feet and the East 25 feet thereof, dedicated for street purposes, and less
the East 50 feet of the North 170 feet of the Northwest 1/4 of the Southwest
1/4 of the Northwest 1/4, less the South 56.67 feet of the East 144 feet,
Section 12, Township 54 So., Range 40 East, Dade County, Florida, less the
West 25 feet, the North 25 feet and the East 25 feet thereof dedicated for
street purposes. (90-2)
3.6 No building shall be erected, constructed, reconstructed or structurally
altered, nor shall any building or land be used for any purpose other than the use
permitted in the Use District. in which building or land is located. Every structure shall
be located on a lot as herein defined and in no case shall there be more than one
building on one lot except as hereinafter provided for.
3.7 No lot area shall be reduced or diminished so as to violate the setback or lot
coverage requirements as herein prescribed, nor shall the density of population be
increased in any manner except in conformity with the area regulations herein
established.
3.8 Any existing recorded restrictions of included subdivisions shall be
considered a part of this Zoning Ordinance, except where such restrictions are in actual
conflict with the provisions of this ordinance, in which case this ordinance shall control.
3.9 (84-02(b) Wherever there may exist or had ever existed in whole or in part,
whether voluntarily or involuntarily removed, destroyed, demolished or decayed in
whole or in part, a building which was constructed on a building site containing two (2)
or more platted lots, said building site shall not thereafter be reduced or diminished in
any manner to less than that required by the district regulations wherein the lots are
situated, nor shall any such building site be reduced or diminished in any manner which
would cause to be created a non-conforming lot. (8402(b)
Section 4. USE DISTRICT REGULATIONS
4.1. "R1' USE DISTRICTS. (91-02)
4.11 In the "R1' residence or single-family
districts no building or land shall be used and no building be hereafter erected,
constructed, reconstructed, or structurally altered which is designed or intended to be
used or occupied for any purpose except "R1' use, unless otherwise provided for in this
ordinance.
4.12 (a) Not more than one principal building shall be erected on a lot in "RI' Use
District; except that one utility shed as provided in subsection 4A.4 and one of the
following detached buildings may be constructed on a residential lot: garage, carport,
gazebo, shade house, playhouse and chickee. Such utility shed and detached
accessory building shall not be constructed unless in conjunction with or as an
accessory to the principal building. No utility shed, or an allowed detached accessory
building described above, shall be used or occupied as living quarters nor shall any
commercial use or activity be conducted therein in "R-1' Use District. Except for a utility
shed, the area of a accessory building shall be included and become a part of the
allowed maximum of 35% lot coverage as set forth in subsection 4.17 of this ordinance.
The setback thereof shall be the same as principal building except garages may have 3
foot side yard and 3 foot rear yard setbacks.
(b) A detached garage, gazebo, shade house, playhouse or chickee may
contain electrical or plumbing facilities, except there shall be no electrical or plumbing
facilities or fixtures for bathroom or kitchen use.
4.13 Every principal building in "R-1" Use District shall contain not less than 1,000
square feet of floor area exclusive of porches, garages or Porte coachers.
4.14 Every principal building in "R-2" Use District shall contain not less than 700
square feet of floor area per dwelling unit exclusive of porches, garages or Porte
coachers.
4.15 In "R" Use Districts the front setbacks shall be not less than 25 feet from the
zoned street line, 7.5 feet or 10% of lot width, whichever is greater, from the side
property lines and 15 feet from the rear property line, except for swimming pools and
swimming pool enclosures as set forth in Section 11.3. On corner lots, the front setback
shall be 25 feet from the zoned street line and the exterior side setback shall be 15 feet
from the zoned street line. The interior side setback shall be 7.5 feet, and the rear
setback shall be 15 feet. In "R-3" Use Districts the side setbacks shall be not less than
15 feet or 10% of lot width, whichever is greater. Front and rear setbacks shall be as
set forth above.
4.16 In the principal building constructed on a lot in "R" Use District, no individual
room shall be completely separated from the remainder of the principal building. Only
one kitchen shall be provided on any lot in "R-1" Use Districts and only one kitchen shall
be provided per dwelling unit on any lot in "R-2" Use District.
4.17 No R-1 or R-2 USE shall exceed one (1) story, and each residential
improvement on an R-1 or R-2 Lot shall comply with the following open space and lot
coverage requirements:
(a) Minimum of 35% of the net residential land area shall be maintained in
landscaped open space, which space may include recreation areas not paved with
asphalt, concrete, or similar impervious materials and swimming pools excluding
abutting apron areas; and setback areas.
(b) Maximum of 35% of the net residential land area may be covered with or
occupied by the principal residential building, and an accessory building except a utility
shed is excluded.
(c) Maximum of 30% of the net residential land area may be covered with open
parking areas, vehicular drives, and service structures and devices.
Provided, however, that no paved area shall be closer than three (3) feet to any
side or rear lot line except for driveways providing ingress and egress across such side
or rear property line.
4.18 Inside lots in "R" Use Districts shall have a depth of not less than one
hundred (100) feet, a frontage of not less than sixty (60) feet and an area of not less
than six thousand (6,000) square feet. Corner lots in "R" Use Districts shall have a
depth of not less than one hundred (100) feet, a frontage of not less than seventy (70)
feet, and an area of not less than seven thousand (7,000) square feet.
4.19 (a) No auxiliary use shall be permitted in an "R" Use District which requires
manual labor, the storage or transfer of goods or materials, the carrying on of a trade in
its ordinary sense or the use of a workshop. This does not prohibit the maintenance of
a personal or hobby workshop from which no profit is derived and which does not create
a nuisance; nor does it prohibit Home Occupations within the principal dwelling as
defined below.
(b) Home Occupation. Any occupation within the principal dwelling and
clearly incidental thereto, carried on by the members of the family residing on the
premises, provided that no other person is employed, that no stock in trade is kept or
commodities sold, no mechanical equipment is used except such that is normally used
for family, domestic, or household purposes, and there is no exterior indication other
than a sign permitted by the Use District regulations that the building is being used for
any purpose other than a dwelling. When within the above requirements, a home
occupation includes but is not limited to the following: (a) art studio; (b) dressmaking;(c)
professional office of a lawyer, engineer, architect, accountant, salesman, real estate
agent, insurance agent, or other similar occupation; however, a home occupation shall
not be interpreted to include barber shops, beauty parlor, restaurants, or office of a
physician or dentist where mechanical equipment is used, teaching of music, or any
other occupation requiring loud and disturbing sounds. (91-02)
4.2 "A" USE DISTRICT.
4.21 In "A" Use Districts no building or land shall be used and no building shall be
hereafter erected, constructed, reconstructed or altered, which is designed, arranged or
intended to be used for any purpose, unless otherwise provided for in this ordinance,
except for the use heretofore permitted in Paragraph 3.3 hereof, for "A" Use Districts.
4.22 Two story apartment buildings shall not exceed a height of 25 feet and three
story buildings shall not exceed a height of 35 feet provided, however, that where
parking is provided within the building an additional 5 feet height is permitted. In no
event shall any building exceed 40 feet.
4.23. Apartment units shall provide a minimum floor area of not less than 550 square
feet for units not containing more than one bedroom. Apartment units shall provide floor
area of not less than 650 square feet per unit for units containing two bedrooms and an
additional 100 square feet for each additional bedroom contained in each such unit.
Living units containing bathroom facilities and kitchen facilities with no separate
bedrooms shall be known as efficiency units, and shall provide floor area of not less
than 450 square feet per unit. Hotel rooms shall provide a floor area of not less than
300 square feet including closet and bathroom.
4.24 Inside lots in "A" Districts shall have a depth of not less than one hundred (100)
feet, a frontage of not less than fifty (50) feet and an area of not less than five thousand
(5,000) square feet. Corner lots in "A" Districts shall have a depth of not less than one
hundred (100) feet, a frontage of not less than sixty (60) feet and an area of not less
than six thousand (6,000) square feet.
4.25 In "A" Districts the setbacks shall not be less than 25 feet from the zoned
street line, and the side setback shall be 9 feet or 15% of the width of the lot, whichever
is greater. On corner lots the exterior side setback shall be 15 feet from the zoned
street line. Rear setbacks shall be 20 feet from the rear lot line plus an additional one
foot for each two feet of building height above 25 feet. Where more than one building is
erected on a lot, a minimum spacing of 10 feet shall be required between buildings.
4.26 Apartment buildings shall not contain more than one dwelling unit for each
900 square feet of lot area.
4.27 The combined area occupied by all principal and accessory buildings shall
not exceed 30% of the lot area for buildings of a height less than 25 feet, and shall not
exceed 28% of the lot area for three story structures.
4.3 "C" USE DISTRICTS (87-04)

4.32 (85-03) It is the intention of this Zoning ordinance that commercial uses within
the City of West Miami shall be limited to retail sales and service stores that do not
cause obnoxious odors or noises, or which would constitute an eyesore or nuisance, or
be detrimental to a residential community. All uses shall comply in every respect with
the requirements of the Florida State Board of Health. Any other business not herein
specifically listed shall be only permitted in commercial use districts upon the issuance
of a Special Use Permit under Section 2A.
4.32-1 Setbacks, cubic content. yard area, etc.
Setbacks, cubic content, yard area, lot sizes, etc., shall be as specified in Article II
of this chapter.
4.32-2 Height.
The maximum height of a building shall be two (2) stories and shall not exceed
thirty-five (35) feet in height.
4.32-3 Floor area ration and lot coverage.
The floor area ratio shall be 0.40 at one story and shall be increased by 0.11 for
each additional story. Structure parking shall not count as part of the floor area, but
shall be counted in computing building height and number of stories. The total lot
coverage permitted for all buildings on the site shall not exceed forty per cent (40%) of
the total lot area. Enclosed or non-enclosed mall areas shall not count as part of the
floor area, for floor area ratio computation purposes, nor as part of the lot coverage.
4.32-4 Landscaped open space.
The minimum landscaped open space at one story shall be
in accordance with the following table:
Size of Total % of Total
Lot Area Lot Area
Up to one acre 18.0%
More than one acre and up
to five (5) acres 16.0%
More than five (5) acres and
up to twenty-five (25) acres 14.0%
More than twenty-five (25) acres 12.0%
The minimum landscaped open space shall be increased by one and one-half
percent (1.5%) for each additional story or part thereof. For the purpose of computing
the amount of required landscaped open space where the building height varies, the
number of stories shall be equal to the sum of the products of the number of stories of'
each part of the buildings of a different height times its floor area divided by the sum of
the floor area of all parts of the buildings. Said open space shall be extensively
landscaped with grass, trees and shrubbery. Water areas may be used as part of the
required landscaped open space provided such water areas do not exceed twenty
percent (25%) of the required landscaped open space. The specific areas within
enclosed or non-enclosed malls which are landscaped with grass, trees and/or
shrubbery, water areas therein, and areas therein with permanent art display may be
used as part of the required landscaped open space provided such areas do not exceed
ten percent (10%) of the required landscaped open space. Trees shall be provided on
the basis of forty (40) trees per acre of required open space, trees being defined. as in
the landscape regulations, Code of Metropolitan Dade County. This requirement shall
be in addition to the requirements of said landscape regulations.
4.32-5 Prohibited uses.
Sale of fruit or merchandise from trucks, wagons or other vehicles parked on or
along public or private streets or from open stands or vacant lots shall be prohibited.
Such business on private or public property shall be conducted only from within
approved permanent substantial buildings.
4.32-6 Enclosed uses.
All uses shall be conducted within completely enclosed buildings, unless
otherwise specifically provided herein. All materials and products shall be stored within
the building or within an area completely enclosed with walls which have a life
expectancy of twenty (20) years or more from the date of installation of said walls.
Storage shall not be made above the height of the walls.
4.32-7 Business property adjacent to residential districts.
Where a business lot abuts an Rl, R2 or A zoned property, a decorative masonry
wall at least five (5) feet in height shall be erected on the business lots along the
common property line separating the two (2) districts. Where a dedicated alley
separates the two (2) districts, the five-foot decorative masonry wall shall be erected
along the business lots adjacent to the alley, permitting only openings for egress and
ingress purposes with the smallest width possible for this purpose. Where the business
property is a through lot, and the rear of the business lot lies across the street right-ofway
from Rl, R2 or A zoned property, said will shall be located on the business lot ten
(10) feet in from the official right-of-way line at the rear of the lot, and the ten-foot strip
shall be substantially landscaped. The director shall determine which part of the lot is
the rear property line. No wall will be required along the front property line of the
business lot where the same is separated from a residential zone by a street. Where
the common property line between the two (2) districts is an interior side property line,
the required will shall extend only to a point fifteen (15) feet from the official front
property line.
4.32-8 Expansion of existing commercial structures.
Expansion of commercial structures existing at the time of adoption of this article
which do not comply with these regulations may be accomplished within five (5) years
from the date of the adoption of this article provided that such expansion is approved at
public hearing and provided that said expansion is in accordance with the following
requirements:
(a) Expansion(s) are in accordance with applicable zoning
regulations that were in existence immediately prior to the adoption of
this article.
(b) Expansion(s) shall be attached to existing commercial
structures.
(c) Landscaped open space shall be required equivalent to thirty
(30) percent of the additional floor area. Open space shall be as
defined in this article.
(d) The amount of trees required and the definitions of trees shall
be in accordance with this article.
4.32-9 Plan review standards. (85-03C)
(A) The City Manager shall review plans for compliance with zoning
regulations and for compliance with the site plan review criteria. The decisions of the
City Manager in relation to the site plan review criteria may be appealed by the
party(ies) which filed the application for the project to the City Council within thirty (30)
days of the date the project was denied approval in writing. Appeals will be heard as
expeditiously as possible. The purpose of the site plan review is to encourage logic,
imagination and variety in the design process and thereby insure the congruity of the
proposed development and its compatibility with the surrounding area. All final plans
submitted for building permits shall be substantially in compliance with plans approved
under the plan review procedure herein established.
(B) Procedure. Exhibits which the applicant shall submit to the City Manager
shall include, but not be limited to the following:
(1) Schematic site plans at a scale of not less than one inch equals twenty
(20) feet containing the following information:
(a) Proposed commercial floor area.
(b) Height, size, shape and location of existing and proposed
buildings.
(c) Parking layouts.
(d) Proposed grades if significantly altered.
(e) Existing and proposed fences, walls, signs, architectural
accents, street furniture and locations of advertising or graphic
features.
(f) Existing and proposed landscaping including any existing selfsupporting
perennial plant which has a trunk diameter of at least
three (3)inches measured three (3) feet above grade (at the
base of the tree), and which normally grows to a minimum
overall height of fifteen (15) feet.
(2) Schematic building plans, including elevation and/ or sections of major
structures.
(3) Isometrics or perspective and/or model(s) of the proposed
development.
The City Manager shall have the right to waive any of the items required because of the
nature or timing of the development or because the information cannot be furnished at
the time of this review.
(C) Site plan review criteria. The following checklist of criteria shall be utilized as
a guide' by the City Manager and by the City Council upon appeal, in the review
process:
(1) The City of West Miami Comprehensive Plan.
(2) Exterior spatial relationships. The three dimensional air-space volume
created by the arrangement of structures and landscape shall produce
spatial relationships that function with the intended use of the project
and are compatible with the development or zoning in the adjoining
area.
(3) Landscape. Landscape shall be preserved in its natural state in so far
as practicable by minimizing tree removal. Landscape treatment shall
be provided to enhance architectural features, strengthen vistas and
important axes and provide shade.
(4) Buffers. Buffering elements that provide a logical transition to
adjoining, existing or permitted uses shall be provided.
(5) Scale. Scale of proposed structures shall be compatible with
surrounding existing or permitted uses or shall be made compatible by
the use of the buffering element.
(6) Signs and outdoor lighting. All outdoor lighting, signs or permanent
outdoor advertising or identification features shall be designed as an
integral part of and be harmonious with building design and the
surrounding landscape.
(7) Roof installation and facilities. All permitted installations housing
mechanical equipment located on the roof shall be screened from the
ground view and from view at the level in which the installations are
located, and shall be designed as an integral part and be harmonious
with the building design.
(8) Circulation. Pedestrian and auto circulation shall be separated insofar
as practicable and all circulation systems shall adequately serve the
needs of the project and be compatible and functional with circulation
systems outside the development.
(9) Parking areas. Building wall extensions, plantings, berms or other
innovative means shall be used as a means of minimizing the adverse
effect of the visual impact of parking areas. This requirement is in
addition to the requirements of the landscape regulations of the Code
of Metropolitan Dade County.
(10) Service areas. Service areas which may be provided shall be
screened and so located as not to be visible from view. (85-03)
4.33 (81-06) In every case where a "C" Use District abuts or faces either an "R"
Use District or an "All Use District there shall be erected between the various Use
District property one of the following:
(a) a wire chain link fence not to exceed eight (8) feet in height with a
visual screen not less than five feet (5') or more than six feet (6') high. Such
screen shall consist of aluminum stripping woven into the chair link fence; or
(b) a concrete wall either solid or of horizontal louvers which overlap, not
less than five (5) feet in height or more than six (6) feet in height and which
may have a wire chain link fence on the top, which together with the wall,
shall not exceed eight (8) feet in height. Chain link shall be installed on the
"R" or "All side and shall extend not less than three (3) inches below the top
or cap of the wall. Not more than two driveway openings shall be permitted in
such walls for ingress and egress of vehicles, and for a distance of four (4)
feet immediately adjacent to either side of driveway the height of such
masonry or visual screen wall shall be 2-1/2 feet. Driveway openings shall be
located so as not to create a traffic hazard to vehicles or pedestrians, and the
locations shall be approved by the building officer. Barbed wire topping shall
be permitted on fences as provided in Section 7.24 of Ordinance 282. Failure
to maintain visual screen shall be a violation of this ordinance.(81-06)
4.34. No front setback beyond the zoned street line, no rear setback beyond the
utility easement, and no side setbacks will be required; provided, however, that
whenever any single family dwelling, duplex dwelling, or multi-family dwelling is
constructed in a "C" Use District, front, side and rear setbacks will be required as
follows:
(a) For single family dwellings and duplex dwellings setbacks shall be required
as provided in Section 4.15 of this Ordinance.
(b) For multi-family dwellings of more than two dwelling units, setbacks shall be
required as provided in Section 4.25 of this Ordinance.
4.35 All buildings in this Use District shall provided enclosed garbage and trash
bins accessible to collecting crews. Requirements for such bins shall be determined by
the Building official in accordance with the use or anticipated use of the buildings, and
may vary as use is changed. Street numbers shall be prominently displayed at the front
and at the rear of each building.
4.36 (85-03B) No gasoline and oil filling stations or service station shall be erected
or located within the City of West Miami unless a Special Use Permit is obtained under
Section 2A and unless each building, permanent or semi-permanent structure and/or
installation, appurtenance, and underground tank for the storage of flammable and/or
combustible liquids, any or all of which may be located upon or under the premises of
such station, be at least:
(a) Fifty (50) feet from the nearest R-Use property line of any
property zoned for residential purposes;
(b) Five hundred (500) feet from the nearest building, or permanent
or semi-permanent structure and/or installation, or
appurtenance of any other such station;
(c) Five hundred (500) feet from the nearest driveway, paved walk,
or other means of ingress or, or to any church, hospital, school
or other such institution where large numbers of pedestrians
congregate.
4.37 Any gasoline and oil filling station or service station which is presently
erected or located within the distances prescribed by Section 4.36 hereof, may, upon
issuance of a Special Use Permit under Section 2A of this Zoning Ordinance, move to a
new location within the City of West Miami, provided that the new site conforms in every
way to the zoning requirements for such use. (85-03B)
4.38 Nothing herein shall prohibit the City of West Miami from installing on
municipally owned property a gasoline pump and storage tank of not more than 2,000
gallons, to be used solely for the pumping and storage of gasoline for municipal vehicles
only. The intent of this paragraph is to permit the City of West Miami to purchase
